description:
We went in for brunch. Excellent pain au chocolat I'm still dreaming about it. 
The buckwheat crepe was amazing too. Then the Benedicts were ok, nothing to write home about.
But the French toast was worth it, not too sweet and just the right amount. I want to go back for that croissant.
author: Magda C.

description:
My cousin and her husband came all the way from San Luis Obispo last Saturday to specifically have brunch at Petit Crenn with my husband and me.  This was our first visit. Unfortunately, most of our experience there was not what we expected it to be for such a reputable and expensive restaurant. 
On the positive side, our dishes were served at the exact same time, after we ate glorious slices of apple cardamom tea cake.  The smoked trout Benedicts and French toast were delicious too.  As for the crab buckwheat crepe my cousin was disappointed with its taste which leads into the negative part of our visit. 
Although we were seated right away it took a long while for our waitress to come, a tall young woman with golden blonde hair.  In an impersonal way she asked what we'd like to eat then left without taking a drink order.  After several tries my husband finally got her attention but she seemed annoyed, especially when we inquired about the French press type and to please serve us regular coffee and decaf for 2 people each.
Well, 20 minutes passed and our coffee didn't come, although other customers, who had arrived after us, had received their coffees. My husband flagged down the waitress again and she became curt, saying it was still being prepared.  Once it arrived, 10 minutes later, we were surprised that the containers were small, enough for just one cup each.  Other tables had larger containers, even for couples, making us wonder if she should've asked us which size we'd like. 
In addition, the waitress never came by to ask how we were doing.  We also noticed that she was very attentive and polite to other customers.  The only respite was another waitress who smiled while refilling our water glasses. Once our dour waitress gave us the check she said thank you in a condescending tone, making my husband and I regret our politeness and tipping her well. 
Since most of the customer crowd was young we couldn't help wondering if our waitress treated us shoddily because of our older age.  Nonetheless, we're not going back to this so-called classy restaurant since there's no telling if the kind of service we received will be repeated again.
author: Gerri L.

description:
I came for brunch with a reservation on a Sunday, and the restaurant was pretty full. The space is small, but the interior design is super simple and elegant. Parking wasn't too big a problem at all on a Sunday, and parking is also free!

We ordered the pear brioche, omelette, and mushroom tartine. The pear brioche wasn't the fluffy brioche I imagined--it was like a almond flavored, pear blondie. It wasn't too sweet, and perfectly crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside. The omelette was good, but somewhat of  a let down since there weren't any toppings inside. It was basically a rolled up sheet of egg covered in a hollandaise-like sauce, served with caesar salad. The omelette tasted almost like silken tofu, but it was definitely very intricately made. The mushroom tartine was good but a little too saucy for me.

This place was pretty good, but I would probably go for the poached benedict instead next time. However, it's worth a try if you've watched Atelier Crenn on Netflix's Chef's Table.
author: Sandra S.

description:
Casual place charging a decent amount for an a-ok 5 course meal with expensive supplements! (Caviar!).

Service was excellent after being seated. When entering the restaurant no welcome no happy birthday nothing!

Food was ok. Main course was swordfish, not the healthiest of fishes but also not the tastiest. Wine tastings were nice and unique wines we had not had before.
author: Sumit C.

description:
Let's just say, our visit to Petit Crenn was long overdue. I'm personally a huge fan of Dominique Crenn and love Atelier Crenn. When we heard that Petit Crenn opened a few years ago, my husband and I have been discussing coming here for a visit. The timing never worked out quite right but we finally gave it a visit last month. It was a perfectly sunny and warm evening (I know, shocking weather in SF!) to visit Petit Crenn, which specialize in seafood. The only thing on the menu is a set course with seasonal seafood/vegetable. 

The dishes were executed very well, and really showcase the ingredients. Why the 4 star? I think the meal was perfect for day we went, which was quite a warm evening during the summer (and something that isn't all too common in SF). We really enjoyed the "cool" meal that wasn't too heavy. But I can see that if I was hungrier that day and the weather was a bit cooler, I would prefer something with more substance and warmer. My husband wasn't entirely full after the meal, so we end up getting ice cream somewhere else. Overall, great meal and we plan to come back to try their brunch menu!
author: Sharon L.

description: Vegan tasting menu is very good- definitely a place we will go to for future celebrations! Service by few staff is very friendly, a few too cool but equally professional. Ambience is casual relax which is perfect for us. We felt the creativity and taste of the  vegan tasting menu is comparable to some Michelin stars restaurant we tried in Paris and London.
author: Myra T.

description: Oh, come on, how do you make food taste this good? Menu changes often, so silly to describe all the dishes, it was the quality of everything that set this apart. Dominique's Atelier program trickles down nicely here. We sat at seats 1&2 at the bar, it was like watching ballet. No panics, shouting here. My only negative is the wine tasting portions were too small. Go!
author: Dave Y.

description:
Overall, I think this place is a really great deal! If you've been to Atelier Crenn, you can't compare this place to that or expect anything like it. It's much more casual here and the vibe is very different. The menu changes often which I love, since it's always a good reason to keep me coming back for more! Also, I love Dominique Crenn so even if it was the same menu I'd still come back (:

I would love to sit at the bar next time, and even try their brunch as it looks delicious!
author: Megan K.

description:
Unlike her flagship restaurant Atelier Crenn, Petit Crenn is focused on homestyle rustic cooking which mirrors the food chef Crenn grew up eating. Not fancy but the food here is absolutely delicious. 

The dishes here are simple in nature but are executed perfectly. The most surprising was the sourdough bread. Based on appearance it doesn't look like anything special but after taking a bite into the bread I was completely blown away. Crispy on the outside and chewy in the middle I loved this bread so much. 

The peas also were a real standout. The quality of the ingredients really stand out and the mint was a nice compliment to the crispness of the peas. The grilled fish was also delicious.  I highly recommend this restaurant. If you like simple food where the ingredients really shine on their own then you will love it.
author: Vincent Q.

description:
This restaurant is quite unassuming from the outside with a cute little "Petit Crenn" scribbled on the window. 

We made our way in, confirmed our RSVP, got seated, and waited for the rest of the group to show up. We were offered still or sparking water immediately, and we asked to see the alcohol menu. We got sparkling Rose.

As the rest of the group arrived, we were told a little bit about the menu, asked about dietary restrictions, and potential add-ons.  
  
Some notable things:
- The dishes are generally vegetable and seafood focused.
- When our wine was poured, the label was consistently facing the person receiving the pour. This is a really small, but significant detail in fine dining. 
- Wine selection is on point, but also very expensive. Individual glasses of wine are about 17ish, beer and cider have no options under 10 (there are only 4 or 5 options), and bottles of wine start at about 70. Average wine bottle is probably about 120ish.
- The silverware seemed to have some water deposits (residual "spots" after being washed) or some imperfections that standout. Not really a big deal, but definitely noticeable. 
- Every dish was exceptionally put together.
- The plates and silverware were thought out. Plates have a rustic feel, very aesthetically pleasing. 
- Service was always on point.
- Napkin was folded when I used the restroom.
- Feels comfortable / homey with upscale service.

I think overall I had a great experience. It was approximately 195/person for the tasting menu, shared add-on dish, and a split bottle of wine (the cheapest one), tip, and tax. I don't know if the price per value is necessarily quite there though. I would probably expect this to be closer to 150, so we're not too far off. 

Recommended!
author: Kaje Y.

description: Brunch was wonderful.   Perfect press pot coffee,  buckwheat crepe,  smoked trout Benedict,  chocolate croissant... all as good as it gets.   Service is friendly and efficient.... This place has been added to our brunch rotation.
author: Bleep S.

description:
Farewell dinner in SF and I knew it had to be at one of Chef Dominique Crenn's restaurants.  I opted for her more casual restauarant Petit Crenn and I wasn't disappointed.  We got an amazing corner table right next to the window (where the light was great for taking some excellent photos). 

The menu and decor reflects a very clean and modern esthetic with little whimisical touches, like the elegant silverware to the meticulously placed micro-flowers.  I was blown away by the affordable prix-fix menu - still pricey, but not as extragavant as Atelier Crenn.  The six-course tasting menu left us full, but not uncomfortably stuffed.

I was hesitant with the seafood-heavy menu since I'm not a big fish fan, but Crenn's cooking left me convinced that you don't need meat to complete a meal. 

#1 course - canapes 
gougeres (pastry puffs) filled with cheese and topped with a shallot gelee.  these were absolutely amazing.  We subbed out the oysters for grilled nectarines which was also delicious. 

#2 tomatoe salad 
subbed out the mussels for tomatoes.  this was the BEST tomato salad I've ever had.  love the cucumber gelee and the avocado mousse and the lemon verbana made the dish. 

#3 Tokyo Turnips
Like a lot of yelpers, I was hesitant about the turnips since I'm not a big fan, but this version has me convinced to give these guys another chance. The consumme was very flavorful. 

#4 Entree - Grilled Mt. Lassen Trout
I've never been a big fan of trout, but Crenn's version has changed the way I think about trout.  It's not fishy at all, but pretty meaty and substantial and the sauce vierge melded it all together.

#5 Cheese plate - Bohemian Creamery, "Cowabunga" cheese
a semi-solid cheese that's more on the mild side and paired perfectly with the honey and tiny and surprisingly sweet cherry tomatos. 

#6 Dessert - Grand Macaron
If there had to be one dish I liked least, it is the dessert.  Up until this point, all of the dishes are light and elegant and the grand macaron is too big and sweet and dense.  If you love chocolate then you will love this dish.  I would have liked a lighter and smaller dessert - but that's totally my own personal preference. 

Really glad my last meal in SF was also the best.
author: Hieu H.

description:
What a beautiful homage to chef Crenn's hometown. Cozy space and amazing staff. 

My husband and I came to celebrate. We split a wine pairing for the tasting menu. We also added both supplements and were not disappointed! 

We started with the oysters and gruyere bites. I wanted to take that cheese puff to the back and get it pregnant. So. Good. 

The rest of the meal was phenomenal. The portions were super generous for a tasting menu. Everything from the trout with beets to the sea bass. 

Bravo times ten million.
author: Olivia B.

description:
Petit Crenn was an absolute joy to dine at. Managed to snag a small group reservation when several friends and I were in town for a conference. From its stellar attentive service to its perfectly distilled and *light* version of French cuisine (with some Californian flair), Petit Crenn makes you feel like you're dining at a really high-end restaurant, at a fraction of the price.

As soon as you walk in, you know you're in for a treat. It's a relatively small minimalist space, but it still feels airy and is beautifully decorated. The 6 course tasting menu is the name of the game here of course, with the option to upgrade for a few of the courses. We opted for one black truffle upgrade for one of the courses, but it wasn't quite worth it, the truffle got somewhat lost. That said though, every single course was amazing. Each dish had great contrasting flavors and texture at any given time. Any ingredient used felt fresh. Despite it being obviously French inspired food, it wasn't typically heavy as French food is (hello being cooked in 4 types of butter!). You come out of the meal not feeling overly bloated or full, you feel just right. The portions are small and well paced out, but by the end you don't still feel hungry at all. Oh, and I'd highly recommend doing the wine pairing, even if only the lower end one. The wines pair perfectly with all the courses.

That said, I'd gladly come back here the next time I'm in SF. Feels like it'll be one of those places where the menu constantly evolves and it'll always be a nice surprise eating there once again.
author: Jobye-Kyle K.

description: Nice place for Brunch. The Mushroom tartine was very good with distinctive strong flavours. The dungenous crab crepe tasted just right with the crab meat.
author: Meng L.

description:
I've been to Petit Crenn twice now and am absolutely in love!

My first visit was for dinner on a Thursday night. The tasting menu included gougères, Tomales Bay oysters, salade de fruits de mer, Tokyo turnips, grilled Mt. Lassen trout and grand macaron. We also opted for both supplements: some type of mushroom over potato purée and cheese with honeycomb. Everything was so delicious. The seafood paired perfectly with the fresh herbs, fruits and vegetables. The grand macaron at the end was so decadent, yet perfectly balanced by the tartness of the pomegranate seeds.

My second visit was for Sunday brunch. We ordered the mushroom tartine, buckwheat crepe and grilled fish. Once again, I was delighted by all of the flavors. The mushroom tartine was probably my favorite of the three dishes--a pile of mushrooms atop sourdough bread. The mushrooms are very flavorful and have a nice acidity. I would definitely return to have the tartine and fish again.

Overall, I highly recommend Petit Crenn and hope to be back again soon!
author: Leanne C.

description:
The tasting menu at Petit Crenn is one of the best dining experiences I've had in SF (and I've been eating through the list of Michelin starred restaurants).  The meal that night included:

(1).  Appetizers including Kusshi oysters and gougeres.  These were a great start to the meal and full of great flavors. 
(2).  Asparagus, radish with trout roe and dill creme fraiche.  This was a surprising and excellent dish that really embodies San Francisco to me. It's a balanced combination of east meets west, visually stunning and really playful. 
(3).  Brioche - this was not officially on the tasting menu list but was really good.
(4).  Tsar Nicoulai Caviar with spring vegetables. This was outstanding and one of two available supplements and even though it's a pricey $80, I have no regrets. 
(5).  Burgundy Escargot, Buckwheat Crepe, Green Garlic, Wild Mushroom plus the Black Truffle Supplement. This was the highlight of the meal for me. Just perfect. 
(6).  Halibut, Swiss Chard, Young Ginger and Citrus Jus.  This was a solid entree and the Swiss Chard brings all the elements together.
(7).  White Cheese, English Peas, Meyer Lemon and Grilled Levain. This dish was really bright and playful. Really enjoyable and it put a smile on my face. 
(8).  Citron Tart, Candied Meyer Lemon and Grapefruit. This was just the perfect dessert. 
(9).  Small sweets to end the meal. 

Service and ambiance was excellent as well. I really cannot understand why this place doesn't have a Michelin star. At $95 (gratuity included), this offers an outstanding value.  I also sat at the counter (the best seats in the house) and really appreciated the meticulous preparation of each dish and engaging the chefs in conversation. The atmosphere here is high energy and represents current Hayes Valley. Highly recommended and I look forward to coming here again.
author: Andrew S.

description:
I have a love/hate relationship with tasting menus, but Petit Crenn's left me feeling satisfied, yet not overly full, and like I had really gotten a taste of Chef Crenn's style and background. 

Highlights of the meal included the super-fresh oyster with fruit gelee and the gougere with cheese. The escargot with green garlic atop a mushroom-filled buckwheat crepe was tasty and inventive. The housemade brioche with butter and salt was perfect. And the lemon tarte with candied meyer lemon was to die for. Finally, the super simple Full Belly Farms asparagus with radish dish was amazingly clean and delicate, yet expertly prepared.

By the time the main protein--a relatively boring San Diego halibut with swiss chard--came I was pretty full and didn't feel like I needed a substantive protein dish. But the halibut was beautifully seasoned and cooked. The swiss chard was ok, but definitely the weakest link of the night.

Service was attentive, but not overbearing. The six-course meal ran about two hours. 

If I had to critique one thing, it would be the wine list. While I understand they're serving only very, very good wines (and beer), listing a few less-expensive bottles wouldn't be a bad move. There are great wines out there that can still be profitable without being outrageously expensive. For reference, the least expensive half bottle was $59, the least expensive glass was $16, which is really pricey, even for those who are going for a $95 tasting menu.
author: Adrienne K.

description:
My boyfriend surprised me with a reservation at Petit Crenn and it was wonderful. This is his favorite restaurant in the Bay Area and now I can say it's no surprise! Amazing service, great ambiance, lovely décor, and above all outstanding food.

The tasting menu for June consisted of:

Canapes - Gougeres, Beausoleil Oyser with Rhubarb Mignonette

Spanish Mackerel - Green Almond Tapenade, Bleu Belle Celtuce

Beluga Lentils and Fava Beans - Wild mushroom, Meyer Lemon, Brown Butter (((I never had such creamy, tastefully done mushrooms in my life)))

Mount Lassen Trout - Sauce Soubise, Fennel, Green Garlic Jus (((cooked to perfection)))

Bohemian Creamery "Boho Belle" - Honeycomb, grilled apricots, toasted levain (((supplement and well worth it)))

Clafoutis Tarte - Brooks Cherry, Vanilla Bean Ice Cream

Great presentations and well executed tasteful plates of art. We also did a wine pairing and it enhanced and complimented the food extremely well. The servers did a spectacular job! I left feeling happier, fuller and more excited about Chef Dominique Crenn!
author: Jenna L.

description:
After figuring out that I would be heading to san fran, the first thing that came to mind was going to this restaurant. I kinda wanted to go atelier crane but that i would save to savour on a longer trip to the city.

The place is buzzing. Full capacity by 9pm. You have to speak a little louder to hold a conversation but honestly it's worth it.

On offer that evening was the tasting menu. They offered a supplement menu as well. I'm not sure I enjoyed having options for a tasting menu as I prefer to go with a story from a directed menu.  So we bowed out of those options as tempting as they were.

I will say this, every dish we were served had this delicate freshness that embodied this locally sourced ideology. Even if you didn't know that - you could tell. Crisp, flavourful and not heavy handed in the seasoning. The ingredients just sing with the seafood and vegetables.

As someone who isn't a fan of oysters - I really enjoyed the tomales bay oysters! delicious.
The gougeres were airy and crisp with a nice finish. Great little pastry to start.

Hands down my favourite dish was the heirloom tomatoes. I crave it still. It was perfect.  The coriander, the anise - the broth the tomatoes, watermelon were bathed in - a dreamlike bath for my palette.

The next dish was the tokyo turnips in a lobster ginger consommé. I enjoyed it but i'm not a big fan of turnips so i can't say it was my favourite. It had a fresh garden bite to the turnips i like but it was a bit too bitter for my taste.

Although the main dish was the trout, i couldn't get my mind off the tomato dish.  It was that good. 

I loved the dessert. A warm pear taste tartan with a valhrona orleys sorbet. It was a warm pear hug. 

We had ordered coffee to go with this meal but sadly it took so long to get there our dessert was done but i did enjoy that it came with a few cookies.  Yay!

A great experience I recommend. I would like to actually try their weekend brunch one day.

I have to say, the area of the city its set in is my favourite so I am very glad to have discovered this area.

ps. i apparently was told i could not use a canadian debit card. very sad about that and made no sense to me.
author: Geraldine G.

description:
Dominique Crenn is the best female chef and probably also one of the best chef around the globe, and petit Crenn I would call it the farm-to-table version of Atlier Crenn. 

Lunch probably is not the best opportunity to explore as it only serves limited menu on an a la carte basis, yet I did encounter one of the best dishes - mushroom tartine. If you did not order this, just make sure you go back and redo.

Countless mushroom sitting on a giant piece of sour dough, it was crispy to the outside and soft within. Very juicy, very flavorful, and...very attempting! 

While this piece of mushroom Tartine completely caught my heart, I dislike the fact that they only have one item on their lunch dessert menu, that I would have to quietly skip. Hopefully they could bring in more options, food-wise.
author: Elaine H.

description:
EXCELLENT INGREDIENTS, MAKE FOR EXCELLENT FOOD, add an EXCELLENT WAIT STAFF what more could you ask for?

   The Prix Fix menu $86.00 pp, call ahead if you have food allergies as they are VERY accommodating, without making you feel bad ~ it isn't inexpensive, however splurge and enjoy the ride. Ms. Crenn's attention to detail in her presentations are spectacular and the taste she creates are truly incredible upon your tongue from the starter to dessert a "True Feist to your Palette"

    Rush to Resy, make your reservation and sit back enjoy the relaxed atmosphere & scrumptious offerings of Petit Crenn.
author: Becky L.

description:
Absolutely awesome experience with Petit Crenn to celebrate my birthday. Started out with a glass of champagne and people watching from the bar. The staff is totally delightful, the location is absolutely charming and the food is divine. I requested a lactose and gluten free menu and was totally delighted by the level of customized options for my dinner and the quality and charm that came with them. Paired with the Reserve Wine Tasting I left a very happy camper with a full stomach and heart. 

Some of the most outstanding portions of the meal were the perfectly cooked, delicately plated pieces of fish decorated with the most vibrant and adorable vegetables. 

Absolutely an inspiration to try the full Atelier Crenn offering and a spot I look forward to returning to as the season and menu evolve through this year!
author: Angela D.

description:
Our first time going was when they first opened. We sat at the high seats overlooking the kitchen due to a mix up with the reservation system.  We couldn't do the tasting menu as a result. The a la carts menu was a hit and miss. It was quite a surprise since one of my most memorable meals was at Atelier Crenn. 

I'm so glad we came back and gave them another chance. The food yesterday was great. Surprisingly, on of my favorite dishes last night was the Dirty Girl Farms Legumes. I'm typically not a big fan of beans, except the whole green beans and such, but the dish was a perfect blend of different umami flavors. The added shaved tuna heart, uni butter, and pieces of tuna stewed with the beans made it a punch of umami. The Rock fish was perfectly cooked and the clams had a perfect oceany flavor. The one miss for me tonight was the dessert. I felt the brioche was over soaked with sugar solution. It was too sweet for my tastes.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
3.5 stars.
Came for dinner. We sat in the wonderful window corner seat. Very cozy and spacious at the same time. We did the tasting menu:

- Gougère and Tomales Bay Oysters - Good presentation, fresh, off to a good start.
- Heirloom Tomatoes with Watermelon - WOW. Flavor explosion in my mouth. The tomatoes taste like they're from the peak of summer, and the watermelon is the sweetest and juiciest!
- Toyko Turnips - NO THANK YOU. I did like the lobster consommé they were sitting in though.
- Chanterelles in mashed potatoes with shaved truffle and olive oil (add-in for $40) - Incredible.
- House made brioche. - Woweeee. Soft and light and airy and amazing. 
- Grilled Mt. Lassen Trout - Served with a butter bean puree (yuck), artichoke (yum), and sauce vierge (also yum). But also with some sort of stewed? roasted? tomatoes (not sure what they were but they were not good). The fish itself was delicious.
- Pear Tarte Tatin - Good but not good enough to finish.

The service felt a bit rushed; we were done in 1 hour and 20 minutes. We ordered an extra drink to make dinner last a little longer.

Overall it was good, but there are so many restaurants that are at this level and cost much less.
author: Jaching H.

description:
Tip Sitting at the bar is great.
Note: I rarely give 5 stars.

Great Ambiance, Great Service, Great Menu/Food.  

The Brioche French Toast is the best I have had on the west coast hands down.  So much so I need to revisit the others that I know. This brioche doesn't throw a lot of sugar at you.   A great blend of flavors as the strawberries was a great compliment to the brown sugar and I have yet to have a creme chantilly in the US that tastes better.  Surely you will not be disappointed if you stop here for brunch.
author: M C.

description: We came here on a Wednesday night. We had reservations at 930 but came a half hour earlier hoping to get seated earlier. They were able to seat us as soon as we got there. They gave us complimentary glass of sparkling rose. The staff gave us time to look through the wine list and were attentive. I selected the sauvignon blanc glass. It had a nice finish and went really well with the first few courses. We started with savory puffs and oysters with pepper on top. They complemented each other really well. Then we got my absolute favorite dish of the whole meal the heirloom tomato salad. The tomatoes were so flavorful and the balls of melon were a fantastic addition. We then got the caviar dish, the sauce was fantastic and the omelet was really light and balanced out the salty caviar. The swordfish was exceptional. I didn't know swordfish could be so tender. The cheese plate was not as flavorful as I would like but very soft. The millefuille was flakey with a light creme that was perfect. Overall a fantastic meal with great service in a nice ambiance. You absolutely should check it out.
author: Anne S.

description:
Gonna have a really hard time giving this experience any more than two stars, mainly because you simply don't get what you pay for - and their pricing is a mystery.

We paid $420 for a dinner for two - sat at the 'chefs table' on extremely uncomfortable stools for 2 consecutive hours while we were slowly served decent french food and a wine pairing that offered about 1.5oz of wine per dish.

There are plenty of fancy restaurants to hit up in SF and they cost considerably less than Petit Crenn - do yourself a favor and skip this one.
author: Ross H.

description:
Absolutely incredible. Impeccable service, clean, efficient and oozing with culinary talent. We came from Washington state just to dine at a restaurant by the great Dominique Crenn for my husbands 40th. The items were presented beautifully, had unique and lasting flavor and flowed effortlessly. I was more than excited to see Dominique herself walk in. I felt like a school kid seeing a hero. After much anxiety and wondering, my husband said, "go introduce yourself ". Finally trailing behind him, I did. So happy I did. She is warm and charming, and an absolute delight. You can really see the love of the craft emulating from her every fiber. 

On another note, I'm not typically a consumer for seafood. Other than some crab, salmon or scallops, I've always found seafood bland and lifeless. Boy has my mind been forever changed. The delicacy that the food was handled with, layered with complex yet simple ingredients was an absolute sensation. Also, I was delighted at the way they handled my celiac dietary restrictions. As most restaurants replace gluten ingredients with things that can be rather boring in comparison to the original ingredients. 

My husband and I will be back!
author: Trina G.

description: Great modern French in a "reasonable" price range (for San Francisco). Exactly the kind of restaurant you'd find in Paris. Fresh local ingredients. Set menu. Loved the squid and the fraisier. However, kind of disqualifies as an authentic French place as meals aren't served with bread/baguette. Ordered some, got brioche instead. It was delicious but I don't think charging $7 makes sense knowing you pay $180 for 2 without drinks.
author: Clémentine C.

description:
One of our favorites in the city! 
 We love the menu and the people. Cherie( sherry)  is our favorite. 
The menu changes daily and as for the bar it's on a  first come first serve basis. We usually go right at the time they open to make sure we get seats. Otherwise, you can make a reservation and you will be able to order their prix fix menu that is not available at the bar. 
Some of the high lights on the menu now is sweet 100 tomatoes. It includes lots and lots of tomatoes, roe, cucumber and some edible flowers. 
We usually get their fish ( either salmon or snapper). You can't go wrong. 
Their brioche with the most incredible butter is also another amazing item. 
They also have these little puff pastries filled with cheese ( I can't think of the name right now) and they come in a portion of 4 bites. Delicious! 
You can't basically go wrong here! Chef Crenn is truly amazing!
author: Ghazal P.

description:
So many instructions, don't be this and that, parking blah blah...not the most welcoming of starts.
Cool greeting, not any fuzziness here. The seating is brutal, hard and unyielding. Bad sign.
In short, precious food, precious price. Assembled with tweezers, not soul. Tasty and empty.
Numb butt after 2+ hours, hungry for substance.
author: William M.

description:
My husband and I saw Petit Crenn on one of the Worth It episodes for comparison of good toast, and thought to give it a try for a Sunday brunch. We also found out later that the restaurant was owned by the famous French chef Dominique Crenn, owner of both Petit Crenn and Atelier Crenn. Petit Crenn, was a more casual un-formal dining. I have yet to try the two Michelin star Atelier Crenn, but saw both of the restaurants was also featured on the Netflix TV series Chefs Table, very inspiring and touching story of chef Crenn's life journey. So definitely on my "to do" list.

Service: 
Petite Crenn is a small, cute, intimate restaurant. Greeted and serviced by friendly staff.  We liked the fact that they included service charge within the dishes (no judgment, no fuss). Thank you chef Crenn for paying your workers correctly, unlike the other restaurants. 

They use a cute chair design for the restaurant but not practical as it was wobbly and my husband felt unsafe when he was sitting on it and felt like he would fall off if he sits on either side of the chair. Chair material was plastic, so it felt a bit cheap. 

Food:
We ordered 2 mushroom tartines and an mussels appetizer (special of the day). $20 for each dish. The mushroom tartine was interesting, tasty and original. A good size piece of toast that will make you full. Loved the piled mushrooms on top of the toast. Although, the sourness was a bit too over powering for me and the side of the toast was a bit too hard that it started hurting the top of my gums by the time I finished eating (we had the same hard bread on the side for our mussel dish as well).  I guess some people like eating bread that's super hard on the outside. I thought the presentation of the toasts that we got wasn't as nicely presented like how I saw it on some of the other photos with nicely decorated mini purple flowers on top. Nevertheless, it was still a good piece of toast. The mussels was a bit bland and I thought the sauce/cream could be a bit more thicker as it was a kind of watery. 

Parking:
We were lucky enough to find free street parking on a Sunday that was pretty close to the restaurant, without having to go around the area a few times. otherwise like the restaurant suggested, could park at the performing arts garage.
author: Sisi H.

description:
Outstanding. I get that there are going to be negative reviews on any expensive place, but I don't think the ones here are justified at all -- yes, this place is expensive, but the quality fits the price. I wouldn't say everything was perfect, but we loved pretty much every dish that was put in front of us.

In rough order of how much we liked them:

- Gnocchi a la Parisienne
- Fromage blanc mousse
- Octopus cassoulet
- Red oak salad
- Charred asparagus
- Canapes
- Bread and butter
- Mignardises
- Alaskan halibut

The gnocchi blew my mind, as did the dessert in some sense, because it's not something I would typically ever like, and it was amazing. (We actually had seen someone order chocolate cake at the bar before we sat down, and originally asked to swap out the fromage blanc mousse for that, but the couple at the table next to us convinced us not to. I'm glad we listened.) Another big surprise was the salad, which doesn't look or sound like anything special, but was so good.

Overall, just a really great experience that was well worth the cost. (We also got to meet Dominique Crenn, who came out to say hello to each table.)
author: Shawn H.

description:
My partner and I shared a meal at Petit Crenn that was nothing short of magical. Our server, Pierre, was beyond charming, and the food was absolutely fantastic. We shared the tasting menu with wine, and opted to add the caviar dish, which ended up being the favorite of the night. Apparently, I've never had good caviar before. My partner pretty much had a religious experience when he took a bite of it and, after I tried it, I literally had tears in my eyes. Every dish was absolutely delicious. By the end of the meal, both of us were that amazing sort of full you get when you eat loads of absurdly good food. 

Highly recommend this adorable restaurant for a romantic night out!
author: Risa P.

description:
I was very pensive after reading reviews that Petit Crenn had no land-dwelling food options. I'm not a big on pescatarian menus, but I was willing to see this out after my husband planned on dinner here. Long story short, I guess I'm a bigger fan of these types of menus than I thought! I don't really understand the super harsh criticism of Petit Crenn. I felt like our meal was reasonably priced and I was definitely full by the end of our meal. Favorites from the evening were the gnocchi with mushrooms, some beautifully crafted bread that accompanied the cheese course we added on, and of course, dessert with a giant macaron. The main entree for the evening was a striped bass, and while I don't love cooked fish, this was good but wished the crispy skin wasn't so salty. Service was good at the beginning where the dishes came out quickly with few breaks in between. After more people came in, we sat for long stretches without our food, namely between our main, cheese course, and dessert.

All in all, I definitely felt like this was a wonderful intro to Dominique Crenn's style.
author: Lisa I.

description:
I'm surprised by the neg reviews! Some point toward service, others the food, both of which were a lovely experience - collectively agreed upon by our group.

Our group of 8 had a reservation, eliminating any kind of wait. The food was as inventive as it was delicious (who would've thought oysters and peaches would go well together? It was magic!), and the staff was utterly friendly and so, so informative, even bringing out the behemoth of a trout pre-cooking to tell us a little about our meal. 

Pricey yes, but you knew that coming in. Adorable ambiance with a woman at the helm of the kitchen. Two very enthusiastic thumbs up!
author: Steph L.

description:
I've been wanting want to try this place for so long and finally got a reservation at the chef's counter. It was a prix fixe menu aka set menu with fixed price for $87 per person (gratuity included). Not sure if you can order a la carte at the counter (I've observed other people at the counter received different dishes than us), but we weren't given the a la carte menu so we just went along. Service was very friendly but a bit slow at times. The restaurant was very accommodating when it came to dietary restrictions but I think that's one of the reasons that the service was a bit slow. 

We started with some house made brioche and butter and some canopes (variety of small bites); that particular evening they served pink scallop crudo, gougeres (mini cheesy puff pastry), and some radishes with herb butter. A great way to start our meal. Everything tasted fresh and the brioche and the gougeres were well made. 

Next we had the artichoke with some mussels and the roasted new potatoes with caramelized onions and cheese. Both dishes were excellent. The artichoke and mussels tasted bright and refreshing, and the potatoes were so creamy and comforting. 

Onto the main course now. We had the seared salmon and a couple of small side dishes. They were grilled mushrooms with garlic scapes and grilled zucchini. Again everything was well prepared, the salmon had a crispy skin and the beurre blanc sauce was excellent. The zucchini was grilled to perfection! They were all very tasty. 

The dessert course was amazing. It was a tart with lemon curd and lemon verbena cream. The only complain was I had to share it with my dining partner lol since everything was served family style. 
They also served us some small bite desserts at the end of our meal. That night they served us a couple of French macarons, pate de fruit, and caramels. 

Overall I had a great experience. Portion was on the smaller side, but it was a prix fixe menu after all. I think at $87 per person, it's a bit pricey considering we only had a small portion of protein! But I gave it four stars since all of the dishes were all delicious and well prepared.
author: Sam M.

description:
When you're obsessed over "Chef's Table" but can't afford the more upscale, fine-dining restaurants mainly featured you may find yourself at Atelier Crenn's sister restaurant, Petit Crenn. And by you, I mean ME.

Petit Crenn is located in at one end of the bustling Hayes Valley, further away from the center of the action. Parking may be hard to find right on Hayes, but if you go just a block out, it shouldn't be a problem. There are plenty of bars and boutiques around the area that you can browse before/after your meal. The interior is relatively small and simple: clean, white walls and modern chairs. Lively music is playing in the background, which definitely lifted the mood. It felt classy, but not uptight.

I made a reservation for 5:30PM dinner. There were 3 other parties at that time. We were quickly greeted and shown to our table by the window, which was enjoyable taken the great weather that day. The restaurant soon filled up as our meal progressed. Dinner is a preset menu (gratuity already included), which is shown on the wall, so you'll only get a drink menu. I opted for some wine and my boyfriend a French beer, which both complimented our seafood quite well. It does seem like the menu changes from time to time, but for our particular meal, our eight courses included the following:

*Brioche bread, butter and sea salt: The slices were pretty large, but upon picking it up, you realize how light and airy it is. SO GOOD
*Canapes (hors dourves): This included 3 separate items - Oysters with a mignonette, gougeres, and a couple of fresh turnips with a dollop of dip. The mignonette complimented the oysters well, and they were not too fishy. The gougeres were supurb! The gruyere cream in the middle was not too overwhelmingly cheesy. The turnips were very fresh and refreshing. You can eat the stems too!
*Salad: You can tell everything was very fresh. My boyfriend very much enjoyed the green dressing.
*Octopus Cassoulet: The octopus was cooked well, very tender and not rubbery. To my delight, there were more turnips as well. The fried shallots were also a nice compliment
*Gnocchi a la Parisienne: The gnocchi came out at the same time as the Halibut and the Asparagus. The dish was very beautiful, topped with edible flowers, and also very tasty. The peas and beans are super crisp and fresh. Not the best gnocchi I've ever had, but still good.
*Roasted Alaskan Halibut: A very simple looking dish by itself. The halibut was flaky. The sauce was light enough that it didn't overwhelm the taste of the fish, but flavorful enough to compliment the fish. 
*Asparagus: Another beautiful plate with brioche crumbs and flowers covering the fresh asparagus. Don't forget the aioli!
*Crème Caramel: Hmm...Rhubarb...I've never had any strong feelings about rhubarb so I was a bit skeptical. But it actually turned out really great! It might be my favorite course out of the menu. All the different elements worked really well together in my opinion. 
*Mignardises: Rhubarb flavored gummy, macaron, and caramel. The caramel was definitely my favorite out of the three.

Closer to the end of our meal, I began to realize how full I was. Despite the dishes being small in size, I was surprised to find myself quite stuffed. What I do like is that gratuity is already included. No fussing with calculating at the end of our meal. 

I think many people, after watching The Chef's Table, may be expecting life-changing dining experience from a Dominique Crenn restaurant, but to expect that from Petit Crenn isn't really fair. I'm sure that Atelier would meet that expectation much better. As for Petit Crenn, I see it as a introduction to the fabulousness of Dominique Crenn's talent.
author: Monica V.

description:
Atmosphere: 5/5 (more relaxed and a small) 
Food: 5/5
Wine pairing: 4/5
Service: 5/5

Both my friend really enjoyed this place. We had some of the best seafood and definitely best smoked fish ever here. The gnocchi and grilled fish weren't that surprising or great, but the courses earlier totally made up for it. 

The wine pairing was nice but it didn't pair with the food as well as I've tried in other restaurants. The service was excellent - one of the ladies who brought food out wasn't great tho, she said the ingredients super fast and also had an accent so it was hard to understand her. She also didn't pause to see if we may have any wuedtions. 

Overall though, we stayed for 3+ hours and left totally happy. Would love to try it again soon!
author: Terrie C.

description:
I believe this place does only a tasting menu and for a foodie like me, it is perfect!

Background story: the night of my actual reservation I was flying in from EWR, my flight got so delayed that even though I changed my reservation to last seating I never would have made it. Caroline was the reservation lady and she is awesome!!! She told me I'd get credited the full amount so next time I came I'd be able to use it. Honestly thought I'd never make there as I had to fly out. Luckily the next day I called and she was so sweet and was able to get me a seating at the restaurant at the chef's table which was so cool..right here began the epic customer service.

The restaurant:
Small cute and excellent food. Our waiter who sounded French I think was amazing! Helped us with wine choices and adding supplements which apparently could be shared. That cheese plate was amazing. Creamy, pungent called boho bell. My favorite dish was probably the potatoes with tuna roe. I will probably dream of it. The brioche (not on the menu) was served with this delicious asparagus dish. Freaking perfect pairing. The dessert was light and crunchy and I loved how different it was. Everything here was delicious. If/when I'm back in SF I will definitely go back.

Their menus change weekly but one item at a time typically. In a few months the menu will be super different.
author: Zohra R.

description:
I found out about this restaurant through the Netflix original series of "Chef's Table."  When I checked out the reviews, I was a little skeptical of the food, but regardless, the documentary heightened my curiosity.  My wife made reservations online and the restaurant will send you text messages to remind you of your reservation.  Our reservation was at 6pm and the restaurant was empty, then within 10 minutes or so the restaurant was full.  The restaurant was kind of small, but quaint.  We did the 6 course meal and my wife did the wine pairing  with her meal.   

The dishes came out one at a time.  All the dishes were delicious,  but some dishes stood out more than others.  I was a fan of the gnocchi and the oysters.  Also the dessert was delicious, and I'm usually not big on sweets.  It was a raspberry tart with gelato on the side.

The staff here was really attentive and provided a 5 star service.  We had Aaron and Derek who brought us out our food and also cleaned up after our dishes.  Maryse served the wine and really knew her stuff.  

Yes, this place is pricey, but duh it's a fine dining restaurant, which means the portions will be small.  I was quite surprised that I was actually full after my meal, which I thought I wouldn't be.  After coming here, I'm interested in checking out Atelier Crenn (sister restaurant).  That will be on my next trip.

Parking- I was lucky and scored a spot right in front of the restaurant, but that took some patience finding parking. Let's be real, it's the bay area and parking isn't the greatest, so be prepared to circle around for street parking. There's no valet here.
author: Dora B.

description: Delicious pre-fix meal. Loved that it was all vegetables and seafood; complex, balanced flavored. Plates looked small but the dishes were so tasty and rich that I was too full to finish the meal. The dessert may have been one of the best I've ever had. Since the menu changes daily, I've attached the menu that I had. There are too many ties for my favorite. Careful about the optional add-one. We added the caviar dish which was delicious but small and it was an additional $70. Wine list small but well rounded. The service could not have been better.
author: Naomi K.

description: Terrific flavors and ingredients in a modest, bright windowfront in The Hayes. Refreshingly -sharp & acidic accents, and very good wines by the glass. The smoked lentils with mushrooms in brown butter was the star dish. Unfortunately, too much had that crudo / ceviche / oyster / soupy-raw-fish texture. We found Petit Crenn less quirky, more honest, and maybe even more comfortable than Atelier.
author: Ben G.

description: Best. Meal. Of. My. Life.  Hubby brought me here as a surprise dinner for our first night in San Fran and it was incredible! The service is amazing, the waiters have these beautiful French accents. We sat at the chefs table which I highly recommend, you get to watch how the chefs make the food and ask questions. They do a tasting menu of 6-8 small meals which they switch up every 2 weeks or so. My favorite part was the dessert, we ended up getting an extra one to share. Everything was delicious though, the flavors were so amazing and the presentation was even better! They have their own farm so the ingredients are super fresh.. who knew there were so many edible flowers! They have wines and beers to drink which are pricey (cheapest glass of wine is $16) but great. The restaurant is tiny though so definitely make reservations. It is an expensive meal but so worth it!
author: Xenia P.

description:
Let's begin by saying, the food is obviously amazing. The mushroom tartine is one of my favorite dishes in the city. The salmon/leek eggs Benedict is simply perfect as well.
Dominique Crenn is obviously genius. But the real pleasure about this place is the service. From the host, the sommelier, to the chefs behind the counter - the kindness and hospitality truly make this place special. Dominique knows how to hire a staff. And it makes a difference!
author: Andrea L.

description:
Came here for an early weekday dinner with a coworker. We made reservations for 6pm to sit at the chef's counter. Overall, nothing special, and would not come back. 

I knew that coming to Petit Crenn meant that I would just need to eat what menu they decided to serve that night. Nothing they decided to serve that night blew me away or seemed creative in any way.

Our menu for the night was:
1. Petit Crenn Brioche
2. Canapes (Crudite, gougeres, Kusshi Oyster)
3. Cherry tomato, cucumber, elderflower, ikura salad
4. Zuckerman Farm Potatoes (with aged goat cheese, caramelized onion)
5. King Salmon with sides of confit sweet peppers and Brentwood corn (with porcini mushroom and spring onion)
6. K&J Orchard's Apricot Tart Tatin (with lemon-thyme ice cream, coriander).  

The brioche was the highlight of my meal. The brioche was nicely toasted and served warm. The only thing we got more than 1 of, the entire meal, were these puff things that had cheese in them. The oysters were oysters, nothing special. I could have done without the beets. Nothing was special about them, they were just beets. The cherry tomato salad was good, but didn't blow me away. The potatoes were meh. The aged goat cheese, sadly, didn't add much to the dish. The salmon was cooked medium rare, which was fine. I don't like peppers, so I avoided the confit of sweet peppers. My coworker who did eat the peppers thought that the dish was too pepper-y. It was peppers on peppers on peppers. She thought that they could have added something to change up the flavor. The corn was kind of this pile of blended corn. Meh. The tart was my least favorite course. I didn't feel like the flavors came together well, and I like apricot.

Overall, I would have preferred less courses and just had 3-4 solid courses. I didn't like needing to share everything with my coworker. How awkward would it have been if we weren't coworkers and that we were going out on on a 2nd or 3rd date? The slice of salmon we got was  thin and I definitely could have made a run to Taco Bell or McDonald's afterwards because I left a bit hungry. The service wasn't that great either. We couldn't flag somebody down when we wanted the check or wanted more water. Because we sat at the Chef's table, I became very close with the pole that I needed to sit up against. Would not come back and would not recommend anybody come. For the price and food, there are so many other restaurants in SF can deliver better food at a better price.
author: Carolyn Z.

description: I took my girlfriend out for her birthday to Petit Crenn - we don't go out much so we thought we'd celebrate. First off, I'd like to say the prices are reasonable for their tasting menu ($200 for 2 people). The food was delicious but I had an issue with their deceptive service. Once we ordered the tasting menu, the server asked us if we preferred the cheese or the caviar for one of the plates (the tasting menu included 5). We decided to choose one of each (because we thought it was included) but the waiter never told us we were going to be charged an extra $90 for it. Simply put, it was deceiving. Food was fine, the lack of transparency was not.
author: kevin l.

description:
This is a way overpriced, over-fuss, over-valued restaurant.
The very only nice thing? The service and waiters/waitresses.
They asked an enormous amount of money, they brag all along but then they don't deliver.
Out of the 6 courses we had, only one dish (the swordfish) was really good, elegantly prepared with the expected mastery.
And the main dessert was quite good. 
All, the other dishes? They were good but they all lacked the refinements that you expect from a place with such high claims.
One of the two salads (yes, pretty much they serves you two salads as courses... felt quite a cheap shortcut!), one was a real disaster. All the tastes were all messed up, no inspiration a waste of effort!
The wine list was good but, man, it was outrageously expensive.
Ahh, and for what we paid, I would have expected at least an elegant decor. No. Even the tables and the chairs were quite uncomfortable.
Would I recommend it? If you want to throw money away and eat not that great at all.
author: Luca R.

description:
Went for the tasting menu.The ambiance of the restaurant is quite relaxed and casual. Service was on par. Nothing exceptional though. 
As far as the menu is concerned, I wasn't overwhelmed. I guess I went with high expectations and I was let down. Don't get me wrong, the food is delicious but definitely a couple of dishes were quite salty (especially the snails). 
Small nitpicking remarks: please clean the light bulbs on top of the tables. You can expect customers to pay $100+ and keep the place dusty right above the food you serve. 
The menu add-ons such as truffles and local caviar are a definite turnoff. It's obvious that it's an easy way to grab a couple of dollars from your customers. Either you're convinced of the dish with all the right ingredients or not. 
The desert was delicious and very well presented although the citron tarte slice was on the smaller side.
author: Y B.

description:
KenScale: 8.5/10

The restaurant world today is still dominated by male chefs and that has been one constant criticism of restaurant reviews and rankings around the world. I for one believe that female chefs can do great things just as well as their male counterparts. One chef that has caught my attention is Dominique Crenn who was featured in the Chefs Table series on Netflix. I was enamored with her background and culinary philosophy featured in the documentary and really wanted to try either her haute cuisine establishment Atelier Crenn or the more casual bistro style restaurant Petit Crenn on my next visit to San Francisco. Recently my wife Jun and I traveled to the Bay Area over the Memorial Day weekend to visit the venue in Napa Valley for our wedding in the fall and I figured this trip was a perfect opportunity to visit one of these restaurants. Since we were supposed to meet up with a mutual friend in the city on the day we landed in SF, I decided to place a reservation at Petit Crenn. Overall, there was a lot to like about the dining experience here.

The theme at Petit Crenn is a family-style dinner party. You get a set menu at vegetables and seafood at $87 per person, all in large formats appropriate for sharing. One thing that I always love about restaurants in the Bay Area is the consistent emphasis on the quality of ingredients. When my wife Jun tasted pink scallop crudo, she said she knew this dinner was going to be special. Since Jun doesn't take raw seafood very well unless it is fresh, I felt very comfortable with what will be coming after she remarked that the scallop was quite delicious. The freshness of ingredients kept showing throughout our meal. Artichoke with mussels, baby carrot, fennel and parsley displayed the citrusy flavor that was not unpleasant for a dish at the beginning of the meal. My favorite dish of the night was gnocchi with English peas. Gnocchi is certainly not one of my favorite pasta dishes as I often find the texture of the dumplings to be a bit too soft for me, but the one at Petit Crenn really nailed the texture (having the right amount of firmness to it while still keeping the essence of gnocchi) and the fresh English peas added another dimension to the dish. It really did make me feel like I was eating at a farm with all the ingredients sourced directly from the farm. I felt the seasoning on Spanish mackerel could've been toned down a little bit, but the fish was overall very well cooked, and the side dish of roasted potatoes with local goat cheese and caramelized onions offered a perfect hearty complement to the mackerel. For the dessert, I still can't forget the delightful penny royal crème caramel with rhubarb jam and pistachio. It displayed an awesome complexity of different flavor and texture from different elements all packed in one beautiful plating without being too sweet.

It's always good to book a reservation in advance especially with chef Dominique's growing profile, although I saw that the turnover on a Friday evening (granted it was the start of a long weekend so presumably a lot of people in the city left town) was more frequent than I had thought. The French-centric wine list skews toward more organic, natural and biodynamic varieties (one gripe that I had about Petit Crenn since I don't like those kinds). I really loved the cozy, welcoming vibe of the white décor with menus handwritten on blackboards to give a sense that you're not really dining at a restaurant but are participating in a supper party that is meant for enjoying food together without much fuss. If you want an experience of how a French bistro meets California cuisine is in action, Petit Crenn is a perfect place to be; I hope chef Dominique can keep up the awesome work she has already been doing. After all, especially in this day and age where misogyny is being viewed as tolerable, we need more female voices in the restaurant world.
author: Ken S.

description:
Petit Crenn was big time great! 

We have decided not to dine out often, but when we do, we are highly selective about where we go. We are busy people/parents and have had our fair share of dining out and takeout after spending a decade in NYC and a few years near NOLA and Denver. After awhile, the oils and faux food they use cheapen the experience. I'm happy to do what we do and the risk is that the restaurant we choose for our "mini-vacation" will not be great. This is NOT true of Petit Crenn.

This place is classy, but not stuffy at all. I'm tired of stuffy restaurants (and mediocre service). Our server was completely attentive, can't communicative and not over the top. Although we did not sit near the kitchen, I had a great view and it was fun to see how much care they put into every dish.

The ambiance is exactly how I'd decorate my restaurant or living room: cute, cozy, simple. The lighting was perfect. 

As far as the dishes go, they very with you once you make your reservation that your food preferences. They double check again once you are seated. 

Each dish was perfect. We aren't carb consumers but we purposely didn't state this. The dishes are vegetable and seafood, with a side of brioche or bread here or there. We've had many a meals in France and I have to say, it would be unAmerican not to serve some large pieces of carbs. They looked beautiful, but we stuck with eating just the butter. In a land where real butter is hard to come by, a tablespoon of real butter is amazing. We had the caviar over and omelette. One of the top ten bites of goodness my mouth has ever had. And the swordfish - my husband and I were talking about swordfish the other day and asking if either of us have ever tasted swordfish that's good. We laughed, because swordfish is usually dry and tasteless. Not at Petit Crenn! For a moment it became my favorite fish. But I know not to get too excited because I'll have to go back only there if I don't want to be disappointed.

We never drink wine anymore. It's been two years, we realized, since our last glass. We each had a glass (different) and it perfectly accompanied the meal.
author: Jen L.

description: This place is so so so good. The food is seafood and veggie centric, and you do not miss the meat. Every dish is made with finesse and care. The ambiance is nice but not stuffy. Their French wines are on point. Overall one of my favorite places in sf for fine dining without the hoo-ha. Would definitely go back again.
author: Shirley H.

description: I don't understand people who rate this place low, this is soul food. After eating here, I went home incredibly happy and content. Everything is tasty, salmon dish was superb, roasted potatoes dish gave me more joy than a 500$ bonus at work (except Zucchini, why is it even considered food, I wouldn't feed zucchini to my pet goat if I had one ... but I digress). Definitely get the wine pairing here.
author: Balu V.

description:
Two pieces of advice:

- Make a reservation.
- Believe the hype.

Seriously though, Rus and I had a great experience at Petit Crenn. We were able to sit at the bar and watch everything being prepared too, which I definitely recommend. The chefs were so friendly and frequently checked in to make sure that we were enjoying everything.

We enjoyed:

- Vancouver oysters
- Grilled squid stuffed with shrimp, wild rice, and topped with some baby squids
- Fluke, grilled squash, and gnocchi
- Lil gems salad
- Pear galette

The squid, the fluke, and the lil gems were definitely the stars to me. The squid was served in a delicious soft and they gave us this light, fluffy bread to sop it up with. A lot of the food is prepared over their mega dope open flame grill, but the fluke dish worked the most perfectly with this preparation. It was expertly charred. I also really liked the squash and I'm not usually a fan. The salad was SO GOOD and I know what you're saying, "It's an effing salad." It was a damn good effing salad. The pear galette was tasty. Not too sweet and I loved the crumbly element that they topped it with. It could have used a little bit more ice cream, but I was definitely full by the end of the meal.

Hat's off to Petit Crenn and hoping that I can visit Atelier Crenn soon, too!
author: Carol B.

description: I thought the tasting menu when Bar Crenn just opened was better than what we had last night and a little bit cheaper. The dishes were good but nothing mind blowing and ingredients weren't fancy. I am a bit disappointed as we drove all the way from South Bay up just for the dinner.
author: Jingwei Z.

description:
Dominique Crenn is one bad ass two Michelin starred chef who was named the World's Best Female Chef in 2016 by San Pellegrino. I enjoyed fancy pants Luce and loved Atelier Crenn for Crenn's whimsical, orchestrated courses. But let's be real, unless you wipe your a$$ with Benjamins, who can regularly afford to eat a $300 meal (sans alkie) there?

When Petit Crenn opened last year, I hurriedly made reservations but then cancelled them after perusing the menu and seeing the negative reviews. While Petit Crenn is much more casual with a family-style menu that's based on the dishes Crenn's mother and grandmother cooked, it didn't look very interesting nor enticing. 

Fast forward a year later, I was talking a long stroll during my lunch break and passed by Petit Crenn. I thought it would be good place for my friend and I to have a leisurely, catch-up lunch since it looked rather peaceful. I made reservations but they weren't needed.  

The lunch menu is basically an a la carte version of the prix-fixe dinner menu with the addition of two tartines. Prices ranges from the $8 Josey Baker bread to the $38 Whole Roasted Trout. Beer, cider, and wine only. All prices include gratuity. 

Considering the menu is small (less than 10 items), basic, and has pretty much been the same since they opened, the food was underwhelming and overly salty, as others have mentioned. Some dishes could easily be put together at home with items from the farmer's market. 

While you're essentially paying $9 for an amuse bouche that should be complimentary, the Gougères w/ gruyère cream, pickled shallot gel ($9): http://bit.ly/2eZ5dbq were some damn delicious balls. When you bite into the delicate pastry shell, the warm, salty gruyère just explodes in your mouth. The pickled shallot added a nice contrasting sweet and sourness. It was the best bite we had at lunch.

Our server recommended the Market Tomato Salad w/ chèvre ($13): http://bit.ly/2enYMhp. The tomatoes were nicely ripen and the cheese was fine but this was very ordinary. 

We also ordered the Smoked Trout Tartine w/ caper fromage blanc, pickled shallot ($16): http://bit.ly/2eo1W4A to share. The Josey Baker bread was perfectly crusty with a good chew but the smoked trout was too salty. I know smoked fish is usually salty but this was more salty than smoky. 

I was looking forward to the Petit Crenn Omelette w/ fines herbes, creme fraîche ($15): http://bit.ly/2eo3VG5 but it was a complete let down. While the omelette was fluffy, it was monotonous after two bites. I appreciate simplicity but it felt it needed more than just crème fraîche to liven it up. The worst part of the dish was that some parts of the omelette and bibb lettuce were excessively sprinkled with sea salt flakes. Upon biting into these parts, it gave us that Botox induced surprised face and duck lips look. I found myself trying to pick off the flakes of salt while my friend didn't even bother finishing her half. 

Our bill was brought in this beautiful shell along with orange pâte de fruits: http://bit.ly/2eqv0aj. The orange jelly had an unpleasant sour finish so we went to Smitten afterwards for some ice cream. 

Our server was friendly and not pretentious but they really do the absolute minimum here. After receiving our order, there was no check-in and we had to ask for serving utensils which should have been automatic. Food service was timely and we were finished in about 45 minutes. There was a lady that just stood at the FOH doing nothing. Would have been nice if she pitched in and helped our lone server or thanked customers as they're leaving. But, nada. 

The space is very minimalist with funky white slither dining chairs and wooden tables. I liked the pillow throws which gave a nice coziness with the 80s-90s slow jams playing in the background. Tables are very close to each other so be prepared to breathe onto your neighbors and vice-versa. 

I'm glad I tried Petit Crenn once but the food here is not representative of Crenn's culinary talent. I highly recommend skipping Petit Crenn and going ham at Atelier Crenn. You'll probably end up eating top ramen until your next paycheck like I did but YOLO! Do people still say that?
author: Cherylynn N.

description: I've been a fan of Chef Crenn for awhile, from her appearances on various TV shows to meeting her in person, so I was confident that my first-ever dining experience at one of her restaurants was going to be terrific -- and it was.  Even prior to the dinner, her staff was great about communicating with me regarding food allergies, special occasions, and timing concerns.  Once we got there, we got great seats and some complimentary bubbly to help celebrate our anniversary.  It just got better from there: knowledgeable servers, delicious and creative food, and a simple and beautiful ambiance.  THIS is the new definition of fine, French dining!
author: Carlo A.

description:
We have been here three times, twice for special occasions (anniversary).

While we liked our first experience best -- that was back when they were only do two seatings per night, and when it was only $69pp -- we still come back for a delicious pescatarian menu that always includes yummy oysters, fabulous veggie sides, good bread (I think it is Josey Baker, which is my favorite bread in the whole wide world), not-too-sweet desserts, and a good (if small) wine list. You won't leave this place hungry -- portions are quite decent! -- and most of the time the dishes are well paced (every so often we will get a long wait of around 30 minutes between courses, usually before the entree).

Service is pretty good, could be a bit more attentive and quick. The space is itself is light and bright and welcoming, and I like the neighborhood as well.

Although the price continues to rise (now up to $95pp!), it is still a good value. Dominique Crenn's food is just consistently delicious and well executed, and well-presented, too!
author: Janice T.

description:
We went to Petit Crenn for my wife's birthday on 7/24, and overall we were not impressed. most of the dishes were good, but not memorable
- the seasoning of the cured kampachi was overpowering, so we couldn't taste the fish. 
- the lentils with mushroom had a pleasant smokey taste
- the swordfish was the best dish in the tasting menu, tender and with a light sauce
- the "ragged point" cheese tasted like a run of the mill mountain tomme. Good but nothing special
- the peach Melba was totally dominated by the raspberry sorbet
- and finally the wine pairing was unmemorable, with most wines served too cold to be appreciated. 
We are happy we tried the restaurant, but would not go back. The Atelier Crenn was also on our to do list, but after this experience we crossed it out.
author: Theo F.

description:
I had the most amazing time at Petit Crenn for my birthday.  We decided to splurge and get the tasting menu with the wine paring. AMAZING!!

The food is divine. Each course was so perfectly made.  You try each piece of each dish and they are wonderful and then you put those items together in to the perfect bite and it is something like heaven on your tongue.

The service is awesome, the servers are nice, friendly and know tons about the food and wine and just make you feel comfortable.  

I don't know how they manage to have this beautiful amazing upscale feel with out loosing the cool SF hipness / relaxed Hayes Valley vibe.  

The food is the star here and I am sad my meal had to end.  THANK YOU SO MUCH FOR AN AMAZING BIRTHDAY!
author: Amy P.

description:
Took my sister in law for a belated birthday dinner last week 

Ambiance is energetic with a touch of refinement 
I would say across the board all the dishes we had were done well and satisfying
Only exception was one-quarter of the fluke was over salted but other than that no complaints (as an apology they gave us an extra dessert which I thought was a great little touch)  
Good selection of wines, only one beer choice if I recall correctly

Overall Thoughts

A very memorable dining experience, one that I would recommend to anyone who wants a chance to try Dominque's food
author: Eddie W.

description:
It was fantastic. I was honestly expecting snooty service and over rated food...but i was pleasantly surprised thst it exceeded expectations.
Everything on the menu was great and our server was divine. Be sure to make a reservation and enjoy this great little place
author: Hamm B.

description:
Long pauses between courses. 10 min waits to allow different reservation times to finish together. We finish at the same time as someone with reservation 30 min later.   Unattentive to customers. Did not close door during  cold nights even after 3 tables put on their jackets. 

Food was mostly good. But did not quite enjoy the mushroom dish enough to justify a 45% increase from prix fixe price. 

I am disappointed that they can get the food right but not service which I consider fundamental. Venue was also fine.
author: Gary W.

description:
I had the pleasure of trying almost everything on the menu, while watching the care and attention to detail these gentlemen took to prepare each and every dish.

I literally watched them rearrange herbs with tweezers to be more visually appealing.

They are masters of their craft and that is reflected in their food. It was a true treat and one of the best dining experiences of my life.
author: Lily N.

description:
Maybe my expectations of this place were too high due to Netflix but paying $450 for bones in my fish, uncomfortable chairs, extremely slow service and inattentive waitresses is not fair either for the customer. 
The truffle dish and pear pie were the only two truly memorable and outstanding  dishes but overall I am disappointed...and sad that I chose it for my bday celebration. 
Now I'm hesitant about trying Atelier
author: An C.

description:
Having heard so much about Dominique Crenn from my sister, I was excited to score reservations at one of her spots. This is more casual than Atelier Crenn, but none the cheaper. I was here for lunch so didn't get to try the tasting menu, but pretty much did most of the lunch menu items.

Upon walking in, it was pretty empty since it had just opened I believed. We started off with the cream puffs (I don't know the fancy word for them; judge me) that were injected with foam cheese and fish gel. It sounds totally weird but honestly they were pretty great for a first bite.  Second came the figs, which were okay but they're just figs. I could pick them off my friend's backyard and add some feta on top and it would probably be just as amazing. Half dozen oysters came out and presented on a bed of salt.  I'm not sure what they had in the sauce over them but they were refreshing. Smaller oysters though and not your gigantic ones that often can have an overwhelming ocean taste. I split two entrees; the cured trout tartine and the sole fish. I would definitely get the tartine again as it was salty and a little bit of sour all in one.  The sprinkles of dill was a nice touch to keep the tastebuds interested.  If you like tilapia, the sole fish will be good for you. I just felt like there was too much oil used and that made it much more rich than it should have been. 

Lastly, the dessert menu for lunch was a single option. The paris-brest is like a love child of the donut and custard.  When you get too legends like that combined in one dish, it almost becomes iconic.  And after a quick Google search, apparently it's probably a top five French dessert.  This one had an orange caramel touch to it and I don't regret ordering it all for myself.  

The service itself here is good but the delivery of food can be slow.  Given the portion of the food, it doesn't take much time to eat unless you're a slow eater.  Time between each plate runs about 20-30 minutes and that gets on my nerves when I'm hungry.  However, the staff are attentive and also at the mercy of the kitchen so I'm understanding.  You should prepare to be there for about 2 hours to fully enjoy the experience.
author: Quoc N.

description:
Really disappointed. I don't usually write 1 star review but I have to do it this time. With a high expectation on the "Best Female Chef" by the World's 50 Best organization last year, we found there was a huge lack of touch and soul in the food. For the price they charged, totally not worth it. Completely ruined a well planned date. Bummer!

We tried the tasting menu. Nothing really made us feel like Bretagne. One of us was born and raised in Bretagne (un)fortunately. From the presentation, quality of ingredient to the cooking, everything is at mediocre level. The open kitchen is not really for cooking but warming up food and assembling plates. The smoke reached to an unpleasant level. There are bunch really young cooks behind the chef's counter. Couldn't believe my eyes in a $$$$ place. I saw one young guy was chewing food or gum while cooking.  I took a photo when a girl was preparing the appetizers from a container of mussels with a shocking label 'mussel 3/2' which was 7 days ago. From the seafood served we can tell whoever in charge didn't do a good job picking the high quality stuff. The clams and mussels were so small. Gnocchi was served. Really? Did you claim grandma cooking style?! Maybe the grandma is not from Brittany. The dessert pairing didn't go well. Ganache with sweet white wine, really? The ganache is dense, would prefer to have port. 

Service overall is not bad. I am just disappointed for the gap between what was promoted vs what really it is. when a chef carrying such an authentic Brittany style produced something completely irrelevant, I feel deeply upset. We went there for Dominique Crenn, for Bretagne, for French cuisine... but we didn't get what we thought we would. Paid over $300 for a dinner just to learn the sad truth about Crenn. Will not come back.
author: Shell J.

description: One of my top 5 restaurants experiences ever. 5 course tasting menu. Highlights were the Swordfish, Wild mushrooms (with the lentils) and Gruyere stuff Canapés. It was a comfortable and relaxed atmosphere. Service was excellent and the meal was well paced. It is on the pricier side for us, but we enjoyed thoroughly. We would definitely do it again.
author: Dennis M.

description: Wonderful restaurant. Dom Crenn has created a lovely intimate restaurant with delicious French food. Excellent service, presentation, and flavorful multi-course meal. The chefs are industrious, cooking each course for the entire place and serving the patrons at the same time. Our favorites include the oysters, wood-fired trout, and the gnocchi. Check out my photos for the great dishes and presentation. Thank you Dom!
author: Mikey J.

description: Unimpressed! Food and service were definitely lacking. One of the chefs in the open kitchen was in a bad mood and diners could see how they were treating the other chefs. The dessert was OUT OF THIS WORLD!
author: Matthew A.

description: This meal made me cry. Dominique Crenn is one of my idols and I couldn't get into Atelier Crenn in my short time in SF but Petit Crenn did not disappoint. The butter. The bread. The amuse-bouche. The ambience. Literally every bite was DELICIOUS and perfect. Every detail is well thought out, from the silverware & linens to the layout to how every dish is out together. I will visit SF just to enjoy Dominique Crenn's food again.
author: Angela W.

description: I had a really phenomenal meal here. I enjoy the setting, which is clean and modern but not too uptight. The service was so attentive and lovely. We did the normal prix fixe meal with the wine pairing, which was a tasty treat (all pinks and whites to go with the seafood). I thought the small portions were perfect, and everything was so good. I would absolutely come back.
author: Mari K.

description: Very intimate restaurant to showcase a more casual menu by Chef Crenn. Good service and the food is well thought out and executed.
author: David L.

description:
It feels like this restaurant is trying to play in a league above what it is currently capable to achieve -- or, maybe, pricing its experience well above what the service and the food justifies. 

We arrived five minutes before our reservation time and were told there would be a wait. The space inside is pretty cramped and the host pointed us to the outside bench. After fifteen minutes waiting in the cold, we walked back in and inquired about our table, which was still being set up. The rest of the service was fine but this set the wrong tone to begin with.
