We have been to other restaurants with tasting menus in the same ballpark pricing-wise. The idea behind a tasting menu is that the chef is responsible for crafting the sequence of dishes. As a customer, the expectation is to sit and wait to be served without thinking twice about it. But the experience at Le Petit Crenn was different: to our surprise, several items on the menu were listed as supplemental (for up to an extra ~$70 for a 1oz serving of caviar).

This feels like a very cheap move. We ordered one supplemental item, the cheese. We had ordered the standard wine pairing, but the cheese was not covered by that and we were encouraged to order a separate glass, which is another cheap move in my opinion. The dinner was frankly expensive, even by San Francisco standards. With tip, we ended up with a $450 tab for 2 people. This is fairly pricey for a meal where left feeling like we missed out on the best the restaurant had to offer.

The sheer quantity of food was also disappointing. Other restaurants of the same caliber serve dishes small in size but with numerous fillers and small surprises in between. At le Petit Crenn, what you see on the menu is strictly what you will get, barring for the pricy optional dishes. We left the restaurant hungry despite a pretty deep hole in our pockets.

The food itself was good but nothing exceptional -- all dishes were well executed but without any real surprising or inventive flavors. Of all we ate, the asparagus was probably the best dish we got, but let's be real: this was basically three or four shoots that are well cooked and seasoned. Overall, the food was not par for a $95 price tag.
author: Julien S.

description:
Giving this 3 stars based on getting what you pay for. The food is very good, not amazing. And the price at $95 per person (including service) for the tasting menu is palatable but still a little too much for what you get.  However, the wine list is honestly offensive. Marking up a bottle that retails for $40 to $145 is just ridiculous. And asking $80 to add caviar to the menu is kind of greedy. 
The food itself is very good and fresh. But not exactly creative. A lot of us watched Chef's Table and expected a mind blowing dinner. But in reality it's just a nice simple dinner with very small portions. Would only recommend if you're fine paying $350+ for a dinner for two that is good but leaves you wanting more.
author: Aaron K.

description:
NOTE:
My gf got an email from Petit Crenn pointing out we got the Chef's table menu instead of the regular menu. That's why the courses were "out of order". The posted menu is their regular menu at $79, so if you're wondering what's different about the Chef's table, you get 2 extra courses, but they omit a course. In essence, you're getting an extra dish for an extra $41.

I had a fun time here, but alcohol and good company can always provide that, regardless of venue. My review is based solely on my thoughts of the food and the service. All I wanted was an explanation of the menu and dishes we were getting. I don't think that's too much to ask.

REVIEW:
A group of us had dinner here last Saturday, March 12th at 8:30pm for a girlfriend's birthday. We had a reservation for a party of 6, but someone decided to join us last minute. The restaurant was nice enough to do some rearranging to accommodate our party of 7.

I guess the restaurant has 2 seatings: one at 6pm & another at 8:30pm. Either the 2nd seating was running late or they build in time for a drink as we didn't sit down until 8:50pm.

*NV Zoemie de sousa, brut classique, champagne ($20 glass) ×2
*NV Julien fouet, cremant de loire ($13 glass) ×3
*2015 Petit crenn rose, rootdown wine cellars, amador ($12 glass)

We all ordered a drink at the bar. I got a glass of the crement de loire. It was crisp, refreshing & not too sweet. Perfect for me as I just wanted something bubbly to start the night.

Chef's table ($120 each):
*Kusshi oyster: champagne gelee, preserved meyer lemon
*Gnocchi a la parisienne: hen of the woods mushrooms, meyer lemon
*Butter bean casserole: braised swiss chard, smoked breadcrumbs
*Roasted carrot salad: candied kumquats, hazelnuts, creme fraiche
*Market fish: sauce vierge, crispy garlic
*Little gem salad: caper vinaigrette, golden beets, mimolette tuile
*Chamomile panna cotta: rhubarb, basil, candied seeds
*Mignardises

We started off with an Amuse bouche, or three. The 1st, I believe, was an ahi tuna spoon. The 2nd plate included a puff (I think with lemon?) & the 3rd item was an egg centered snack. It reminded me of the korean rolled egg dish.

The menu above was what they posted on their walls. During our service, they skipped a dish, substituted another & served some stuff out of order. It was really confusing. I thought the reason the restaurant only did 2 seatings was because it was going to be banquet style. Everyone gets the same dish at the same time. But it wasn't that way at all. I felt like we were behind most tables.

My favorite dish on the menu was the oysters. They were very fresh & clean. They never served us the bean course, but we got a scallop dish & a mussel dish instead. The scallops were tasty & tender. The mussels came in a nice broth. I don't like beans so I was glad we didn't get that dish.

For some reason, they had skipped the gnocchi course, so we asked them about it. The first thing I smelled when I walked into the restaurant was the butter from this dish and it smelled delicious. We eventually got it, but I don't know if they meant to serve it out of order or if they forgot to give us the course. My gfs loved the gnocchi but I thought it was too rich. There was nothing to cut into the fattiness.

For me, the rest of the meal went downhill. I'm not a huge fan of cooked carrots. The server ended up taking my plate without asking me if I was done. I had literally only taken two tiny bites. They bring out the market fish to show you before they prepare it. I love fish, so I was looking forward to this dish. Unfortunately, the fish was slightly overcooked & the skin was super salty. So the top of my piece was over seasoned while the bottom was bland.

I didn't really eat the rest of the dishes as I don't like beets or rhubarb much. It was a shame as I love salad! They did offer me a salad without beets, but that was after I went to the restroom & stepped outside. It felt out of place and too late since our server didn't ask when she served the salad course. We did get a small piece of a creamy cheese w/one of our last courses. I was happy we got that as I love cheese.

Bottles:
*NV Zoemie de sousa, brut classique, champagne ($75)
*2014 Dom de champarian, sauvignon blanc, menetou-salon, loire ($47)
*2012 Domaine montvac, adage, grenache, gigondas ($65)
*2012 Castello di verduno, nebbiolo, barbaresco ($88)

We ordered three bottles over the course of our meal. One bottle was enough to get a small pour per person. A few of us ended the night with a Double espresso ($3).

Maybe I came on the wrong night. It's obvious the menu didn't suit my tastes. I was ready to give them 3 stars until I thought about the service. I expected more from a restaurant that charges $120 pp. Serving dishes out of order w/no explanation and the clearing of a full plate w/o asking seems like issues a restaurant of this calibur shouldn't have. I feel bad writing this review, but I don't think Petit Crenn deserves more than 2 stars.
author: Elena N.

description:
Food and presentation was average. I was disappointed. Probably one of the least value and fell flat 3-4 course meals I have had in SF. And we like course dinners and have been to many in SF from mid price to high range like from Aster, Trestle to Quince and Saison. Raw oysters  appetizer, mushroom tart, halibut and lemon dessert plus one 1 wine pairing cost $350 for two.

I did not find the flavors or the ingredients special even though I understand this is suppose to be Bistro French food from Crenn's France.
I was gonna try Atelier Crenn if this was exceptional. But not sure if I will after the experience here.
author: Mit T.

description:
I'm surprised at the amount of low reviews for Petit Crenn as people need to think of this experience as dining at "your hypothetical French Grandma's house". Like any "French" experience as an American, you need to take it with a grain of salt. Even if it's in America!  

While it be pricey, might I remind you that you are eating food from Dominque Crenn. If you don't know who that is might I suggest you look it up. Hint: She has a lot of Michelin stars between her restaurants in San Francisco and New York. In fact, she has more than any other female chef in the grand ol USA. Props to her. 

The menu changes nightly so I'll give you a little perspective into ours. 

Kushi Oysters - Um, yes please.
Anchovies w/ Olive Oil and Lemon - Get in my face. 
Egg Omelette - let's just call em "Air Eggs". 
Escargot in Mushroom Broth - Snails, mushrooms. Like eating the Burgundian floor. 
Noodles and Cheese - ok, it was fancy mac and cheese w breadcrumbs. 
Whole Trout - barely cooked and on the verge of sushi. Radical. 

I'll be back to sit at the bar and do a wine paring with my meal. Boom haters.
author: Benjamin F.

description:
My son bought me dinner tonight for my birthday. 
It was a very special dinner. We enjoyed it a lot. He did the wine pairing. We want to go to Atelier Crenn next. Every course was done perfectly. My least favorite was the slimy part of the Turbot. That's just me. Thought the gnocchi was also little bit over cooked. It was an experience to remember. My son who doesn't like oysters changed his mind after having the oysters tonight. Mind blowing eating experience.  I recommend everyone to go.
author: Julie K.

description:
Delightful. Simple Surroundings showcasing superb food. Dinner last night was delightful. The food is inspired and the service just as it should be! No pretension, nothing over the top, just perfectly executed creative but very approachable cuisine. 

We were there for my birthday and the staff truly made it a special evening. Birthdays may have to come twice a year from now on at least
author: Andy R.

description:
This is a tough review to write... Not because I had a bad experience. It was simply a touch above mediocre, which of course is disappointing since this restaurant is associated with Dominique Crenn. 

I did enjoy the vibe. It's unpretentious. It's a cute, cozy space with tons of light pouring in. I love the menu on the chalkboard. It seemed as though some couples were able to come in without reservations and sit at the bar (which I love to do). 

I have to admit that I am writing this a month after my dinner there and here is one of the issues: I cant remember what we ate!! There was an interesting halibut crudo served on almond butter. There was an incredible sweet corn dish. Maybe something with salmon?? I do remember liking all of the canapes we started with, though once again I couldn't tell you what they were. Anyway, the meal was probably a B+ and I would totally consider coming back; however, I will be crossing off everything else on my list first. 

Side note: We also came on one freakishly warm day in SF. Our table was in the front window and we were SO HOT. My brother in law had to go outside to take a breather halfway through. I understand that this is not the norm and nobody in SF has air conditioning, but this might have affected my enjoyment of the food. I'm a delicate flower, what can I say??
author: Molly S.

description:
Petit Crenn is the pubescent younger sister of her glamorous older sister, Atelier Crenn, the 2 Michelin Star chi chi foodie darling also in San Francisco.  Both are curated by perhaps one of the most celebrated female chefs today, Dominique Crenn. 

Petit Crenn is pushing the long up and coming Hayes Valley foodie scene up Hayes street another block, just past (and next to) Suppenküche. It has a cozy but open design, and a minimalist pure design scheme as mastered by Akemi Tamaribuchi of Subject to Change design. White on white wall hangings, modern white plastic dining chairs, white bulbs on rope lighting. There are perhaps 12 tables por deux on the main wall, and another 3 against the front window, that can be shifted to work for 4, 6. There is also a chef's counter with another 10 seats or so, which can be for walk-ins and a la carte diners from 5 - 7pm Tue - Sat. 

The tables, however intimately arranged (they are close together, so if you have a large bum, sit on the outside or you won't get in and out without spilling your neighbor's wine glass!), are for Prix Fixe 7 course seafood and veggie Chef Menu tasting meals, in 2 seatings Tuesday through Saturday, and Sunday there is only a 6pm seating, none after. This goes for $87/pp, gratuity included. They serve no rezzie lunch from 11 - 2pm. There is a more extensive Chef's Table experience, rezzies required in advance, $200/pp. Their wine pairing adds $65. 

My dining companion, who was generous to offer this meal as an early birthday gift to me, and I had table rezzies, and sat at the far end table, just under the daily Chalkboard menu, so only people on 1 side of us. (See menu pic.) 

We opted for a bottle of Brut Rose bubbly for drinking with our meal. On our second dish, our server accidentally knocked over my flute toward my companion. This seem to shake things up, as we asked for napkins, dry and wet, as some splashing was on clothing. The staff seemed to rotate out our server with others to settle their collective nerves, which you would think they would try to provide more service, rather than stepping back a bit with less after the faux pas. But they did give us another replacement glass from another Rose. Fortunately, the glass didn't break. Such is the tight quarters, even on the end table. 

Petit Crenn has a decent wine selection for the nature of the food and venue size. There are a dozen By-The-Glass offerings from $13 - $20, including bubbly. In fact, there are perhaps 15 different bottles of Champagne (9) or Sparkling Wine (5) offered, the delineation per the treaty of Versailles.  There are about a dozen+ of each Red and White wines, too, as well as beer. 

The food itself was good for what you are paying. It is based on Dominique's culinary memories from her grandmother's cooking in Brittany, France. So it is a little more casual and Bistro like than a Michelin place. Sort of like the younger sister still living at home, rather than her sophisticated older sister, who has moved to the bright lights and big city.  

See photos for each dish.
author: Wanugee N.

description: Petit Crenn is a small and cool place, the quality of the food is amazing, it's probably not a place you're going to hit often since it's pricey but if you are into seafood and want to celebrate, this is a nice place to  go. We took the tasting menu and most expensive wine pairing option to celebrate my birthday and didn't regret it. Service was very nice and cozy ambiance.
author: Julien S.

description:
We had a great dinner here starting at 6pm and ending at 9pm. The staff were very attentive and friendly. The food was filling and delicious. I appreciate that they source from local farms and produce dishes using the highest quality, organic ingredients. The color and flavor of the food popped. They even have organic and biodynamic wines on the menu. The interior design in minimalist, white, modern, bright and fresh feeling. I feel that this makes the appearance of the food stand out like a work of art. We thank the head chef for coming out to talk about the farms they have relationships with... Give this smart casual eatery a try - and watch Dominique Crenn on Season 2 of Chef's Table (Netflix) before you do! 

Sarah
author: Sarah H.

description: Cozy, romantic atmosphere with thought out creative seasonal menu.  A highly recommended restaurant to enjoy delicious food with great technique execution.
author: Rodrigo M.

description: Man, I wanted to like this place. This seems like it should be right in my wheelhouse but the chefs, which from my kitchen view seat seemed for be new, were consistently in the weeds and heavy-handed with the salt. The first couple courses were adapted to be gluten-free for my wife and about midway through the menu they forgot and brought out food that we identified as having gluten which then took longer to adapt and reserve. Expected better attention to detail.
author: Joseph M.

description:
We had a Saturday brunch here for four people, three adults one child. The service was a bit slow and we seemed to have multiple waiters. The menu was not as communicative, or explicit or as descriptive as I would like. For example, I like to know when a dish is Vegetarian, just a simple "V" next to the dish would do, esp. when you have waiters with limited English. 

I had the charred peaches; the peaches themselves were excellent but for some reason I didn't care for the intensely goaty goat cheese with the peaches despite the fact that I love goat cheese. 

I then had half a mushroom tartine and half a trout tartine, both were good but not really anything extraordinary. 

We ordered pastries for the table mainly for the child with us and struggled to get the descriptions whereby to choose 3 out of 5. I laughed inside and got worried all at the same time when the waiter said one of the pastries had escargot on it...I thought well that doesn't seem likely so I'm going to let that one slide...it turned out to be a snail pastry which in France is probably called escargot but I'm not sure how the description of the there is escargot "on" it came about. We asked for the pastries to come out, for the child, before the other food but they didn't bring the pastries until they brought the rest of the food. 

I also ordered a bottle of sparkling water. Later that night I see a charge for $14 for water and I'm thinking wow that is an expensive bottle of water. Then I see it was for two bottles, Um...hello...I only ordered ONE BOTTLE. Just because I order one bottle doesn't mean you just keep bringing bottles and pouring bottled waters endlessly without even asking me if I'd like another bottle! Plus only three of us were drinking bottled water. 

Also the receipt charged me for the "Mission Fig" instead of the peaches...I guess they were the same price point or something, but I've no idea...I just thought it was a mistake, but let it go without question. 

In the end we couldn't finish all the pastries so I asked for a to-go box...but instead of getting the box as I had asked for, the pastries themselves were suddenly whisked away.

I prefer to box my own food but thought oh well. I later go to the restroom and ask about the pastries to make sure they had understood what I wanted and I was told the pastries were there in back and we be brought out later. After the bill was signed and we were ready to leave still no pastries....which mystified me cuz it was the second restaurant in San Fransisco to keep to-go portions of food from us...so I actually had to send my partner to go ask for them. 

Later in the park my partner and I had the pastries and they were quite good but there were no napkins or knifes or anything...so they ended up being finger food. 

All in all some major improvements with service timings and requests need to be worked on.
author: Lara K.

description:
Cute little restaurant in Hayes Valley! Came for brunch with my family and we tried everything on the menu. Our favorites were the quiche, crepe, trout and mushroom tartine. The pastries were pretty good as well, but some of them were a little too sweet for my liking. 

Bonus: tip is included in the menu price! Overall, it was really worth it. I'd come back!
author: Rachel L.

description: Can't remember what I ordered but it was unmemorable... is that sentence way too redundant? Well, that's how meh it was. All you need to know it's not even close to Atelier Crenn.
author: Betty T.

description:
Simply stated, Petit Crenn was just not special.  Nothing about the food made us use adjectives that would encourage us to share with friends or return to give it another try.  It just wasn't anything special.  The room was crisp and clean and a there was a very pleasant crowd--really nice vibe.  Service was good other than it taking about 15 minutes to get a very simple cup of hot water with lemon.  

The Prix Fix menu for the evening was as follows:

1. Petit Crenn brioche
2. Radishes and puff pastries
3. Cherry tomatoes, cucumber and elderflower
4. Zuckerman Farm potatoes, goat cheese, caramelized onions
5. Sea bass with sides of confit sweet peppers and Brentwood corn with porcini mushrooms 
    and spring onions
6. Apricot and blueberry creme brûlée with lemon ice cream

Our highlights were the brioche with delicious butter and the creme brûlée, both were very, very good.  The sea bass was prepared nicely, with crispy skin. Otherwise, just ok.

Again, there is nothing wrong with the food or the service it is simply lackluster.
author: Jeff P.

description:
I would have given a lower 3-3.5 stars had it not been for the spot on food and kitchen working at their best and more.
Our server was aloof, unhelpful at times and just didn't seem to be with/interested in our group of 4. Not sure if this was due to us seeming to be the only dressed up diners, not in shorts and shirts showing tattoos everywhere, but paying $150/person incl wine and gratuity is not a cheap meal and doesn't deserve to be treated as such. It was spot on value, and I get the whole relaxed dining and server outlook, but last nights result was lacking.
I hope this spurs a little front of house training because the kitchen staff and food deserved the additional gratuity we added.
author: Paul D.

description:
It's a cool nice "neighborhoody" spot. I use quotations because it's not a total comfort spot because there is still an air of elegance but yet atmosphere of hustle and bustle.  There are two seatings so everyone is getting served the same thing at the same time.

This is the same chef as Atelier Crenn (one of the best dining experiences in SF in my opinion) and she's made this a much homier feel.

If you don't eat seafood, this isn't the place for you because the substitution for the fish (main dish) is a small plate of mushrooms.  Just a warning.  It should be labeled as a seafood restaurant.

The best part of the meal was probably the little puff pastry with gruyere cheese and pickled shallot on it. I could eat a dozen of those little things.

Meal started with a huge oyster (I got a little piece of omelette instead).

Then a squash soup that was tasty with uni (i got brussel sprouts instead).

Side dishes of sunchoke mash and brussel sprouts on the stalk came out - very tasty.  I had no idea sunchoke tastes that good.

Fish was raw and didn't come off the bone. I was a little surprised the fish was so raw. But when I looked at our neighbors, their fish was perfectly pink and cooked well.  They offer to debone the fish for you at the table (I don't know why you wouldn't say yes!) and they do a good job in general. I think our fish was just too raw.

Timanoix cheese was great.  Never had this kind of cheese and I don't normally like cheese, but this was a highlight.  But I have no idea how to find it again.  It was served on the side of a really bitter salad.

Salted caramel is well, they do it really well!

I wish I could give it more stars but it wasn't an enjoyable meal for me, but it's worth a shot.  Oh they have a chef's tasting for 6 people also that gets slightly different food - the big difference we saw was a huge octopus.

Main reasons why it's not for me:
- hustle and bustle of the assembly line service and overall rushed feeling
- tightly squeezed tables make the dining room feel like you're sitting on your neighbors
- substitution for seafood was limited - I was hungry after nibbling on that little plate of mushrooms. 
- our trout was cooked raw and deboned extremely messily

Why it's worth a try:
- I love Atelier Crenn
- See ^^ but don't feel like an extravagant meal all the time
- It looks like the seafood is probably good
- Our trout was cooked poorly (or not cooked) but it looked like other fish were actually cooked well
- Booking on Resy is easy and awesome.
author: Traci H.

description:
Horrid cancellation policy. We wanted to celebrate my birthday and made a reservation weeks in advance after enjoying a brunch there around a year back. We ended up with a sick child, so I tried to cancel 36 hours before and they wouldn't budge from their 48 hour cancellation policy with a costly $95 fee attached. Fine, I said. We will try to make it, hoping my child would feel better and we could go. That didn't happen. Tried to cancel again and explained the situation, but they were very strict and unfriendly - find someone to replace you, or we will charge $95 per person. Tried but couldn't find a last minute replacement. And then they have the nerve to tell me to text them and let them know if I cant find anyone to replace us - for what?! So they can take my money AND fill up our two spots, and make double? 
I understand calculation policies are meant to prevent no shows from careless people, but this is not the situation. 
Not considerate, not friendly, not welcoming, and the last request is just plain rude. I'm sure in any case they can find a wall- in to take the spot and cover for lost expenses. Will not be returning here.
author: S F.

description: Enjoyed a lovely Saturday lunch. A la carte menu. Service right on. Food a delight. Wine & bubbles nice. Def return.
author: Brian B.

description: Had a really memorable meal at Petit Crenn recently - what a breath of fresh air compared to its sister restaurant, Atelier Crenn (sorry but had a bad experience at AC)! The night I dined at Petit Crenn, every dish tasted bright, fresh and seasoned perfectly. Service was spot on and the overall feeling of the restaurant is welcoming, open and modern. Can't wait to go back!
author: Kalani K.

description: Buttergasm! I can't stop thinking about our brunch here. The omelette while deceivingly simple sounding, is nothing short of mind blowing. I regret not ordering a baguette to sop up all the sauces. I also wish I sat at the bar so I could watch the chef techniques.  Merci Chef!
author: Andrea N.

description:
We had a perfectly nice brunch at Petit Crenn, but it didn't meet the high expectations I had for one of Chef Crenn's restaurants. Our experience was good, but not great, and we probably won't be back because it didn't match the high price point (and we're willing to pay a lot when it's worth it). 

The high points of our meal were the nicely attentive service and the fantastic pastries. We ordered one of each pastry and they were all excellent. The ambiance was also great - light, modern and airy with an open kitchen. Our entrees were well executed and most of us were happy with what we chose, but we weren't blown away. 

Maybe I shouldn't expect so much for this price point in the San Francisco market, but it just wasn't the amazing food experience I expected. The only thing memorable was the time spent with friends in a beautiful space, with service we appreciated and delicious pastries. I would not go out of my way to dine here again.
author: Julie C.

description: Bright and cheery atmosphere, but not comparable to the other expensive restaurant in Haze Valley, Jardiniere.  Only two out of five dishes were noteworthy.  All the courses were tiny and barely a few bites.  Wine was marked up considerably, but the selection was extensive.   My high expectations went unfulfilled.
author: Peter S.

description: I loved this spot - I came here for my birthday. Each course was fantastic, we had oysters, wonderful rich brioche, some cured fish, creamy lentils with morel mushrooms, and swordfish. I was perfectly full without adding any of the supplements to the tasting menu, although they sounded very tempting. The servers were very attentive and explained each course. I definitely want to come back one day!
author: Laura A.

description: Aesthetically pleasing as it Tastes! Super cute and casual interior. Service was great! Left very satisfied
author: MaiMoua X.

description: Had our anniversary dinner here. The food was great - innovative ingradiens, colorful flavors. We had the daily special mussels which was a big surprise,  so fresh and tasty!
author: April W.

description:
I am a huge fan of Dominique so when I was visiting my sister I thought we could for for a quick lunch!  Crystal the Hostess was very sweet as well as the other gentlemen (didn't catch his name) and it was pretty slow when we got there so it worked out perfectly.  This is what we had, not in order

1/2 dozen Kumamoto oysters with a shallot mignonette- delicious and so fresh 
Gougères, Gruyère cream,  pickled shallot gel- I love gougères but these fell short of anything special unfortunately maybe I am spoiled from Trois Mec and Chef Ludo
Little gem salad,  green garlic, Comte - the cheese gave it an extra creaminess, delicious
Mushroom tartine, Espellette aioli, pickles and crispy garlic- the pickles and mushroom combination was soooo delicious I could eat these all day!
Mt. Lassen trout fillet, radish butter with sauce Vièrge-  maybe I wasn't in the mood for fish but was my least favorite, the frise was a bit old like they had to pick out the green slimey parts and I found aphids vacationing in the crevices 

I don't like complaining to the staff as I know things happen in the kitchen but for an establishment such as this the small details are the most important.

Overall,  I am glad I experienced Petite Crenn, would I go back?  Probably not, do I want to try Atelier Crenn?  Maybe, just glad I didn't have to fork over some major cash only to be disappointed.  Not saying the comparison is equal but if they can't get the simple plates without Dominique overseeing then I hope for everyone sake and wallet that she is with staff at Atelier Crenn.
author: Je J.

description:
What a delightful dinner!

We went for a 8:30 seating. Apparently they only have 2 seatings per night. It was really fun, since all the tables start and finish at similar times, we get to see the kitchen bring out their huge fish to show us what we were going to eat as our entree. 

This place is French country style, so you really feel like you're visiting someone and eating a meal with a family. There's an oyster appetizer, a first course of pan-fried gnocchi, and then three things together, the main dish (for us it's the big fish that I forget the name of), a smoked vegetable that is wonderfully bitter and sour with amazing flavor, and baked white beans. Then it ends with a salad, and a dessert. We shared a wine pairing which turned out to be quite good also. 

As you see from what I described, the food isn't fancy. But it tasted very home-style, with top-notch cooking skills, so it's extremely delicious for this style of food. I can see this is sort of an experiment for Chef Crenn, and it seems from the other reviews that people either love it or hate it. I wouldn't compare it to a more "standard" tasting menu since the food isn't as delicate. 

My only complaint is that I really didn't like the dessert we had that day. Otherwise, it was a wonderful evening.
author: Wendy K.

description:
Dominique Crenn kills it again, albeit at a much more affordable price for the common human :) Disclaimer -- this review is actually a very delayed review on my part (sorry!) but actually for Crenn's NYE dinner special. The SO and I came to celebrate our NYE with one of my favorite chefs. We were fairly pleased with our experience and very much enjoyed the quality of the food. When we came back in January, it was clear that the kitchen staff still had a lot they needed to figure out about their own chemistry (will explain later), but in general, given the price and the amount of food we had, it was a great experience. 

Like I said, this is a NYE dinner review, so the format of the dinner was probably very different than Petit Crenn proper -- I'm excited to come back on a normal day to try out what the actual experience is like since it seems like there is quite a multitude of review about the quality of that experience. The menu for the night was:

Little gem salad with dill dressing, house-made pickles and fried oysters
Gougeres with gruyere and pickled shallot jelly
St. Simmon Oysters with caviar 
Gnocchi
Hen of the wood
Onion bouillon
Celery root mash
Lobster 
+apple panna cotta dessert with chocolate and cream and mignardises

I don't know if there is any point in getting into too much details on each dish given that this was a special menu, so here are my high level takeaways. We sat at the bar so it was really interesting to watch the team's dynamic:

-Everything was good. You're definitely paying for that Crenn standard when you come to a place like this

-What was a little disconcerting about my experience was watching them grill our lobster over the flame, and then taking it off, and then while quality checking, realizing that it wasn't cooked and watching them just touch the lobster and put it back onto the flames. Glad they caught it, but no one wants to watch their apparently not cooked food be recooked in front of their own eyes!

-The soup was served out in two different kinds of containers--we noticed a pivot in serving style midway. There was also a weird dynamic between the expeditor and the rest of the team that I think needs to get sorted out so these types of miscommunications and changes don't happen in the middle of service

So overall, not much to complain about from a tastiness standpoint. It's not Atelier Crenn, but it's also have the price of that, so what did you expect? I definitely don't think it's deserving of its poor ratings so far. Maybe the communal normal style just doesn't work for people? I'm really not sure what people are upset about. 

tldr; great home-y food, tastes delicious, though restaurant execution and cohesion could use some work
author: Jasmine X.

description:
Artful food and elegant atmosphere! I was on a quest to try Dominique Crenn's French cuisine after watching Chef's Table - an unmissable food documentary series on Netflix. 

I walked into Petit Crenn (on a suburban street in Hayes Valley) with no booking, but was promptly shown to a seat at the bar - there is a separate chef's corner menu, and not the same one as the main menu on the chalkboard (which meant, no salmon for me!)

The service was friendly and genuine, I was talked through the menu and the waiter pointed out the gluten free options. Turns out, there is a lot! Like the woodfired gluten free bread with house churned butter - a m a z i n g, chewy and dense with nuts and charred bits. 

I jumped at the chance to try buckwheat gnocchi with charred corn broth, fava beans and flowering coriander. The gnocchi is piped and boiled to order (in rhythmic style) and the seasonality of the flavours is profound. Next up was fulfilling my fish cravings with pan seared dorade, roasted sunchokes (like potatoey artichoke), thinly sliced corn 'steaks' and fermented scallion relish. Presented like art, and tasted like a well-balanced seafood and vegetable dish. 

Dessert was salty coconut custard that made use of my favourite berry and the taste of Californian summer - blackberries! I liked the textural touch of granola. 

I was dining solo and planned to read a book - but found watching sitting at the bar and watching the chef's cook was much more interesting! Petit Crenn's sister Atelier Crenn has two Michelin stars, but Petit Crenn certainly feels like you're eating thoughtful and elevated cuisine in a classy setting.
author: Andjelka J.

description:
What can I say?I've been following chef Crenn around San Francisco for a while now. Since day 1 at Luce at the Intercontinental, many years of Atelier and now Petit Crenn, So you could say there is some bias here :)

Not the lush money forward hotel restaurant that is Luce, nor the focused fine dining workshop that is Atelier, Petit focuses on the simple but delicious elements of seaside life in Brittany, The focus is the bounty of the sea and vegetables of the land. For now it's a 2 seating set menu for dinner but at a future time breakfast and lunch bites will be available from an a la carte perspective. 

The soft opening menu went as follows:

-Classic radishes and butter
-Gougeres filled with cheese 
-Oysters with smoked tomato gelee, sea bean
-Escargot in mushroom broth, chantrelle, buckwheat crisp
-Classic omelet with cheese and fine herbs
-Grilled cauliflower gratin, mournay, smoked bread crumbs
-Grilled cabbage, crispy onions, grilled leeks vinaigrette
-Whole fire roasted stuffed trout,  cider vinaigrette
-Salad of little gems, anchovy caper sauce, heirloom tomato
-Fromage from Breagne
-Valencia orange mousse, lemon granite
-Brittany cookies and caramels

Everything was fabulous and very filling. The bowl of cauliflower gratin could have been a meal in itself. But as a family style meal shared across many diners it was interactive and a great way to have conversations with your neighboring diners. Service is still getting its foothold but we were well taken care of. the space is sleek yet somewhat rustic with the main shades of white throughout. Minimalist art and subtle aesthetic touches. Certainly cant wait to try the set menus as they evolve and definitely looking forward to what the other mealtimes will offer. A great start!
author: Kim N.

description:
I like the space, concept, and mixture of prix fixe tables and drop-in bar seating. We had some a la carte items at the bar. Overall, not great value for the money. Don't see myself coming back

Front of house:
Front of house staff was rather inattentive. When I walked in I just stood there 3 full minutes making eye contact with the main Host while he chatted and finished his drink before coming over to seat me for my reservation.  The same FOH dude mixed up the bill (and charged them no less) of two different parties and took over 20 minutes to rectify and only offered 10% comp, causing a bit of a stir at the chef's counter. I had to flag down the waitress (this is a tiny restaurant mind you) after sitting at the counter for over 7 minutes to ask if we could order drinks and food.

Back of house / Food:
The cook behind the counter was audibly talking about how hungover she was. I get it's supposed to be a bit of a peek behind the curtain having an open set up like that, but it felt unprofessional. 

Food-wise, the gnocchi was pretty good, the pea dish and dessert we had were both rather bland. Endive salad was good, but over seasoned for sure. The fish in brown butter felt uninspired and tasted like something I could easily make at home (I know "homey" is the intended vibe but should be more up-leveled at this price point).

They also need to do some touch-up painting from where they caught the place on fire not too long ago.

All in all, it felt like a promising restaurant lacking in taste, value, and some adult supervision.
author: Andrew H.

description:
Went for my wife's birthday while we were visiting SF, and we had a great time! I would totally recommend opting for the wine pairing - adds some fun drinks to the already wonderful meal.

The restaurant is small (only around 20 seats) in what must have been an old storefront. Music is played on the loud side, but it takes away a lot of the stuffiness that can fill a price fix place like this. Conversations were nice and loud, and everyone seemed to be enjoying themselves (my wife and myself included). Service was prompt without us feeling rushed, although tables are located relatively close together, so I found myself with a waiter's bum in my face as he dropped dished off at our neighboring table - not ideal for a $300+ dinner.

Not being a huge foodie, I was totally impressed by the meal: dishes were well-varied, surprisingly filling, and presentation was pretty. I have a tough time justifying such an expensive meal, but it really was terrific!
author: Nick D.

description:
Before coming over to San Francisco, I had to make reservations for at least one fun brunch place and one proper dinner destination. I always have to have at least one proper dinner whenever I go on vacation because let's be real, if you don't do fine dining, are you really living? This was a prix fixe dinner and service was included. If you go to their website it tells you that you do not have to leave gratuity which is very nice. I learned about this after being unsuccessful in getting a reservation at Atelier Crenn. Since I failed to secure the Michelin star rezzies, I had to come to it's sister restaurant.

Our uber driver got lost from Union Square coming to this part of town and then there was SF traffic. The combo was making my blood boil to temperatures where even mercury would melt (356.7°C, in case you were curious). Finally upon entering the restaurant, we were 13 minutes late to our reservation, our names were checked off on the list in the little black book and we were told to sit at the bar from where we had the view of the live show. We opted for the wine pairing and it was a little underwhelming. Usually I get a bottle or two and have never opted for a wine pairing but the pour just sorta left me astonished, and secondly the lady serving was not very polite. While she was serving one of the bottles she said something like oh if you've ever had that wine then you'd know what I'm talking about in an almost condescending tone. Like ok, fine, we probably haven't had that wine or any of the wines that you are serving but you should not be talking to your customers like that. Otherwise the whole experience was very enchanting and engaging.

The kitchen staff was working together like the arms of a clock, in perfect harmony. It was like watching a symphony perform with the head chef being the conductor. I won't go into the details of the food as everything was pretty much phenomenal but the only thing that left me wanting a little something more was the dessert. It was a corn based dessert with corn ice cream and just tasted too sweet to me. The macadamia nuts in there were my favorite part. Overall, this was one of the most fun, relaxed, and uplifting experiences I had in SF.
author: Zain R.

description: Simply amazing. The menu we got was brand new (it was their first day of cooking this menu) and it was perfect, so I can't imagine how much better it would be as chefs get more experienced over time! It's a bit pricey but service is included and the chef and servers are great. I would recommend making a reservation at "chef counter" so you can see how they prepare the meals and even some occasional conversation.
author: Winson S.

description:
Disappointing .... was expecting the wow factor but I've had better for less $$$.
7 course, everyone gets the same selections. The raw and cooked appetizer at beginning. It would have been better with just the cooked beets and myer lemon yogurt ....the radishes had no place there. The Boulibase only had mussels and clams, gee I thought it was a seafood stew Seafood.
The Gnocchi with mushrooms spot on. The Turbot w Burre  blanc
was fatty fish w fatty sauce. The endive salad with green garlic dressing was over salted and creamy.  Chocolate ganache dessert was good. There's no coffee Or espresso just dessert wine.
I don't think Dominique Crenn had much to do with this meal or menu.... to bad.
author: Tom P.

description:
3.5 stars for an upscale lunch experience, that didn't quite hit my expectations given their sister restaurant has 2 Michelin stars. Chic place with a minimalist menu, highly recommend the cheese puffs!

- Salad - 3.5 stars: good and refreshing
- Cheese puffs - 5 stars: Incredible - but so small
- Bread - Tartine? But they charged us for it without asking.
- Gnocchi - 3.5 stars: Very buttery, too mushy.
- Mushroom toast - 1 star: Beautiful, but tasted vinegary - dislike.
author: Jess C.

description:
We had an amazing dinner here tonight. The staff were friendly and attentive, pacing the meal perfectly -- at one point we mentioned to ourselves that we should take more time savor each dish, and without missing a beat they slowed down and gave us more time between courses. The highlight of course is the food. We did the tasting menu, and started with an amazing bite of oyster flavored with ... I don't know, Magic? The following salad with salmon roe was bursting with fresh flavor. A wild mushroom tart was the tastiest thing I've eaten on quite some time. The main was a good sized price of really fresh halibut, which when compared to everything else simple. The cotton tart at the end was a perfect ending. 

I'm not sure why here are some negative reviews here. Sure, it's expensive, but it's also better quality and better put together than any meal I've had in SF, not to mention more original. Would definitely come back here for special occasions.
author: Brigitte H.

description: Obviously created by a talented chef, but we left feeling slightly underwhelmed, and hungry.
author: Makinzie C.

description:
Do you enjoy paying $87 per person for mediocre seafood? Do you also particularly enjoy stinking of smoke and the dockside after dinner? If so this is the place for you! Not me though. I won't be back even if you pay me

Supposedly this restaurant is Breton cuisine. I'd had Queen Amman before so I figured it could be decent and I was dismayed to learn how utterly wrong I could be. And this is supposedly the best female chef in 2016 and a holder of Michelin stars! Maybe she only got that award because of the Netflix documentary about her. I can't imagine that someone ate here and decided to award her anything

The squid was okay. Just okay. The only really edible thing on the fixed menu and even then I'm pretty certain the cook got a little too eager with the salt. And by a little too eager I mean it was the saltiest squid I've ever eaten

Thankfully I had a pastry at the end to wash the taste out of my mouth but even that was a disappointment. Ended up going for Taco Bell late at night because I wanted some comparatively decent food. 

Don't bother coming here. If you want a better experience, make a campfire, have some fish sticks and throw $87 in for tinder.
author: Ilya V.

description:
If you are a foodie at all you have likely seen the Netflix series Chefs Table. It's a beautifully filmed documentary style interview of prominent chefs from around the world. When my daughter invited me to SFO for the weekend, I immediately made a reservation for Petit Crenn, a restaurant of one of the Chefs featured on the series. IT WAS INCREDIBLE! Even a simple brunch was fantastically prepared.  This experience began with the most heavenly crispy, intensely buttery chocolate croissant.  There must have been 10,000 layers, all of which ended up on my lips as I was devouring every bite.  Just when you thought there couldn't have been any more buttery goodness, the hit of dark chocolate invaded my palate.  As the chocolate melted in my mouth, I knew this meal was going to be wonderful.
 The quiche was next.  The combination of leeks and chevre nestled in an impossibly flaky crust was a true joy to eat. Each bite was soft and full of flavor.    I also ordered a mushroom tartine, a French version of an open-faced sandwich.  This masterfully designed dish was simple, yet full of amazing depth of flavor.  From the tender mushrooms to the rich tarragon sauce, each bite was a mouth full of silky perfection.  Although I ate alone, the service couldn't  have been better.  I highly recommend this experience if you ever get to SFO.  Make reservations, or you will likely be turned away due to its full booking.
author: Fuhrerfoodie ..

description: I've been wanting to try a Crenn establishment for a while. This trip I booked lunch at Petit Crenn. The gougeres were excellent. Warm cheese melts into your mouth. The toasted bread and butter was great though a bit pricey. The chicories were a nice salad. I had the mushroom Tartine which was great, for a main.
author: J. Karim A.

description: We went here after watching an opera. Its a small restaurant...cozy , casual and with a friendly atmosphere. Tasting menu is at $95 that includes tip. Every dish was tasty and perfectly executed. We will surely return.
author: Elly G.

description:
Was so excited to try Dominique Crenn's new restaurant, and it didn't disappoint. I loved Atelier Crenn so couldn't wait to try this new sister restaurant with a different concept. Set menu for $75 with a communal dining experience where you will most be sharing some dishes with people at the same table unless you book your reservation for party of 4+ and the table only fit that many people.
Two seating of dinner at 6pm and 8:30pm so it's best to arrive on time to arrive nice pacing of food and adequate time to enjoy the food. Walk-ins are taken at 5pm and you get seated at the counter.

My husband and I had a 6pm reservation and arrived on time, waited for our other two friends whom had requested to be seated with us. They were a bit late so we had an extra cheese course before they arrived.  Dinner for us ended at 8:15pm where most of the other 6pm tables left and staff are busy preparing settings for the 8:30pm seating. 

Food/Drinks- The menu changes so I'm not going to go into detail on each item. My favorite items that night were the oysters (I love oysters) and whole trout. Other dishes were solid and they nicely accommodated some for no dairy. However, for the cheese course with salad, they did not offer me a substitute and no substitute for the nibbles/treats of caramel and chocolates at the end either. It would have been nice to also get something rather than watching others at the table slowly savor those treats. Wine was tasty, good selection.

Ambiance/Decor- brightly lit and nicely decorated yet simple. Two large menus of the day posted on the walls. Seating a by the wall could be a bit cozy especially if you have a large coat or purse as I didn't see any place to store them but by my side.

Service/Staff- professional, I wouldn't say they were
Super friendly, but nice enough. Quite attentive as they came to check on us multiple times for drinks while we waited for our friends. Dishes came right away one after an other. One waitstaff brought me the dessert with dairy, but caught himself right after he set it down in front of me. He returned with my non-dairy dessert a bit later. 

Overall, good place for dinner to have solid/good food and a new dining experience if you sit/share dishes with strangers, which could be fun! Portions are reasonable and I was quite stuffed so boxed part of the trout home to fit in other courses into my tummy. I was already happy before I had any food because I got to shake hands with Dominique. She's so cool! ;)
author: Iris H.

description:
I was there last Saturday  and didn't find the place convincing. The idea is to give a taste of the real Atelier Crenn but in a more affordable and informal way. only option is tasting menu, at $100 including tip and tax and mid range wine is $100-150 per bottle. For us bill ended up at $150 per head. That's the concept. Not bad. Several problems with execution. 
- The room itself looks like one of those new frozen yogurt shop hastily repainted and furnished. We understand the minimalist idea but this looks darn cheap. 
- out of the 6 courses of the menu, only 2 were up to expectations the fish and an amazing escargot crepe. The rest (amuse bouche, asparagus, fromage blanc and lemon tort) was basic except for the fromage blanc that was sad
- we may have been unlucky but our main waitress, a nose-ringed snooty woman, seemed mainly interested in upselling us, showing her disapproval when we declined to take the small $80 each caviar supplement for caviar and we asked to share the wine pairing option (5 glasses). 

Very honestly this place feels like they're leveraging the Atelier's reputation to make a quick buck, using old up selling tricks and pushy personnel incompatible with the reputation. 

Recommendations to restaurant: let the customers decide the tip (at the moment already included following the (bad) French custom - waiters only way to increase revenue is to sell more not have better service ), work on the decor, reduce the number of courses and increase consistency, don't offer supplements as expensive as the menu. Recommendation to diner: skip until above is fixed.
author: Emmanuel R.

description: A really enjoyable first dinner in San Francisco after relocating here. The service was excellent and each dish of the tasting menu was beautiful. Perfect location to bring friends or family for a special occasion.
author: Josh M.

description:
What a surprise for a b day dinner thanks to my soulmate.   She made reservations for the first seating at 6pm.  

Located in Upper Hayes valley.  Place is very cozy.  Pillows along the wall for comfort.  Clean, WHITE everywhere almost remind me of Greece (Mykonos).  

I'm such a fan of Chef Dominque Crenn.   She represents the Bay to the fullest with her French inspired dishes. The wine pairing, and the service was phenomenal.  Every wine and dish was explained in every detail. 

Food was mind BLOWING.  From the first course to the last.  The Gnocchi À La Parisienne was superb from the freshness of the corn and fava beans to the soft pillows of Gnocchi with hints of coriander tops....C'est MAGNIFIQUE!   Then The chefs brought out a full Salmon and explained when and where it was caught (talk about ocean to table).  So saying it is FRESH is an understatement.   

At the end they brought out a little something special with a candle for my b day.   Thank you!!
author: Eddie M.

description: Unfortunately, not the best for us.  Don't get us wrong, a few of the plates were good, but that really was only 3 out of 7 in the tasting menu.  I think we set our expectation too high.  A few of the dishes were too salty.  My bf is severely lactose intolerant.  The substitutes that were prepared really didn't seem to match the price or expectation.  I mean 2 piece of fruits in place of some appetizer?  Or some Korean style egg thing in place of escargot.  Seriously, not a $90 per person place.  I have dined at better place for that price!
author: ME K.

description:
It is with mixed emotions that I'm leaving this review.  The place was beautiful, with a great atmosphere.  It is clear that the chefs are professional and take their food seriously.  Here is the problem:

- we had the tasting menu, which I know is for "tasting" only, so the portions were small.  But after 5 dishes, I walked away hungry.  I admit to loving food, but I'm not an overeater.  I thought I was going to dinner (albeit, consisting of many small dishes).  The food itself was good, with some negatives (more below), but literally, my dinner did not include anything more than one taste.  I'm not going to say that I paid $95 for just 5 tastes, but I did go to dinner, and was expecting to feel at least not tempted to have a second dinner (which I did).  For example, I had the herring with potatoes, it was delicious, but it contained 3 minuscule herring pieces and 5 very small potatoes.  So, in 3 bites, it was over.  I would have liked to enjoy the taste besides just "tasting" the dish.  I also had a clam dish, which consisted of 3 baby leeks (looked like the white part of a baby/ thin spring onion) covered with 3 tiny leafs of a plant I am not familiar with, and underneath each leaf, I found a small clam (it was so small, I didn't see it until I moved the leaf).  I understand small dishes, but this dinner was tiny and unsatisfactory for that reason.  The only dish that provided some kind of substantial nourishment was the bread slice with butter, but it wasn't the kind of calorie intake that I was anticipating.  The bread was a brioche style and it was greasy (as all brioches are), and I was happy to finally eat something that required chewing and actual swallowing of food, but I was really disappointed that it had to be bread, which as tasty as bread can be, just isn't actual food.  After all this bashing, I have to say, the food itself was good.  The buckwheat mushroom tart was excellent.  It was the only dish of a decent size, considering it's a small-dish dinner, and it was very tasty.  

- the taste of some foods wasn't ideal.  For example, we had the halibut as the last dish.  Both my husband and I had different reasons for not liking this dish.  I dislike halibut in general, but this one had some sort of cartilage in the middle, and it was overcooked on top and undercooked on the bottom.  It was a big difference in taste and consistency in 1/2 inch of fish.  I'm not sure that halibut is a great fish to eat undercooked, either, it has a really fishy smell that is only exacerbated when it's near-raw.  My husband thought the overcooked part was too heavy.  It was the last dish and the worst of the night.  The desert that followed (chocolate cake) was good and probably one of the heaviest and most copious dishes relative to our dinner, but it was sweet, and I wasn't ready for desert on a hungry stomach. 

- the servers were clearly trained in serving tables, and they did a great job on manners/ filling water glasses/ courtesy, etc.  But the restaurant was loud (people talking and laughing, etc), and all servers talked in a normal voice, which was extremely hard to hear.  Especially for an unusual menu like this one, my husband and I barely heard what the servers said each time.  To clarify, we're in our mid-30s, with excellent hearing :)  It was always... "blah blah... buckwheat.... on a bed of... blah blah... clams... in a sauce of .... blah blah... "  Very frustrating.  And we genuinely wanted to know what was in our dish, but we just could not hear.  The servers have to speak up more, or the menus may have to be more descriptive in writing.  

- we were offered a few additional dishes to the tasting menu.  It was very unexpected to be provided with a 5-course menu (of course, I didn't know in the beginning that the portions are tiny), and to be told that you can buy 2 more courses at $22 and $45 each extra.  With truffles at $25 extra.  I understand the pricing system, and in retrospect, I wonder if I had bought the 2 extra courses, whether I'd have felt fuller after the dinner.  It was only when dinner was over that I realized that it was small and I was still hungry and the tasting original menu really wasn't a dinner menu at all.  And I felt disappointed with the whole experience.  If it takes 7 small dishes to feel the full experience, then the restaurant should charge $120 per person and provide all food for a complete experience.  I felt like the normal menu of $95 per person was a let-down and that perhaps the restaurant knew that it wasn't sufficient food, which is why they offered those extras.  It just didn't feel like I knew that 5 dishes would not be enough, and I wish all this information had been more explicit so that I can make a choice.  While $95 is a lot already, I would have paid $120, if I had known that it's what it took to feel satisfied with dinner.
author: Raley S.

description:
Lunch: extraordinary deliciousness for the price (which includes gratuity, a welcome surprise). Each bite was the best I've had of these French classic dishes... 
Whole roast trout (drizzled with magical herbs & oil)
Gruyere Grougeres (stuffed and fluffy)
Carrots with pistachio sauce (crisp al dente, awesome)
Mushrooms & Gnocchi (brown buttery)
author: Wiley W.

description:
Huge fan of the food and the service! We made reservations for the Chef's Table which cost more...but in my opinion, worth every penny. It was $120/person + Truffle + Wine. No regrets!
Courtney was our server but everyone in the restaurant was pleasant and accommodating. We even had pictures taken with Dominique Crenn and Elizabeth Falkner.
-Started with some kind of puff pastry...
-Then, Petit Crenn Omelette
-Then, had the rustic sourdough with butter from Brittany, France
- Then, Nasketucket Oysters prepared two ways: pressed meyer lemon or apple cider veil (Grilled the Other Raw)
-Then, Parisienne Gnocchi with Black Truffles (additional charge..extra $60)
-Then, Main Course: Grilled Octopus with Butter Bean Casserole and Charred Brassica (part of the mustard family...had to google it!)
-Then, Little Gem salad
-Lastly, some dessert. SO FULL! just thinking of all that food we ate. 
But yes, I highly recommend doing the Chef's Table for a splurge.

P.S. Somewhere between all those dishes..we were served abalone. It was my least favorite...and possibly why i forgot to mention it..but i found it to be extremely salty..but it was my first time having abalone..is it usually salty?
author: Sharon Q.

description:
Beautiful, airy interior with a chic and casual ambiance. I haven't been to Atelier Crenn yet (their sister restaurant), but if Petit Crenn's food and service is any indication, it's definitely on my list now.

My gf's and I came here for lunch, and we shared a few plates between the three of us. Food was delicious and service was impeccable.

FOOD:
- Loved their bread and fresh butter (beware, not complimentary!)
- Mushroom tartine - topped with plenty of mushrooms and full of flavor and umami. Unfortunately the bread became soggy because of all the sauce.
- Gnocchi - if you're a fan of gnocchi, this one's for you. I loooved the mushrooms and buttery sauce. The gnocchi were also tender and delicious.
- Gruyere gougeres - these little cheese balls were delicate but full of flavor. I liked the dollop of shallot gelee on top.

Overall, a little pricey but great service and quality food. Solid 4 stars.
author: Vivian H.

description:
We came to Petit Crenn with high expectations, and left sorely disappointed.  The food and service were both quite a let down, especially considering the price point.

Our party of 4 had reservations for the 8:30 PM seating on a Friday night.  We found nearly every course unimpressive.  The oysters were overly salted.  The gnocchi was good, but not great.  The broccoli rabe was ok.  The fish was bland and boring.  (Also, were were shocked that they originally told us the fish was from Massachusetts, and later told us it was from Virginia...you'd think they'd have their facts straight about their main course!).  The dessert tart was the only dish I got a little excited about.    

In addition, were weren't impressed with either of the bottles of wine that our waitress indicated would pair well with the menu.

Also, it was quite hard to see the menu on the chalkboard - it would have been nice to have printed menus on the table.

The decor and lighting made for a cozy, elegant setting.  On the other hand, the place was shockingly too warm for a chilly SF winter night.  

Overall, this was a mediocre dining experience.  We've gone to Atelier Crenn before and came in expecting something equally high caliber (if more casual) - Petit Crenn is not anything like it's big sister.
author: Barnali D.

description: We had an amazing birthday dinner here tonight.   The staff was welcoming, despite our being a few minutes late.  We had seats at the bar and really enjoyed watching the chef and cooks work.  Every plate was balanced in both acidity and texture.   Thank you Petit Crenn!
author: Nicholas O.

description:
In the TL; DR spirit, I recommend that you get a bottle of wine vs. by the glass.  We ordered glasses of wine rather than the pairing.  My champagne was great but my date's glass was a *very* skimpy pour.   Maybe the waitress was thinking of a pairing pour, but it was maybe 3 oz vs. 4-5 oz I would expect for the cost of a glass.    

But the good:
A few years ago, I saw the menu from Atalier Crenn  and thought "NEVER!" since the cost of a dinner for two there would support a family for a month... in most places outside of SF.    Petit Crenn, while still a total splurge as far as I'm concerned, makes it possible to eat Crenn dishes for us mere mortals. 

We sat at the chef's counter, warmed by the heat of the massive fires, and were able to watch the immaculate preparation, obsessive cleaning and general attentiveness of the cooks.   There was zero chaos in the kitchen.  It was a show, for sure. 

Dinner is a  tasting menu and the tastes were substantial enough that we left full. Very full, though we did eat every bite, resisting the urge to lick the plates clean, especially in the case of the crudite and the tomato sauce with the squid. 

The menu is displayed on a chalk board and I strategically left my glasses at home so each course was something of a mystery, which made it fun to try to guess what was in the sauce for the crudite (maybe avocado?)  and what the crunchy bits were (toasted buckwheat). 

The best course was the trout.  Now, I don't usually think of trout as being a robust, fatty fish, but this was, and after we had ours, we watched how it was cooked, very closely, to see if we might be able to re-create the perfection and yumminess at home (I have no idea how they got the skin so crispy and delicious without sticking to the grill or turning black - probably something to do with the temp and distance from the fire....) 

I'd definitely like to come back and try another menu.   Loved the food, loved the view.
author: Maria C.

description:
Walked in .. waited twenty minutes, totally ignored ... place was half empty.. someone finally noticed me.. I asked if I could sit at one of the many empty tables was told they were reserved.. but could sit at the counter..after a while I was offered some water since a full bottle of Badoit is a bit large for one..it never came..walked out ..no one asked why or cared .. 
Oh and by the way I am French ...désolée Dominique mais Bar Jules était bien mieux !!!
author: Marie-Christine K.

description: Brunch here was fabulous.  The service was great, and their menu is affordable especially given the quality.  I had the best glass of Burgundy here, too!  Can't wait to go back the next time I visit SF!
author: Christie S.

description:
Probably the most romantic restaurant in San Francisco right now.  Those French!  I took my wife here for a date and we sat at the counter, close enough to the fire pit to enjoy the added warmth.  The restaurant is beautiful, from the dinnerware to the decor.  It was fun trying the a la carte menu, and getting to share different items, all while watching the chefs prepare the various meals right in-front of us. The food was great, the whole roasted trout on the charcoal grill was a spectacle.  My wife loved the squash. And the pillow-like gnocchi was exquisite.  Our Alsatian white wine, with just a bit of effervescence, was divine.

Staff was very friendly, and with tip included in the price, we left feeling like it is one of the better deals in the City for a very nice night out.
author: Jesse H.

description:
Came here with a friend. The food, service, ambiance was amazing. Next time I will sit at the bar, it was cool to see them from afar make the food. 

This place isn't cheap, but if you are a foodie, or simply like good food and value an excellent dining experience. This is your place!
author: Sonia A.

description:
I've discovered yet another overrated, over-priced, mediocre-to-terrible "fancy" restaurant in SF! Beware - this place is nothing like Atelier Crenn (nowhere near Atelier's price range either, haha!).

Prix-fixe menu. Started off with raw oysters, two per person, tasted pretty good. Next came a pot of mussels. The mussels did not taste fresh (not-fresh mussels usually have a slight stink to them, and these mussels had that stink), and the garlic bread was burnt along the edges. There was a dish with a full fish (head and bones included) that was difficult to eat and tasted okay. The brussel sprouts on the stock with the sun-chokes dip tasted pretty decent. The salad was bland, the cheese that came with the salad was pretty nasty (don't eat the rind). The dessert, which was a traditional pancake sorta thing, tasted awful and bland. There was too much food, in my opinion, an attempt to make up for the poor quality and bad taste. 

Ambiance is a typical, trendy, chic, French bistro style. Service was nice. The seats (bench along the wall) is hard and uncomfortable (pretty much sitting on concrete). 

Way over-priced ($79 per person) for mediocre food. Never again. I would not recommend this restaurant. Go to Clementine on Clement if you want good French food (with affordable prices if you do the early-bird special).
author: Jennifer W.

description:
I'm putting the disclaimer out there that I did not eat at the restaurant. Why am I reviewing this restaurant then? Read below.

My bf and I were supposed to eat here the Wednesday before Thanksgiving. I was in town from LA for the weekend, and he had wanted to try this restaurant for a while now, since it had recently opened, and we've had great experiences at their other restaurant, Atelier Crenn. So, he had booked the reservation 4 weeks to the day through SeatMe, to ensure that we would have a table for this particular weekend. It was to celebrate our 7.5 year anniversary. He had received the email confirmation through SeatMe, a few days before the reservation, and another text message an hour before our reservation. 

All was going well, until we arrived at the restaurant, and it was CLOSED.

We left 2 phone messages. I gave them until Monday to return my call, since it was Thanksgiving weekend and all. That should have been plenty of time for them to return my call. They never called back to apologize - not to my boyfriend nor me! A week following the reservation, my boyfriend emailed them saying how disappointed we were with our experience. Her response: 

"I am very sorry for the frustration and disappointment that this caused you and your girlfriend. We no longer use Yelp SeatMe as a reservation platform. One of the reasons is because there were frequently mistakes like this.  We have transitioned recently to Resy, which we believe is much more reliable. 

I hope that you will consider joining us in the future. If I can ever be of assistance in making a reservation or for anything else, please do not hesitate to contact me directly at ______"

To be honest, if they knew that SeatMe frequently makes mistakes, they should be especially careful to prevent these mistakes from occurring!!! I don't know why that had to be their excuse. Or if it was their excuse, restaurant credit encouraging a second visit would be appropriate. This is especially disappointing, since their sister restaurant Atelier Crenn is a Michelin-rated restaurant. One would think that they would have their service down pat. Nope. 

They made it loud and clear that they did not want our business there. Will not be returning.
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
I had only been there for dinner and had equally high expectations for lunch and was extremely disappointed.

There is a reason it is easy to get a lunch reservation.  

For one thing, the menu was hard to read since the printer was broken and the waiter made no effort to bring me a more legible copy.

I ordered the $24 trout on a piece of bread  which was called something else (tartine something)  but that was what it turned out to be. Maybe a little cheese or something spread on it. Nothing special about the trout or the bread.

My sister ordered the crepe with an egg in the middle for $15 which was a little tastier but not worth the price. I was still hungry after lunch and dessert ($9 for some cake with carmel)
author: Emily W.

description:
I talked this place up for 6 weeks to my boyfriend while planing our trip to San Francisco and we were not disappointed! After looking through reviews, he had mixed feelings, but all the poor reviews were unfounded: food was spot on (fabulous flavors and combinations, Good portions, great flow of food course to course), service was as expected (not intrusive, took there time between courses and ensured that the table remained neat) and the setting was intimate but not stuffy. We did the tasting menu plus the cheese course prior to the desert and 1 drink with the price as expected. When reservations are made, you're told how much the tasting menu is and they tell you the price of any added courses once you're there plus gratuity is already added so there isn't any "sticker shock."
Some reviews said the food was lackluster, service was poor or it was more pricey than they thought it should be. All those reviews are wrong. Petit Crenn was fantastic and I will one day go to Atelier Crenn you see what Dominique Crenn has invented in her Michelin star restaurant.
author: Analee S.

description: Dominique Crenn is a singular genius (and star of the Netflix series Chef's Table). Here at Petit Crenn you may enjoy one of her fantastic meals for a lower cost. Every bite is magnificent. This is a special place.
author: Nate B.

description: I've eaten at Petit Crenn for lunch and dinner now and while both services differ greatly, the wait staff was informative and very friendly. For the dinner my vegetarian friends were blown away with their veg alternative dishes although the menu is predominantly vegetarian. PC is certainly a well oiled machine.
author: brian k.

description:
Great tasting menu that won't break the bank. Mostly seafood focused with everything cooked very nicely.
- Grilled flatbread, white bean puree
- Oysters, gruyere puffs, and radishes
- Gnocchi with mushrooms
- Grilled trout
- Frisee and citrus salad
- Mousse with blood orange sorbet
All really tasty, with the only minor complaint that the gnocchi didn't have much of a crisp/sear. Also got the wine pairing which complimented the for very nicely, with the exception of the dessert pairing which was just not my taste.
author: Jeff W.

description:
Was so excited to try this place after being moved by the episode on Chefs table. I know we didn't go to Altier Crenn but were expecting some kind of "wow" factor. 

The service was great and the attention to detail gives it that fancy feel from the staff. But to be completely honest the food was was good, but not great. Nothing left us feeling like "wow" this is so good I need another bite. The meal was pretty blah. In retrospect I wish we had spent that amount on a birthday dinner somewhere else. Was not moved and don't want to go back.
author: Jess K.

description: For a cute lunch with a light, comfy atmosphere, this place is delightful. Think: French grandma's cookin'. We had reservations, but they were unnecessary. The menu has some nice items to choose from, but it is quite limited. Shared the little gem salad, Bibb lettuce salad, omelet and mushroom tartine. Both salads were refreshing and delicious. And while the omelet was well-prepared, it was monotonous and quite boring, both in looks and taste. The tartine was brimming with mushrooms. It was a great size, but too salty and buttery. Alas, French food! Last but not least, we split a pumpkin crème brûlée and wished we had ordered a second one! Overall, a cute place with nice service and decent food. However, when Crenn is your last name, you should be delivering above and beyond, even if this isn't your prized Michelin restaurant.
author: Carolina B.

description: SF has its share of great restaurants, and this gem is among them. The food is imaginative and all of the flavors meld well together without being fussy.  The wine pairings are exceptional... it is fun to taste the wine before the food & to see how much they evolve after the food. The service was on point.... one dish got served with an item that it shouldn't.., instead of removing one plate... they removed all & presented together again. Would hands down recommend again.
author: Alison B.

description: Great for brunch. The mushroom tartine and pastries are to DIE for! Overall, this place reminds me of my numerous trips to the French Riviera: Lots of good bread and lots of good vibes!
author: Jeddeo P.

description:
I was looking forward to really enjoying this place, as I'd been wanting to come here for awhile, but I was disappointed. I went for Sunday brunch. The pros: unusual dishes, good bread, an extremely tasty parting dessert item. The cons: expensive for what it is, few menu choices.

The place also had the vibe of a casual coffee shop - maybe a little more upscale. The brunch dishes were $15-$20 on average. I had the mushroom tartine; it was beautiful, but the taste overall just didn't appeal to me. My friend had the buckwheat crepe - also beautiful, but somewhat simple. The pastries looked delicious, but I couldn't justify paying 3 for $18. The total bill was $62 for the two of us.

There weren't that many brunch reviews on yelp and now I think I know why ... more people go for dinner?

Lastly, the on-line reservation system makes this place seem more booked than it actually is. Slots fill up quickly, but when we went, many tables were empty for a good part of the time we ate.
author: Kim H.

description: Stopped here for lunch. Fantastic farm to table experience and great pastries and good service :)
author: Thomas W.

description: Very creative cuisine and impeccable service. Everything was delicious. We also sat next to a Top Chef so it's definitely legit.
author: Joyce Y.

description:
Wonderful meal. The courses were spaced a little slow toward the end and I mistakenly thought we were done when we still had two left. Oops. Very cool that they accommodated my BF's vegetarian menu request and the slice of birthday cake at the end was a great touch.
Cute wine list as well. Excellent service. Thanks for making his birthday dinner so special.
author: erin m.

description:
Great service, delicious food, very stylish and clean , nice decor
Cant wait to try the sister restaurant atelier crenn
author: isabelle w.

description:
I, like others who have reviewed Petit Crenn, had high hopes for this dinner, but alas, while the food was all delicious, the overall experience left much to be desired. Four of us arrived for our 8:30pm seating at 8:32pm and were relegated to sitting at a counter. Normally, I love a counter seat, watching the cooks prepare food, but for an expensive dinner with four people, a counter is not conducive to a good dining experience. First bit of advice: close the counter to anything other than couples.

Next, while the food was really delicious (oysters, mussels on Josey Baker bread, a small bowl of chopped tomatoes, fluke, a salad, some sort of dessert), there just isn't very much of it. And, with two wine pairings (one for each couple to share) and a bottle of wine (more on that), our meal was about $600 (or more, I quickly looked away from the receipt lest my retinas burn out). In terms of value, Petit Crenn simply doesn't offer any. 

Back to the wine, we relied on our wine server to find a good accompaniment to the meal. While the wine was ok, it was curious. And, when I asked about it (since I couldn't hear the earlier conversation about the wine selection--see also: counter seating), he described it as an unusual wine. Oh. Why, out of curiosity, are you recommending unusual wines to be paired with your food? Do you know how this works? Second bit of advice: provide actual valuable wine guidance to your patrons. If you think a wine is weird, be up front about it before they order it.

All in all, we did it. That's about the best praise I can offer for the total dining experience at Petit Crenn. I'd eat the mussels on toast again (hard to give Crenn credit for Josey Baker's handiwork, though). But, I think PC is a one-time event.
