If I could turn back time, I'd have several meals at Nopa or many other restaurants instead.
author: Todd X.

description:
The food was good but it didn't blow me away. It's very rustic and homey. Nothing like Atelier Crenn. There are only two seating times, 6pm and 8:30pm. While I like the idea of everyone eating at the same time, it just doesn't quite work. We all eat at different speeds so the people who are quicker end up waiting uncomfortably long for the next course since we are waiting for the people who don't eat as fast. This uncomfortable wait happened several times during our meal. Also being in the first seating, when the next seating group started to arrive, all we got was stares. While I understand what it's like to wait, it's not our fault that the food is coming out slow. 

I'm glad they got rid of the communal sharing plates idea. Food is now only shared among your own party. Tables are all two tops, not communal either. 

The service was ok but slow. There were times I think they could have paid more attention to us. I had to ask for water refills several times. 

Street parking in the area can be hard but not impossible.

There are some extras you can order on top of your set meal. Tips are included as well but tax is not. 

I'm really glad they have a housemade soda for people who don't drink. I just wish they have more flavors to choose from.

Overall a good meal but bring your patience with you.
author: Andy W.

description:
I was dreading to write this review but I feel like I have to.  I was very, very disappointed w/ the service.  What's the point in having 2 seatings if you're not going to seat people on time...?  And of course it felt like because we were the token Asian girls we were the last table of 4 to get seated.  While other tables of 4 waiting in line behind us were seated before us...does that make sense.  We weren't offered a drink or amuse bouche on the house...nothing.  

The food was mediocre, I can't even remember what we ate.  I was expecting great food given the name.
author: Meredith K.

description:
Were there for my birthday: I cried in the end because the smoke made my eyes burn in a very unpleasant way.
Service: awful, Food: decent but not special, courses were too stretched, we got bored and sleepy in the end with a month-worth of condescending attitude.
author: Deniz S.

description: This experience was the best - we sat at the bar and celebrated a milestone together and every dish was artful, creative and bursting with flavors. My only negative is that I don't have enough money in the bank to eat here every night. ;o)
author: DeeLite W.

description:
Delicious dinner with friends. 

Seafood-centric meal, loved everything we had. 

Tender smokey grilled octopus. 
Whole grilled trout. Superb de-boning at table side. 
Oysters were so fresh and clean. 

All were hits for me, except the honey crisp apple tart. 

But many accompaniments to more than supplement for one miss. 

Get the add ons. We ordered the mushrooms and also the razor clams. Both were nicely done and well executed.
author: Sonya T.

description: So disappointing. The skate they served was hardly edible. Undercooked and truly off putting. Side dishes were over salted. Cauliflower under so much sauce I couldn't enjoy it. Egg were just ok as was the dessert. The only highlights were the oysters and octopus. Lovely decor though. Wish food was better. Michael Minna test kitchen was much better and a better value. Loved Atelier Crenn so this was truly sad for me.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Not a fan and am so disappointed. This may be cliche, but since being moved to tears by Dominique Crenn's episode on Chef's Table, I really wanted to experience one of her restaurants. Sadly, I was met with utter disappointment. 

The restaurant in general isn't very clean and it doesn't have a good feeling. Upon arriving, we were helped by a bunch of people and you would think that would feel nice being tended to by many but instead it felt very disorganized, rushed and unprofessional. Every few minutes, someone different would come to our table and ask how we were doing or if we wanted anything although whatever we asked for never came. Water was spilled on our table and he replied he would come back to wipe it down but he never did. We had to ask a several times for silverware. The towel with which the table was wiped down between courses was dirty. The service just generally felt sloppy. There was one particular waiter who was incredibly creepy. Both my friend's and my radars went off. He seemed drunk or high and was very openly hitting on the women seated behind us. We felt pretty uncomfortable.

The food...we had the 5 course dinner plus wine pairings. Our bill for two came to ~$350 including gratuity. We left very hungry because the servings are so small!! Each course comes out "family style" except it's such small servings it's like you're splitting a meal. The wine pairings were pretty horrible. We did not enjoy any of the wine/champagne served. So much so we left glasses unfinished (and I never leave foods/drinks unfinished because I feel wasteful + guilty). We wished we had just ordered a nice glass of wine of our choice.

Lastly, if you do choose to dine here, expect to smell like campfire afterwards. They have an open grill that emits a lot of smoke. I've been to other restaurants with open grills/wood burning ovens and never went home smelling so smoky but after our meal here, my hair and clothes were quite smoky.

We were still so hungry after our meal here, we went and got tacos. It was amazing.
author: Akiko O.

description:
When you walk in and see Dominique Crenn smiling and greeting people at tables, you know you're in for a treat.  The restaurant is like walking into someone's living room, bright and welcoming with pillows along the long benches that you sit on against the wall.  We were lucky enough to score a reservation on their first Saturday dinner service to celebrate my friend's birthday.  As soon as we were seated, Chef Crenn came and jokingly asked if we've been there before and then said, of course not since they just opened.  

If you love vegetables and seafood, you are going to love dinner here. Right at 6:00 sharp, all the tables started being served a few amuse bouche from the kitchen:  an omelet, some anchovies and a wonderful gougeges.  Chef Crenn served a couple of them personally!   We then went right into the first course, oysters with smoked tomato gelee on the half shell.  Bread  and salted butter was brought to the table as well.  Next was escargot, with an Asian inspired onion pancake and mushrooms.  I've seriously never had escargot before, and this was just delicious - great combination of flavors and texture.  Soon arrived the cauliflower au gratin and grilled cabbage.  The sauce with the cauliflower was rich, and yet light at the same time.  I love cabbage so I really was excited to eat a good wedge.  The piece de resistance was the roasted trout, deboned tableside, with a cider sabayon.  It was perfectly cooked, and the lemon really brought out a wonderful taste.  Dinner ended with a light salad and more bread, then nicely transitioned to a light citrus mousse, along with some caramels and cookies.  

All in all, the service was professional with a slight casual touch.  Even though it was their first week, they were all coordinated in making sure we received the right amount of attention at the right time.  The best part of the night was when Chef Crenn photo bombed my friends while I was taking a picture of them.  She came across as very fun and friendly, as well as proud of her restaurant, as she should be.

I like that the service is included in the prix fixe menu.  Broken down, it's like a 20% tip on a $60 dinner.  I loved the cider we had with dinner, but next time I really need to try something from their wine list.  This is a great place for going out to dinner with a few friends.  If you're pretty social, going out as a couple is good too, but expect to sit with another couple as she really does try to make this like a dinner party atmosphere.  

Start booking those reservations.  You'll want to add this place to your list of special places you've dined at that you can brag about.
author: Maria S.

description:
I made a reservation for a Sat. at 6 PM, well in advance, asking for a corner table.

We arrived on time to find all but a few tables full and were told they had no record of our reservation. We showed them the confirmation to the message they sent the day before and were seated at a table closest to the bathroom.

Yes, a bad start, but the staff was very friendly, if a bit soft-spoken to the point where were were asking each other what they had just said.

We opted for one wine tasting at $65 (they were not kidding-more later) and, as were seated at a table the fixed-price meal, service included, for $87 per person-service included. 

The big positive was that the food was excellent and the service very friendly, especially for a service-included restaurant.

On the down side, the portions were, at times, the size of the "from the chef" treats we would get at other, albeit more pricey, venues. There were also equally small portions of the wine. If you are serving bottles that cost $10 wholesale, you should pour more than a few tablespoons in those nice glasses. Last, we spent, as they stated/warned over two hours at our table, and during most of that time we were looking at empty plates. 

One of the problems may be that they seated 90% of their tables and most bar seats at 5:30 the time. We walked in right at 6:00 the very small kitchen was slammed. Most other small high-end restaurants would seat 1/3 at 5:30 , 1/3 at 6 and the last at 6:30. This is resturant management 1A.

Will we be back? Perhaps to sit at the bar at 5:30...
author: K W.

description:
Very elegant restaurant and a wonderful dinner. 

I did appreciate the pre-fix menu. Today they served trout and oh, boy, It was cooked so well! Course after course my hunger disappeared in roasted carrots with peanuts (!), scalloped potatoes, oysters, mussels, dessert, cheese and salad. Delightful. 

I did not enjoy the apple pie (?) kind of chewy, not as flavorful. But I don't eat carbs, so it did not matter.

Service was very attentive and very friendly. 

Also Lionel F. the reviewer from 10/30/15 already mentioned red wine served cold... I never really had it like this, but I let it sit and warm up a bit, and it opened up and I was able to appreciate it even more.

We did take the last dessert course to go (chocolate truffles, sugar cookies and caramel candy) - the right decision. We walked to Absinthe and ate all the sweets there while sipping on Laphroaig and a glass of Cabernet Sauvignon.
author: Anelya S.

description:
Petit Crenn is a decent place, but way too pricey.

We were the first guests to have a reservation at 11AM. Upon entering, we were greeted with a blast of loud music from the 80s. I personally love 80s music, but coupled with all of the chefs and waiters singing, it was a tad too much. We asked to have the music turned down, but they barely reduced it by -1dB. Not exactly the kind of ambiance you expect at a French restaurant. The design of the place was pretty nice with its modern elegance and crazy plastic chairs.

Here's what we tried:

TROUT TARTINE ($15.00) salty smoked trout on top of a large slice of bread topped with a spread of cream cheese and capers. I like harder bread, but this bread was a bit too hard and a tad too burnt. It wasn't super filling or anything special but it was decent. 
GNOCCHI ($22.00) surprisingly soft and melt in your mouth. Some people think it's too mushy--I agree it's not a bouncy as your normal gnocchi, but I actually preferred it. It was seasoned very well with a butter sauce. I HIGHLY RECOMMEND THIS. 
MUSSELS MARINIERE ($24.00) a little too much lemon in their sauce but the mussels were fresh and the buttered bread wasn't too bad.
OMELETTE ($18.00) I don't recommend this dish. It was simple a thin omelette stuffed with cheese and cilantro.  
PANNA COTTA ($9.00 each) I also don't recommend this either. It was similar to a yogurt parfait with granola and strawberries, but it was super small and not worth it. Go to McDonalds instead if you want a better parfait. 

It's nice that they included the service fee. Tip is always a super touchy issue--not sure if we give enough, feeling bad for waiters, don't want waiters to get mad, don't want people to trip us as we exit the building (I'm kidding of course).    

SERVICE: 4 stars since they refilled our water and changed the plates and utensils.
AMBIANCE: 3 stars because I wish they turned down the music more even though we already asked.
FOOD: 4 stars since it wasn't bad, but it wasn't amazing either.
PRICE: 2 stars because it's overpriced.
TOTAL: 3 stars 

Bottom Line: Food is decent. Price is not. This place is good to try once, and maybe, just maybe again.
author: Andrew C.

description: The food couldn't have been any better, which completely made up for the fact that we were told our table wasn't ready yet just to be seated at the bar. The prefix menu included the following dishes: canapés, a potato dish with bread, mushroom crepe with escargot, Halibut with greens, fromage blanc and toast, and citrus tart. The vegetarian options were nearly the same with a potato strip instead of the Halibut. (The homemade bread was unbelievable because it was so soft and the crust dissolved in your mouth.) We has been hoping for chocolate and were pleased to get a chocolate caramel with our bill. It was a great Valentine's Day weekend celebration!
author: Jennifer A.

description:
Great food and mediocre service pretty sums up this place. I arrived 45 minutes before closing and stood at the door for about 10-15 minutes before being asked if I wanted a seat. I was only offered the bar even though there were a handful of empty tables. No matter, I looked at the short menu and ordered some raw oysters, gougeres and a salmon Tartine. The flavors were bright and mesmerizing. It was an expensive lunch but a memorable one. I also saw on the bill that gratuity is automatically included so perhaps that explains the lack of service.

If you have the time, don't mind being ignored and just want to try wonderful flavors, this is the place.
author: Jen K.

description: I've gotten the opportunity to enjoy the tasting menu at Petit Crenn many times and I also send my out of town friends and family here. Petit Crenn never disappoints. Their fish is prepared perfectly and their plating is always so pretty. Also, their bread and pastry chef will leave you craving Petit Crenn months later.
author: Natalie J.

description:
I dined here this past Saturday and was pleasantly surprised how much I liked it because I'll admit going into it I was skeptical. I had heard and read a lot of mixed reviews along with my experience at Atelier Crenn I honestly was expecting a let down. Though I enjoyed the experience of her flagship restaurant the flavors didn't really come together for me. Luckily her artistry and the pairing of poetry made that experience one of a kind. 

Right out the gate the prices felt very high to me. As much as I was ok with a fixed price menu I was hoping it would be a little more casual. The whole place felt almost too clean and hospital like. In many ways it felt as classy as Atelier just less spread out. I was hoping for parisian and neighborhood like rather than the sterile white. Chairs weren't very comfortable either though I'm sure the bench seating was fine. The service was equally as sterile. Again in hopes of it being a more relaxed casual version of Atelier it felt like it was trying to be more than that. I recall at Atelier our servers were very laid back yet professional. They were another part of what made that experience great and sadly I didn't get that here. They were efficient and timely but just didn't grab me on a personal level. 

The food however is spectacular. Flavors came together really well during our meal and the wines that were suggested to me paired really nicely. Probably the strongest part of the service now that I think about it. The gnocchi was perfect and roasted potatoes were both excellent. I enjoyed the salmon entree though for an 89 dollar I expected a little more flash or better fish. The little gem salad was a bit boring as well. Tasty but a bit of a let down due to expectations and price. 

In the end I can't say I had a bad time but I also can't rave about it either. I had a lot of hopes of it being more casual and it never did that for me. The beauty of Atelier crenn is her personality shows in the all the other aspects of the restaurant and at Petit you don't even get a little of what makes Dominique Crenn so adored by her fans.
author: Joco F.

description:
I made a reservation at Petit Crenn a month ago to celebrate a special occasion. They called me 2 days before to confirm the reservation, which I did. They then called 24 hours before the reservation to let me know that their system had a problem and my reservation has been canceled, though they can sit me - wait for it - in a month or two months.

Wow.
author: Sammy F.

description: Been here a few times for brunch and loved it each time.  The omelette is wonderful, even though the portion is very small (and they always tell you that).  The mushroom tartine is flavorful and makes you want to take one bite after another.  Service was rather good each time.  Very courteous and just on point for us.
author: andy w.

description:
I came to this restaurant with very high expectations after hearing wonderful things about the chef and watching her documentary on Netflix. However I was extremely disappointed with the service. 

The food was very good, but not out of this world, with the exception of the chamomile Panna cotta - which was amazing! There where 3 waiters, 2 woman that had unfriendly attitude and 1 guy that said he had been here for 2 weeks only. We were served last most of the time during the whole night; we ordered a bottle of wine and we had to serve ourselves water and wine during the night because none of the waiters came over to fill our glasses.  The waiters where very unorganized, everyone was trying to do everything at every table and because of that they missed actually Giving service to every table.  We did not get offered more drinks nor coffee. 
I think the concept of the place is good and believe it has potential but they really need to do something about the service.  I did not get a sense of anyone there being happy to be there or do their job. 

If I could rate the food and service separately I would give it 2 stars for service and 4 stars for food.
author: Lyndy N.

description:
Wow. Just wow.

My husband and I celebrated our anniversary dinner there on Saturday night and haven't been able to stop talking about our experience ever since! From the ambience to the service to the food to the wine, it was absolute perfection. The servers were friendly, attentive, and extremely professional. The interior of the restaurant itself is lovely and seemed to glow that evening; they even had a really cool playlist going in the background which just added to the overall effect. As for the food...the only SF restaurants I've been to with similar quality food are Quince and maybe Benu. Too delicious to even attempt to describe! I highly recommend splurging on the wine pairing, too; the staff did a good job of selecting wines that complemented the food perfectly.

We came for the 8:30 seating and wrapped up around 11:30pm. We really appreciated the pacing of the meal as it gave us time to savor each course and fully soak up the experience. The bill came to around $315 for two prix fixe meals plus two wine pairings. We felt it was money well spent.

(Side note: I have to say that it's hard to understand how this place could only have 3.5 stars on Yelp. Makes me question how valuable a tool Yelp really is for assessing the quality of businesses. There are countless other restaurants in SF with higher ratings that are nowhere near the quality of this place. My recommendations to fellow fans of the SF restaurant scene: if you're not already, turn to Michael Bauer, SF Eater, or another SF food blog for your restaurant recs!)
author: Kerri W.

description:
I want to start this review by saying that I am SO disappointed to write this review.

The decor was impeccable. The food and wine were fabulous. Service was attentive...with one large exception.

Petit Crenn is exactly as the name describes it...SMALL. It's so small that the restaurant has yet to figure out a proper ventilation system. Last night, we had a fabulous meal but we could have been sitting by a campfire in Yosemite for all we knew. We. Got. Smoked. Out. The smoke was so bad that all of our clothes had to go straight to the washer and our hair still smells after taking showers.

Now, if it was a one-off smoke show, it would have been understandable, but our table, the table next to us, and the table next to them complained. The server merely brushed it off and started telling us about the amaze wood-smoked grill they have. Our eyes were burning at one point and when we told them, they simply opened the front door.

Honestly, I wouldn't expect this from a BBQ joint let alone a fixed price $100pp fine dining restaurant. So disappointed. We will not be back.
author: Brittany S.

description: Was back at Petit Crenn last night. I just love it! Gougeres, mussel tartine, incredible fluke, pumpkin vichyssoise and pumpkin and buckwheat crepe (so good) to name a few. We ordered a bottle rather than the pairings, as they would have made our dinner insanely expensive. Very warm environment and we got to watch the sous chef et al neatly pack and put things away. Also, the cooks all clean and meticulously scour their areas, which is how it's done in France - this is a HUGE plus for a restaurant in contrast with here where night cleaners come in and the cleaning us not as good, plus there is less of a whole body involvement on the part of the cooks - these details make a big difference. Anyway, I love and recommend Petit Crenn, please go if you love excellent food and a full-bodied experience.
author: Ana W.

description:
I really really wanted to like this place but it was quite disappointing overall.

Service was quite meh given that the 20% service fee is already included. We were the 2nd party to arrive for an 8:30 seating on a Friday night and once seated we kept waiting to be asked for our drink orders while pretty much most others around us were served their drinks. There was just a lack of warmth and willingness with the service. 

The wine list is quite French but probably a much better experience if done as a food pairing. The by glass burgundy Pinot noir I ordered tasted a bit acidic and old probably not corked well.

Food - conceptually I loved the idea of a pre frix menu served in family style plates even for tables of 2. The first couple courses were ok - oysters (berry mignonette a bit too sweet), gougeres were tasty, charred corn gnocchi was probably the tastiest dish of the night. Then it went downhill. The bass was the main course and probably the most disappointing. They  brought out the whole fish while the first course was being served but it took over 30 minutes for the fish to be served after everyone had finished the 2nd course of gnocchi. Fish was really dry, chalky and overcooked which was a pity given a potentially  high quality ingredient. The carrots were rubbery. Potatoes w Gorgonzola didn't taste bad. Dessert was too bland and blah didn't really care for the chocolate dust. 

I am not sure I will be returning but if forced to come back it will to order an ala carte meal and will bring my own bottle of wine.
author: Cookie M.

description:
I never write reviews, but I feel compelled to mention a few things...

I came here for a special occasion with my close friends and family and did the pre-fixe.  This was a big splurge for us, but figured it would be worth it because we love seafood and French cuisine.   Everything was pretty delicious, except... the halibut was the most overcooked fish I've ever eaten in my life.   It was as hard as a brick and dry as sawdust.   We did have the tail piece, but, there is no excusing the amount of cook on this fish.   It was just such a disappointment, given the amount of attention that is spent showing the fish to the guests, and allowing us to watch it be prepared.  We also saw them packing away extra pieces, so, clearly they could have re-fired a piece if they saw it went over.    I did not mention it at the table because I didn't want to create an awkward situation for the special occasion. 

I would have also sent a private email to Petit Crenn, but I emailed (and called, and left voicemails) in the three days prior to my reservation to ask about corkage fees and no one ever followed up or responded to me.   Therefore, I didn't think it would be an effective way to communicate.   I hope this reaches someone because I don't think Petit Crenn should be making this kind of egregious mistake unwittingly.
author: N. C.

description:
We had reservation for the pre-fixe menu. The only dishes memorable were the gnocchi and trout. Both seasoned and cooked perfectly. I didn't enjoy having the salad at the end to "cleanse" your palate before dessert, which was not enjoyable. It was a weird concoction of mousse like texture cream. There was an ingredient in it that left a bad taste in my mouth. 

The decor feels cold and chairs were uncomfortable.  Service was only ok.
author: Jen A.

description:
Innovative Brittany-influenced cuisine de grand-mère in a minimalist space.

Walking into Petit Crenn, diners encounter an open kitchen surrounded by a curved bar, stark white walls adorned only with ceramic art inscribed with cute French phases, and a pair of chalkboards that proclaim the carte du jour. It is clear from the decor that the food is meant to be the star. And, at Petit Crenn, it is.

Dominique Crenn now mans (womans?) the front of the house, while Aaron Thayer, previously sous chef at Atelier Crenn, minds the stoves. The prix fixe menu ($72) concentrates on the freshest of vegetables and shellfish, and there are two seatings per night (6:00 and 8:30).

Elegant without being ostentatious, the parade of dishes started with gougères, baked savory choux pastries filled with creamy sheep's milk cheese. Lighter than air, they were delicious. Next came briny miyagi oysters topped with smoked tomato gelée. Escargots bathed in mushroom broth and garnished with chanterelles follow.  Earthy, yet light, the dish is a winner. A roasted trout, unfortunately served whole, was flaky and moist. Cauliflower gratin with smoked breadcrumbs was lush and rich. Dessert is a tangy orange and Meyer lemon mousse piped into the peel of a large orange. Cool.

In an interesting switch, servers rotate from kitchen to table, presenting dishes they have prepared. In general this works, except when a junior server is tasked with the complex task of denoting a whole fish. Right spirit, not-so-great execution. Other that this one slight mis-step, servers are pleasant and seem honestly interested in guest enjoying themselves.

The wine list has ample selections by the glass and by the bottle.  Not surprisingly, it focuses on French offerings: Burgundies, Bordeaux, and Champagnes are all represented. Well-priced for The City, it offers something for everyone.

In a city with many choices for fine cuisine, Petit Crenn is a must try. And, and must return.
author: CJ G.

description:
OK, got seated (1st to arrive in the restaurant at 5:30), got wine, half an hour later.   Still haven't seen a bite of food!  So, the story is that they only do two seatings, so they wait for the place to fill somewhat before serving.

Damned if it ain't worth the wait!  Oyster with cucumber ice and pickled green strawberry, Oh My! Soft shell crab with avocado and squash, superb!  Gnocchi with mushrooms and peas - sucked!  Just the gnocchi (like paste), the peas and mushrooms were stellar.

OK, arrived at 5:40.  It is now 7:05 and we've made it thru the 1st 2 of 8 courses!  Pacing is cool, but this is ridiculous!

Anyway, long story short, great food with many hits and a few misses.  Good service, but way too slow paced.  Good deal considering under $300 for 2 with 2 glasses of champagne, a bottle of wine and included tip.
author: Howard B.

description: I was curious about this place for a while and often walked by it to see this little cute restaurant in Hayes Valley busy and bustling. I get to try it for brunch on Sunday and it was more or less disappointing experience. Service is good (and refreshingly included in the price of dishes), decor is pleasant but the food is mediocre in my view. I had an omelette, rolled up kind, heavy, salty and not aromatic, it reminded my companion of the food often served before landing on the long international flight. Maybe it's a bit harsh but not miles away from the truth. My companion ordered buckwheat crepe which had no buckwheat aroma and was dry and almost crisp. I doubt I would be returning for dinner but I hope it's better than brunch.
author: Mikhail K.

description:
Went Sunday evening for the 6 pm seating with friend. The food was good to mediocre. The first half of the meal was definitely better than the second. The gnocchi was the highlight. The wood oven grilled fish was watery. The veggie accompaniments were fine (roasted carrots with vadouvan and yogurt; butter beans with fava beans and olives). For $79, I didn't feel it was a good value. 

As for experience, we were seated right by the window which was great at first but as the sun set, the light hit us both at different times to the point of discomfort. The service was uncoordinated. No one asked to take our drink order until the oysters arrived at the table. We didn't even have water. My hair, jacket and dress smelled like smoke from the oven. I think my jacket still smells after having aired it for a couple days. In short, I would not return.
author: Amy L.

description:
Superb, 5 stars without a doubt. We had a reservation for 6 pm on a Friday. We got there 15-20 minutes early, but were immediately seated. To the great delight of my date, a waiter offered to take my jacket for me (in retrospect it was a poor stylistic choice).  They came to take a drink order very quickly, and were nice enough to split a wine pairing for us, which was great because we didn't each want a full pairing. 

The first thing to come out was some seriously sublime sourdough from Josey Baker Bread. Nice thick slice, crunchy, chewy, melty house-buttery, it was everything you could want from a piece of bread. 

Next was a delicious fluffy omelette with a bit o' Humboldt Fog cheese and veggies in it, along with some puff-pastry type thing, that I can only describe as a sweet and slightly cheesy ball of heaven on Earth. 

The third course was gnocchi. Oh boy, the gnocchi. This might have been the highlight of the meal. Fresh corn, hen of the woods mushrooms, and a creamy sauce that just wouldn't quit, I would trade a Heady Topper and my first born son for another bowl of that stuff. Really delightful. 

Unsurprisingly, the main course was pretty great too. The fish (which they brought out on this massive platter to show everyone before cooking it) was perfectly cooked. The carrots it was served with were also delicious. The bean salad wasn't the most flavorful thing in the world, but it was fresh and complemented the fish nicely. After this, I was full. But I kept eating, it was all delicious: the rest of the meal was a blur of little gems salad, an eclair, and some tasty little candies at the end. 

Overall: Great food, nice wine pairing (grain of NaCl: I don't know squat about wine), friendly attentive service, and all for a very reasonable price. If you're in SF, go to Petit Crenn, you won't regret it.
author: Galen E.

description:
Delightful! My husband and I stopped by for dinner at the chef's counter. It fills up fast and takes no reservations, so unless you show up when it opens, you should expect to wait - we got a drink nearby.

The counter menu appeared to offer everything on the prix fixe (table) menu, with added ambience from the wood-fired grill. You check off what you'd like on a little card presented at the beginning - unusual but seamless. Particular delights were gougeres filled with gruyere cream and topped with a sparkling onion gel and the heirloom tomato salad with savory granola. 

We split almost everything on the menu, plus a lovely bottle of muscadet recommended by the sommelier - incredibly it was only $170 for two of us.
author: Chris B.

description:
A very epic birthday dinner.  we sat at the counter and got to see the show.  darling spot.  

service was impeccable.  highly recommend!
author: Jackie D.

description: This was our first time visiting. It was a great spot to share my Birthday Celebration with a special person. Thank you for the great food!
author: Vero C.

description:
Horrendous experience. Was celebrating my wife's birthday. The staff was so inattentive that it took us over 30 minutes to get someone's attention. The service is not personalized to each table, rather the entire room - you will be waiting for more than 30 minutes between meals. 

The food was nothing to write home about.

The biggest insult, they charged us a full 100 dollars above our total... absolutely pathetic. I had to get the manager to check twice - the first time she didn't believe me and said it loudly, then I insisted and she checked and said, "it's a silly mistake."

I'm sorry. This was the worst experience I have ever had. EVER!

PLEASE AVOID!
author: Jane E.

description:
I would add this restaurant to SF must try list.

Been reading about Chef Crenn with the upcoming Chef's Table on Netflix. 
Husband and I loved the first series and was exciting to learn about a featured chef right in our city.
Her main restaurant Atelier Crenn was harder to get reservation and husband's dietary restriction (no bottom feeder, no pork, no this, no that) made us a bit hesitant of the mysterious poem menu.  Petit Crenn was a nice alternative.
With two seatings a night we were able to get a reservation on a Thursday night.
We were seated prompted and received attentive service.
The only substitute was the raw oyster. 
The rest of the menu was kosher (not in a traditional strict way).

The highlight was the market fish which was a yellow tail caught at Baja coast just couple days before.
The whole fish was parade out in the restaurant which was neat to see.
The fish was seasoned to a beautiful balance.  A bit of crispy garlic with some light herbal sauce.
The gnoochi before the main fish was also delightful with peas, mushroom and one of my favorite yet hard to find ramps.
The little gem salad came after the main fish entree which was different.
It did cleanse the pallet a bit before the desert but I would have prefer the salad before the fish.
The mixed berry galette desert was probably the low point on the menu.
It did not stand out and was a bit of let down after all the mouthful flavor of previous dishes.
The mignardises picked up the slack though.
There was a passion fruit marshmallow look-a-like which was a burst of flavor.
Some sort of peanut butter cube that balance the peanut flavor, the sweetness and the buttery texture perfectly.

Highly recommend the wine pairing which included two champagnes, couple unique white (one Spain one French) and refreshing light red that complimented very well with each dish.

Last plus for the place, the service is included~~!
The set menu was $79 per person and the wine pairing was another $65.
That's it.  None of that suggested 15%, 18% or  20% nonsense.
author: YC L.

description: This is one of my favorite SF restaurants. It is hard to find restaurants in SF that are Pre Fix but not astronomical in price, but Petit Crenn fits the bill. I've been twice and the food was delicious both times.
author: Matthew S.

description: Dissipointing experience trying to get a table here. Would not recommend going without a reservation. Was a battle for only 2 available seats at the bar and when they told us to come back in 20 min they had given priority to another person waiting when they never said you have to stay on the premise. Then they never even bothered to offer to help us make a reservation for the future. Nothing.
author: Maya R.

description:
I was disappointed with the food.  The ambiance is great, the service a little hmmm....overly officious, sort of toss out the ingredients list without a sense of engagement with you.  They have a lot of staff, but clearing glasses and plates promptly seems to have been lost on my team.  I used to live in SF - used to cook for a living and you know when things are done well and when things miss the mark.

A pretty simple meal actually, which I think is great.  The oysters - great.  The gnocchi was nice, but not great - the baby carrots were leathery, the potatoes were great.  The salmon was too salty, : /  really unfortunate.  My wife left her portion on the platter - and nobody said anything...

The salad was good (you better be able to make a salad).  The dessert was not distinct in either flavor or texture.  Sort of a train wreck this evening.  I'm trying to think what exactly it was I ate.  Good coffee and tea.  Great ambience.

The wine list was French as perhaps it should be.  The flight of wines served push boundaries.  I wish they would consider all the amazing local wines in our backyard.  The selection provided I would give a B.    

I would go back, but probably sit at the bar and have a specific dish (and bring my own bottle of wine.)
author: David F.

description: The food was underwhelming to say the least. Certain things were a nice surprise, but then others were a disappointment. Tarte Tatin was more like a dry almond paste tarte and made me wish that I had two scoops of the gelato that accompanied it. And, which I find really weird for a French restaurant, they don't have an espresso machine.
author: Lela B.

description: Such a memorable and pleasant dining experience, the staff puts such care into the food and into the clean up. This is a special spot- great for dates or anniversaries, like I was celebrating. Don't believe some of these entitled hipster reviews- for less than 100$ per person, it's an evening you will remember for some time :-)
author: David O.

description: The food and service were fabulous. My favorite course was the heirloom tomato salad; my husband loved the salmon tail. Everything was delicious. We can't wait to come back! Also, the coconut curry passion fruit custard dessert was out of this world.
author: Amy P.

description:
We came to celebrate the 12-year anniversary of our first date. I checked out the menu the day before and was prepared to be a little disappointed with the tasting menu. It sounds like it was going to be pretty heavy on the first flavor, but the salmon (main course), oysters (1st course) and salad with anchovy dressing (4th course) were also pleasantly mild. The corn cake and corn ice cream were disappointing - the former tasting like an angel food cake, and the second tasting like what's leftover from a can of creamed corn after you eat the corn.

My favorite course was the gnocchi w/ fava beans. The tasting menu was fun and nice for a date. I would probably come back to sit at the bar from the ala carte menu.

Service was a very polite, but sometimes a little clumsy. Waiters planned to keep neighboring tables on similar timing so it doesn't spoil the surprise if a table next to you is served first. Within seconds - before you've had time to get jealous - your food arrives.
author: Ana D.

description: Really lovely tasty lunch. Food was 100% on point, from the whipped Gruyere puff pastry with pickled shallot gelee & flowers (see photo) to the fire-roasted trout that was done just perfectly to the baby gem beet salad. Perfect lunch, elegant relaxed atmosphere. It's not an inexpensive lunch, but not crazy, we felt prices were reasonable and the food worth it. Tip is included in the menu prices. We had a tough time deciding between several things on the menu, and the table next to us raved about everything they had, not making our decision any easier. It's nice to come back after quite a while and know this place is still tempting and satisfying our tastebuds.
author: Michelle L.

description:
Petit Crenn is a wonderful place to get a taste of what Chef Dominique Crenn is all about.

The decor of Petit Crenn is clean and comfortable; drawing my attention to the food not my surroundings. 

Every dish is delicious and flawless. 

My absolute favorite dishes are the following:
1. Escorgot mushroom broth
2. Grilled brussel sprouts crispy shallots espelete dressing
3. Whole rainbow trout cider sabayon
4. Salade of littlegems anchovy caper vinaigrette heirloom tomato fromage

The french press coffee and salted caramel ended my dinner beautifully .

LOVE.
author: Vix V.

description:
The food was good. That's it. Not spectacular, not amazing, not inspired, not surprising. It was good. It lacked any of the creativity I usually expect from a limited-seating, tasting-menu focused restaurant from a renowned chef.

The market fish had me excited when they brought it around from table to table, but its preparation seemed incredibly pedestrian, and the ingredients in the complementary dishes were fresh and tasty but simply plain and expected.

The real issue for me was the smoke. They cook the market fish right in the main room on a wood fire, and the facility just isn't designed for it. During the meal I found myself squinting and tearing up--it was difficult to keep my eyes open as the entire restaurant was filled with smoke. Occasionally they would open the door, giving us a slight reprieve, but then it would get too cold, and they'd shut the door again, thus flooding the space again with smoke.

My clothes reeked of a campfire and had to be washed, and the smell is still lingering on my hair and body even after a long shower! Don't wear your luxury clothes unless you feel like washing them.

There are many other interesting and quality tasting menu experiences in SF, I see no reason to go back to this one.
author: Will G.

description:
I am very disappointed at Petit Crenn. Understandably that this restaurant is a different style than her other restaurant. The food is just very mediocre and the tastes on the plate doesn't go together. The French bistro in our neighborhood tastes way better (and a lot cheaper). We sat at the chef's counter that night. In the beginning of the meal I was disappointed that we can't order the pre fixed menu. At the end of the meal, I am so glad we couldn't order that. Luckily we didn't order much because all the dishes are so disappointed.

Fried oysters with charred romaine lettuce - none of the flavor goes good together. The oysters are overlooked and sorry but I don't quite get a half  limp lettuce with a flavorless dressing. 

Petit Crenn omelette - the idea of a fluffy omelette sounds good but please put some salt in. The dish is one dimensional - bland. 

Abalone - a $22 dish with a tiny abalone (diameter of a ping pong ball?) - there is no flavor profile 

Wood fired grilled fish - another one dimensional over cooked fish. It is dry and salty. The foam they put on top of it is tasteless. 

Chef Crenn is very good at mixing flavor and texture in her flagship restaurant. I was hoping she will bring that to French home cooking. 

I asked myself, if it is another chef will I provide the same comment - the answer is yes, the place is really not good at all   

p.s - We saw a cook dipped his finger in the sauce to taste it and then wiped his finger on his apron. If you are doing that, I don't want to see it!
author: F C.

description:
Very good ...despite the $45 Corkage Fee! 

No notice on their website either which needs to be rectified. 

Despite that, I loved the ambiance ...wood open fire gives a cosy feel to place & real taste to the food.

The restaurant heated up somewhat before they opened the door.  Wear something light.

Food excellent, A la Carte gives lots of options ... Service not hurried at all ... Which I appreciated

Good Value .. Service included even on the a la Carte menu. 


I would go back... If they change the Corkage!
author: Edmind A.

description: The best meal we've honestly had in a while! Everything was not only cooked perfectly, but masterfully seasoned with the right amount of salt and acid in each dish! Loved it. The salad at the end of our savory courses was the perfect palate cleanser to get us ready for the beautiful desserts to come. And we were lucky enough to go home with a delicious almond croissant from the pastry chef. All around fantastic meal!! I can't wait to go back.
author: mel l.

description:
Came in on a whim. And leaving here a believer in Dominique! Met her too at the end of our dinner. Oui oui. We gotta go to Bretagne, France. 

We started with the biggest and freshest sea urchin ever. Check out the picture if you don't believe it. It smells sea fresh too!

We then had the best farm fresh grilled with trout with dill and lemon. How do you know when it's done? Stick a fork in the back and touch it under you lips. If it's warm, it's done. If it's cold, it's still raw. If it's hot, it's overdone. The cider sabayon sauce is egg yolk in cider whipped as you cooked it. This is by far, the best trout I have ever had. 

The dessert was Gateau Bretagne in plum sauce. Marvelous! Like home. BTW, am not from France but wish I were.
author: Jeannie H.

description:
Went here for lunch on a slow Saturday, one of four tables in the restaurant. Service was SUPER SLOW. 15 minutes for a drink, over an hour for food, which they screwed up. A few other tables that arrived were served and almost done before we even got our food. 
The worst part was, the manager nor the waitress offered an apology.
author: Elle R.

description:
Went with a friend for Saturday lunch (brunch?) The tasting menu, written on boards, looked fab but was for dinner. We created our own tasting menu:
Gougeres with gruyere cream and pickled shallot gel
Endive salad
Crispy trout
Grilled bread
Dessert

Gougeres - great, unusual, loved them
Salad - good, not really special
Trout - my friend, incredibly, does not like the skin, I think it's the best part! Crisp and tasty, red trout beautifully cooked and boned.
Bread - good, butter not needed as grilled with olive oil
Dessert, only one option - a pastry split and filled with a mousse - not chocolate, coffee? Glaze on top. Anyway, very good

Limited brunch menu but still could easily return to try a few other things

Generous portions to share. But the waiter thought, mistakenly, we planned to share dessert. No way! Had to bring a second one.

Service good but could have used another waiter. Only one restroom stall for entire restaurant, which could be a problem when crowded. Agree music a bit loud for my taste but we got seat by open door, which helped a bit.

I will probably return and can definitely recommend.
author: Carol S.

description: Chef's tasting menu at the bar/Chef's table allows you to see and learn what artful cuisine can actually look and taste like. The team is phenomenal to watch. It is not meant for everyone. Do your homework - watch Chef's table with Chef Crenn - Don't let yourself be angry or disappointed to what you simply don't understand. 2/23/17 offered a mushroom and gnocchi that seemed deceptively simple, but layers of flavor accumulated in a dish that brought you back to a French childhood.
author: Vincent C.

description:
Awesome food without pretence. We tried almost everything on the menu, and everything was brilliant. Friendly staff, great wine list, fantastic service, and stellar food. Worth every penny, and 'tips included' is a nice touch. 

Don't miss it.
author: Haje Jan K.

description:
The food was great.  Chefs were great and deserve much better than the front of the house. 
 The service was awful.  Our server was totally aloof and inattentive.  He did not know which wines were available... it took 20 minutes to find out that the bottle we ordered was no longer available.  When we finally received a bottle, 40 minutes into service, I chose to keep it table-side instead of chilled in the back because I didn't think I'd see the server again.  Server completely missed an entire course... How can that happen?  The restaurant is so tiny.  The couple next to us sat down 15 minutes later than us and got served two courses before we even saw our first.  I never complain about service, but I felt compelled to say something.  Then, there was really no attempt at service recovery.  Will never return... too many other great places in SF.  So disappointed... and for my sister's birthday.
author: Doug T.

description:
In short, the delicious food and casual decor does not make up for poor service and attitude from the staffs.

I went in on a Saturday around 1pm, the place was about 3/4 full. We had a reservation so the server seated us promptly and ordered our drinks soon after. Unfortunately - aside from the intermittent and welcome breaks in the gnocchi, lobster soup, omelette, and roasted trout that are absolutely fantastic - the service in general was slow and unfriendly. 

We waited at least 20 minutes before someone came by to take our orders (after we got our drinks) and only after we repeated looked over suggestively. The server quickly takes our menu *as we are still ordering*, even though planned to ask for recommendations since we are looking for a heavier meal than other clients. She grabbed it, assuming that we didn't want more, and started to walk away. I know you might be understaffed but there's no reason to rush your service.

Our first course came a bit later than expected - but the saddest part is that it came just a few minutes before the first course on the table next to us - who came after we got our drinks. It was quite disappointing, to say the least.

The final straw is in the under-cooked roasted trout. The kitchen staff came out to de-bone the fish and it was clearly raw along the belly. We usually cook it medium, he says. But I didn't want to take my chances, so I asked him to cook it some more - no hard feelings there. When he came back, he dropped off the fish, complete with sauce, and quickly turned away. I get it you're understaffed - really had no hard feelings. A smile or an assurance wouldn't hurt, you know? I didn't leave feeling satisfied to say the least.

So, if you have some time on your hands and want to enjoy good food - this is a good place to go. There's no gratuity accepted but unfortunately that comes with bad service.
author: Paricha D.

description: A friend of mine was kind enough to watch our son so that we could have a final date night during our move/unpacking and before the arrival of number two. We had to wait for an hour (put our names down for a seat at the bar) or so before getting a seat across from the wood burning oven. Everything there was delicious and lovingly prepared! Not to be missed are the Gruyere gourges (sp?) with a creamy aerated cheese filling and pickled ramps gele as well as the soft shelled crab dish. The apricot dessert was also divine. We were stuffed to the brim but fighting for the last bits of this stuff!
author: Melissa S.

description: We had a great time here. The food was amazing, and the waiter was so nice. Honestly, as it is a French cuisine, we were expecting to coming home still hungry, but we were amazed at how much food was served. So many delicious plates, and we couldn't finish our desserts as were so full.
author: Sahar J.

description:
This meal was exactly what I had hoped for, fun and easy-there was nothing truly exceptional but all the food went together very well and the service was great. My husband and I got two bottles of cider to go with our meal. The space is sparse but the staff, lighting and the smell of the wood oven make it cozy. 
My advice is 1) don't think you're getting fine dining, this has a bistro feel with upscale food but it's not white tablecloth 2) only wear chambray or Britton strips of you're ok looking like the staff (I did and was) 
Enjoy!
author: Kristina K.

description: Average experience with very average food. Wine list is good but ultimately didn't think anything was memorable or worth going back for. I think the idea was way better than the execution of the meal. Its just so different from what Atelier Crenn is that I think this idea should be re-thought.
author: Sean K.

description:
I really really wanted to like this place. I'd been looking forward to it since hearing about the place opening. But sometimes when your expectations are super high, the reality disappoints more than when you had mediocre thoughts going in. 

We had a reservation which meant the tasting menu and we decided to add two extra items from the a la carte menu. Those two extras (scallops and uni) were the bright spots of the night. Mussels were meh, not unique or creative, but I guess you could tout that as being traditional. The rest was good but not stand-out, which I would expect at these price points and the chef's klout. 

If you're going to go with a reservation, go with more than 2 people because there is a serious portion problem--Brittany food is pretty heavy and their idea for family-style for two people is far over what one could/should eat. For example, we were served a mountain of sunchoke mash as a side. And that was with a whole brussel stalk and a whole fish too. I'm not sure if it's a Brittany tradition to serve salad so late in a meal, but that's what they do here and it feels awkward and misplaced. 

I'm not sure I would go out of my way to go back, but if we happened to walk by and there were openings at the counter it might be worth a peek to see what you could order a la carte so you wouldn't have to commit to the tasting menu.
author: Vivian C.

description:
Came here for a work dinner with a large group (20), and I strongly recommend against it!  

The condescension expressed by the staff was unpleasant.  Our seating was at 6pm, and we were made well aware that we were not fitting pace of the kitchen, nor the style of the restaurant.  Plates were taken away from people as they were eating.  My colleague asked for a glass of chardonnay, and was then informed of the associated flight...so she asked again!

The food was ok, nothing extraordinary (except the salted caramels at the very end).  Everything was served family style.  Our prix fixe menu seems in line with others who have reviewed recently (oysters, mussels, carrots, potatoes, trout, salad, apple tart).  The oysters were served warm and very tasty.  The mussels were disappointing to the point of not being cleaned properly - with the volume of mussels they serve, they should know better.  The carrots were very nice (with yogurt and sumac).  The potato gratin was bland; so bad they brought us another dish.  The trout was deboned table side, nice but didn't make up for the flavor, or lack there of.  The salad, nice and bright, no complaints.  The apple tart with spiced cream was lackluster.

The wine pairings were well done, and the cider at the salad course was very refreshing.

Maybe good for a date night, but not for a big group.  Not sure its worth the expense even for a date night.

+1 star as they were quite flexible to accommodate vegetarian and dairy-free colleagues, and the stemware/dinnerware were very nice.
author: Beth V.

description:
Petit Crenn doesn't take reservations for breakfast or lunch, so it's a bit of a gamble to trek to Hayes Valley not knowing how crowded it gets on a weekday, or how much space there is to accomodate diners.  We were able to score one of the last tables available, and although there was never a line outside the small restaurant, the tables were never empty.  

Lunch menu is insanely simple.  Just look around your neighbors' dishes---those are your choices.  I had the mushroom tartine with a salad for $15.    

The menu might be simple, but the food is delicious and well-edited.  Mushrooms were nicely flavored but not overly marinated/cooked.  Bread was hearty and dressing was light and refreshing.  

The little cream puffs that resemble an adorable snowman was a perfect way to end a savory lunch. 

I am surprised at the fact that they are willing to serve breakfasts and lunch.  I am surprised that the food was so simple but elegant.  I am also surprised that the last time we ate at her restaurant (Atelier Crenn), we spent literally 10 times the money on two of us instead of four people this time, and although obviously the dining experience was totally different, they could both be so satisfying.
author: Candice B.

description:
Dinner here was disappointing. The food was very ordinary. Barely more interesting than what I routinely cook for myself at home. Tasting course consisted of oysters, mussels, potatoes, carrots, trout, salad. I suppose it's true to the marketing, it is the type of meal I might imagine a French mother to prepare, but for $200, I expected more refinement and creativity. Given that most of the ingredients were so banal, they must have one heck of a mark up on this food. 

We had a delicious wine but the pour size was the smallest I've ever experienced. 

Several others have mentioned that side dishes are over salted. I experienced that too. I actually bit into a clump of salty briny stuff while eating the salad. 

The table was too small to fit the food and there wasn't enough space to move. I kept hitting my arm against the wall and felt claustrophobic. 

They  need to get rid of the chairs! The tables have chairs that are similar to what you'd expect to find in a low income public school that was built in the 1950's. They were so incredibly uncomfortable that they make flying in economy class on United Airlines feel relatively luxurious by comparison. And, because of the strange shape of the chairs, it was impossible to keep a jacket on the back of the chair, so my jacket kept slipping off and falling on to the floor. Nonsense like this is inappropriate for a restaurant that charges so much.
author: Eater S.

description:
I had high expectations, but they were sorely not justified. The place is cordial, but super overly crowded. Mixed review on the staff, various levels of clarity about what was being served.
But the main issue is the food. 2 diff vegetables served were extremely undercooked. The fish was deboned at the table and deboned poorly. Then a foam was placed on the fish, hiding the bones remaining, making it almost impossible not to eat bones.
Also, there was no option to make substitutions in the menu, even though there were extra dishes on the 'specials' list.
I would certainly not eat there again.
The wine pairings were very nice, and the desert was quite pleasant.
author: Joey D.

description:
Food & Drink: 5 stars
Service: 4 stars
Atmosphere: 5 stars

My mom and I stopped at Petit Crenn for a late lunch, and we were very impressed! We weren't sure if we would be able to get a table without a reservation, but had no trouble around 1 pm on a Thursday. 

The menu is small, but we chose a couple of the dishes that sounded best and thoroughly enjoyed everything. I ordered a single oyster to taste, and it was served with the most amazing sweet and salty elderflower syrup, and a charred lemon half on the side. Such an interesting combination, and a perfectly delicious mouthful! Next, we split the trout tartine - fresh, rich fish atop a thick slice of crusty bread, with an amazing spread in between. So, so good. For our main course we chose to share the seasonal gnocchi. The house made pasta was incredibly light and airy. Probably some of the best I've ever had. It was served with corn and mushrooms in a delicious rich and buttery broth. Each spoonful was incredible, and because it was so decadent the single dish was more than enough for the two of us. The single dessert offering, a chamomile panna cotta, was yummy but probably my least favorite part of the meal. 

The restaurant itself is small and intimate, with maybe only a dozen tables and a long bar. I imagine it would feel very cozy at night, but was full of light on this afternoon. The French decor and lovely servingware are nice touches. The service was quick and the waiters were attentive. I would definitely be happy to return to Petit Crenn sometime soon!
author: Hannah L.

description: Ambiance was great, really felt welcoming and was decorated beautifully. Service was on point, with every interaction being pleasant. Food was so good!
author: Andrew A.

description:
My wife and I just had a lovely meal at Petit Crenn where we did the seated 5 course prix fixe menu. We were seated promptly for the 8pm seating and the ambiance of the restaurant could not have been more inviting. We were both recommended very nice wines to start and all the courses were delicious. They even brought out the catch of the day prior to butchering the fish, which was an interesting touch. With starters (fantastic oysters, wish they gave 2 each), catch of the day, sides, and desert we were both left stuffed and generally satisfied.

My main concerns were really that they coursed out the meal simply too much given only 5 courses, which took almost 3 hours and that given the relatively traditional french preparations it was simply an overpriced experience. Minor changes to either would have warranted 4 stars.
author: Brian H.

description: Went here a few weeks ago with my best friend and it was one of the best meals we've had in San Francisco. Some people get weird about a fish-forward menu, but we loved it. Their somm is amazing and every pairing is on point. I don't pretend to know much about wine, but I do know when something pairs and heightens the experience of both parts, it's magic. The desserts are well-balanced and have beautiful textures that leave you wondering how they do that. You'll have a hard time eating somewhere else upscale and feeling like your money went nearly as far as it will here. It's all beautiful, delicious, and well presented. We'll be back.
author: Melissa S.

description: The entire experience was top notch. I was coming in from New York and knew I wanted to try Petit Crenn during my time in SF. I originally made a reservation for one, but then my friend was able to join - called the restaurant day of, and they accommodated me, no problem. The food and service were impeccable. We got to talk to the wine director and she's a New Yorker herself. All in all, this is an absolutely must do while one is in SF!
author: Courtney B.

description: I expected to love this place because of the story of Dominique's life that parallels mine in a number of ways.  I will assume that I went there on an off night when she was far away on a well-deserved break. Nevertheless, it is hard to overlook the cafeteria-grade service, the painfully loud music, and the mediocre dishes.  We were there for the Sunday tasting menu and every dish was off, except for the sea bass crudo and the king salmon.  I may give it another try, because I cannot believe that this was representative of the restaurant.
author: Jean W.

description:
Unlike most of the previous reviewers, I have not yet had the pleasure of dining at Atelier Crenn, but unfortunately Petit Crenn did not live up to expectations.

With its pedigree and the price point of a one Michelin starred restaurant, I arrived excitedly anticipating excellent executions and flavors, simple and direct food that was slightly elevated above the norm, and excellent service. The food was certainly not bad, and most of the dishes were enjoyable enough, but really nothing came close to being a stand-out...perhaps the escargot came close with it's interesting preparation, but this was counterbalanced by moderately dry and plain fingerling potatoes and undercooked Brussel sprouts accompanying the main course of nicely cooked whole trout (but unlike mentioned in previous reviews, was not expertly deboned and lead to constant picking of small bones out every bite of the dish). The oysters were fresh and nice appetizer, and the salad was good, but similar to a nicely prepared home salad with a cheese crisp. The dessert mouse was a nice typical French dish, but was a bit too creamy and needed more citrus flavor and acidity. The mignardises composed of a little butter cookie and housemade caramel was quite good at the end of the meal.

The service was amiable, but seemingly a little disjointed and inattentive. Multiple plates were dropped, and pacing was definitely on the slow side between courses. My small water glass stayed empty for quite a while each time I finished it (3 times total during the meal) with no one around for a refill, and the last time I finished the glass remained empty for the last 2 courses and remaining 25 minutes of the meal.

The wine list was quite reasonable and of good quality, with many ciders to choose from, but surprisingly contained no dessert wines.

Bottom line is that if the price of the meal was about $20 less per person, I would think it a better value, but for 2 prix fixe meals and 3 glasses of wine for $210, I expect a higher level of service, refinement and execution.
author: Evan B.

description: OK, the food was very very good (the exception was the main course fish itself, which was a little dry, although surrounded by good things). But everything else was just not that good.  Friendly enough, but slow.  (It's really annoying when there are two seatings in the entire evening, and they can't clear out the first group in time to sit the second group.  We had an 8:15 reservation but did not get any food until about 9:00, and the waitstaff gave a kind of "what is your problem" vibe when we got a bit grumpy about this.  The decor is nothing special, just kind of functional; very hard benches,  Not crazy expensive, but still, not cheap.  One bottle of wine and dinner for three was over $350.  I just expected something a little more special, given the reputation.
author: Anthony G.

description:
Delicious! Worth every penny!

My date and I had the tasting menu at the 6PM seating. Make sure to arrive on time! Also, we did not want to drink that much but were interested in the wine pairing. They let us split it, which was very nice of them.

The bread they brought out from Josey Baker Bread was delicious. I wish I had not eaten it so fast and saved it to sop up some of the delicious gnocchi sauce that came later. Basically, every bite of everything was delicious. Very vegetable heavy! The only non-vegetarian food we ate was the yellowtail fish. It was caught that morning and presented for us before it was cooked.

The space is cute and intimate. It is smokey, but I did not mind that. I'd recommend watching Netflix's chef's table episode on Crenn before attending!
author: Michelle M.

description: Overrated. Wish I had looked up the yelp reviews before going. Save your money and go someplace with a higher customer rating and higher attention to detail. Imo this restaurant does more to discredit Dominique Crenns reputation than promote it. Low creativity, decent customer service experience, wine and food pairing marginal, entire experience mediocre. A couple of the dishes were good. Not what I would have expected from this establishment or any of it's supposed caliber.
author: Bartholomew H.

description: One of the best and most enjoyable meals I have ever eaten. Delicious and beautiful. Exceptional service.
author: Jennifer C.

description: Excellent experience! We had overseas guests in town and were a party of four looking for great food, wine, and an environment to catch up. Petit Crenn was everything we wanted and more. The restaurant is small to mid-sized, with an open kitchen and perfectly prepared food. The preset menu meant no time was lost choosing - we got everything in perfect timing which left plenty of time for catching up! While its not the place for large groups, it's perfect for 4 or less. HIGHLY recommend Petit Crenn.
author: Julie R.

description:
Wow, what a disappointment! No, not just a disappointment but a complete loss of faith and belief in the marketing of the "super chef" era. Four of us were so looking forward to this meal after seeing the episode on Dominique Crenn on Chef's Table. The allure of the love and care and genuine authenticity that emanated from Dominique in her preparation of food that was displayed on the show was transcendent and drew us to her new restaurant. The actual experience and meal was anything but. 

One thing all of us agreed on, this was absolutely the WORST meal that any of us have ever had. Ever! The food was tasteless, unexciting, horribly presented and not even warm. No one finished any course. We are not tourists from Oshkosh or the Ozarks. We live in San Francisco and travel and dine worldwide. This dining experience was horrendous and everyone associated with this restaurant from the chef, Chef's Table, servers, owners should be ashamed of themselves. 

To say the food was underwhelming and the experience was disappointing would be the understatement of the century.
author: S H.

description: Very attentive service, elaborate and well coordinated prix fixe tasting menu, original and earthy flavors.  A nice experience for a special but gourmet event.
author: Laurent G.

description: Two seating times, 6 pm and 8:30 pm.  Pretty laid back decor.  Once you sit down and order your drinks, food starts getting served pretty quickly, and there is a lot of it.  We started with an amuse bouche and bread with salted butter. Our menu included fresh oysters in a smoked tomato gelee, a delicious escargot and chanterelle mushrooms in rich tasting consomme, two perfectly cooked rainbow trouts for a party of 3, cabbage with bacon bits, cauliflower au gratin, little gems lettuce with heirloom tomato (right before dessert, interestingly), and then tarte tatin for dessert with petits fours to end.  A very well executed meal, delicious food, and I like the fact that it feels more casual than the flagship Atelier.
author: Vivian W.

description:
Very nice little addition to the "Crenn" restaurants.
Food was very fresh and great and the wine selection was excellent.
author: Kay R.

description: Very impressed with the food and overall experience at petit Crenn. Service was impeccable and the food very tasty.
author: Lea O.

description:
Amazingly elegant dinner without pretentiousness. The pop French nautical setting really lifts you out of San Francisco. Such a treat not to be at a restaurant designed with Edison bulbs, ropes and stuffed animal heads. The clean white setting gives it an other worldly feeling like you're not in Hayes Valley. The clientele is definitely on the older spiffier side.

The food was delicious, refined but approachable and generously sized. We did the tasting menu with the wine pairings and it was worth every penny. Dominique Crenn came out and introduced the first dishes--a delicate omelette with laces of tarragon and anchovies that was her mother's recipe. They fillet'd the fish right at the table for the main and all the side dishes were yummy and delicious.

Definitely a splurge but will be back!
author: Tom K.

description:
Celebrated an anniversary here. We were able to get reservations reasonably last-minute (day before) for a Tuesday night. Loved the simplicity of this place - two seatings nightly, with a fixed menu. Simple. 

Overall we had a great experience. Delicious thoughtful food. Especially love that veggies are front and center here - one of the best dishes we had was (grilled?) napa cabbage, something which might typically be a lowly side but here it was prepared and served as a main event. Lovely ambiance too - the space felt cozy and neighborhoody while still being really elegant.

A tip for future diners: the prix fixe menu is more than enough to delight your taste buds and fill you up. You can add onto your fixed menu any of the a la carte items they serve at the bar for walk-ins. We ordered one additional dish and I think it put us over the edge in terms of quantity of food. Particularly because it was served before the main course - the amazing fish and veggie dishes that were the highlight of the meal. I was wishing we had more room when those dishes came because they were phenomenal and we ended up leaving a bunch on the plate.
author: Neeta N.

description:
another overhyped place with pedestrian food. 

came here for bday celebration for their tasting menu with wine. i was very excited to finally try out this place since Dominque is such an acclaimed chef with her other 2 star place in the marina. i was unpleasantly disappointed to find out with the cost of our meal ( a whopping 400 dollars for 2 people), i am better off going to la folie or even monsieur benjamin to get much better service and food quality. 

after the over-charred and oily toast course, we each had 1 oyster to start the dinner (yah, just one), followed by french style corn gnocchi to share, and then came the entree of super over-charred/burnt fish. It wasn't your ordinary grill mark, we are talking about full on BURNT fish skin that makes the fish bitter to taste. after the main course, we were then served another small salad to share and finished up with chocolate creme and petit pastries for dessert. the whole food experience was less than memorable, the only memorable moment was how burnt and bitter the fish was when i was eating it. 

i would've given this place a 2 star, but the wine pairing was actually a good job so 1 more star for the wine, the rest was totally a miss.

for the star chef trying to open a casual bistro thing nowadays, no one can beat corey lee with his benu and monsieur benjamin gig, if you are looking to come here hoping to get a glimpse of how it would be like to eat at the her 2 star place, forget it, you are better off going over to hayes valley to corey lee's bistro.
author: Joyce C.

description: We went here for a Sunday brunch and could not have been more impressed. The menu is a bit limited in terms of options, but we found more than enough to be content. We loved the food so much we ordered the majority of the items. Everything was fresh with amazing taste. It was a real pleasure to see Dominique there as well. We cannot wait to give the dinner tasting menu a try.
author: David L.

description:
Interesting experience. I am a big fan of Dominique Creen's work at Atelier Crenn (which gets 5 stars for me), so I had big expectations for the place. 

I enjoy the concept of a communal dinner served by the cooks. The tasting menu of the day was well balanced. Oysters were delicious and the preparation was subtle. 
Mussels were good, but it was probably the most simple item on the list (at least for a French person). 
The trout was perfectly cooked, with a special mention to the carrots side. 
Cheese was interesting, the salad was a bit too big - or the cheese portion was too little. But again, I'm French so my cheese consumption is maybe not standard. 

The dessert was the least impressive: it was an apple far (traditionnally we make it with plums). It was pretty basic, and I would have put more apples. 

The service was good and the waiters were definitely nice, but there was room for a few improvements. We were sitting in a corner, and we have had to ask for water at least 4/5 times (we were constantly skipped). When trying my glass wine, the bottle was really too cold. The waitress was really nice; she agreed with me and went to open another bottle. 

The atmosphere is great. I would say that the music is maybe slightly too loud, but I liked the decoration and the open kitchen. I chatted a bit with the cooks at the end of the dinner, really friendly people. The brigade is actually quite young. 

Price was definitely reasonable, and it's nice to see that some restaurants try to get rid of the terrible US-tipping system. 

Overall, I think that Petit Creen will eventually get a Michelin Star. As a French person, the cuisine was not really over creative (especially if you compare it with Dominique's work at Atelier Creen), but I can see how it would appeal to Americans. 

I would happily go back.
author: Lionel F.

description:
I gotta say, this review is late and mainly focused on the customer service. My colleagues and I do this thing where we go out and eat at a Michelin Star rated restaurant in the Bay Area once a month as way to de-stress from our day to day activities saving lives. Since this one is a sister to one we decided to try it out. We went with the tasting menu which was good as expected. Our waiter was awesome! There was a lady with bright red lipstick who did not smile at any point. We were afraid to ask for anything and hoped our busy server looked over at us. She came around a couple of times but was very cold and just short with her words. So we decided to get out of there as soon as possible. 
Food 5/5
Portion/size- perfect
Wine Selection- great
Staff- for the most part amazing. 
My only suggestion is if you are going to be mad and mean maybe don't serve at all or don't help the other servers. Maybe be in an assignment that doesn't require you to interact with customers.
author: leba g.

description: Petit Crenn, compared to what one would eat in France, would be average at best. For San Francisco, it would be above average. So it all depends on one's culinary experiences.
author: elizabeth f.

description:
So glad I got to try Petit Crenn so soon after the opening! And to our surprise, Dominique was present and serving the diners!

The restaurant itself is small and simple, but it fits with the theme. White on white, stark and clean. There are two seatings nightly, at 6 pm and 8:30 pm. We arrived 10 minutes early for our 8:30 pm seating and saw the staff effortlessly transition from one seating to the next. 

Dinner is preset so no thinking is required. They were able to accommodate a gluten allergy as well. You start off with a few delicious bites then the courses come out. Each table is served the same dish at almost the same time. The servers manage to do this very well!

The menu is available online so I won't repeat it. But the trout is to die for. It is vegetarian fed so does not taste like mercury or dirty as fish sometimes does. The dessert was a citrus creme served inside an orange. Delicious!  We could not finish everything-- the portions were plenty and there were so many offerings!

Dinner is $72, gratuity included. The selection of French wines was good and affordable as well. 

I can't wait to come back and dine at the bar where they offer a la carte options.
author: K V.

description: One word: Unprofessional. I called before I came and they said they reserved 4 seats for walk ins. It was my birthday dinner and I was really looking forward to trying this place out. I showed up, they said they don't take names, it's first come first serve, and a table would be done in 20 minutes so me and my fiancé should come back in 20 minutes. So we walked around the block and 20 minutes later we came back to find out that the chefs friends came in and now the 4 seats reserved for walk ins were now 2 seats, and that someone came while we were walking around the block and now they were ahead of us.
