The host NEVER mentioned that if we leave the doorway, we lose our place in line. If that's the case she should never have said come back in 20 minutes, she should have said, "wait outside". She said the next table was now probably gonna be open in about an hour. I left and I'm never going back. So unprofessional.
author: Ethan H.

description: Took my mom here for her birthday and we had the best experience! The tasting menu is fantastic--really nice-sized, well-thought-out, delicious courses for a relatively great price. We shared a wine pairing which was also excellent. Each course, starting with the (insanely delicious) house baked brioche, was amazing. Such lovely details in each course, and flavors were on point. Not to mention the service was A+. Our servers were so friendly and helpful; before i even picked up my knife that fell on the floor there was another one on its way! They even put a candle on an extra birthday dessert for my mom. Very thoughtful, and ultimately a great experience. I'm really surprised by some of these low reviews... I've been raving about it and can't wait to go back.
author: Kelly P.

description:
Had a lovely and quite unique (for SF) dinner experience at Petit Crenn last night. I didn't have a lot of expectations but it definitely surpassed any I arrived with. 

We walked in a bit earlier than their second seating of the night and were immediately greeted and and offered a table. The space is clean, spare and inviting. I somehow felt transported to LA or NY. 

The dinner began with several delightful amuse bouche including local anchovies prepared exquisitely using the chef's grandmother's recipe and served by Dominique herself. The olive oil left after savoring them was so delicious we insisted on using it for the bread that was brought to us with its own scrumptious butter. 

Some of my other favorites from the meal were:

-local trout cooked simply and to perfection which Dominique de-boned for us at the table
-cabbage with vinegar and French onions which was a meld of the most satisfying flavors ever
-abalone and carrots in a memorable wine reduction

The concept is a single menu of several courses, which often I find is too much food. I didn't feel that way at Petit Crenn. 

Their pricing policy is European inspired wherein the 5 course prix fix menu includes service charges (so no tipping necessary). 

I will definitely return and in the meantime urge friends to try it!!!
author: Sandy G.

description:
Wife and I got lucky with the last table for the 8:30 seating on a Friday night. Having eaten recently at two of the best prix fixe restaurants in the world - Tetsuya in Sydney and Del Posto in NYC - we were really happy to find an outstanding experience at Petit Crenn for a completely reasonable price, all things considered. Our total check was $260 (tip included) with 2 bottles of wine for a 7 course meal where every dish was classy, expertly finished, and delicious. And paced perfectly - often a sore point with prix fixe. 

Honestly, I don't know why more restaurants don't use this business model. The two seatings and fixed menu allow the kitchen to totally control food costs, and lets the chef design a meal where each dish complements the other. 

Atmosphere is genial. Petit Crenn is a very comfortable space despite the minimalist decor and the staff does a good job of walking the line between being formal and inviting. Petit Crenn is pretty loud, and a bit bright for our liking. But the crowd was young, lively, and well-dressed, which is refreshing in a city that favors ironic t-shirts and North Face sweaters. Not being snobby here, just prefer a respectful attitude when having an excellent meal. 

It's a new restaurant so the little service gaffs are acceptable. Dominique Crenn is a pro and I'm sure she'll get her staff dialed in. She graciously introduced herself to guests and thanked them for coming. She says the menu is based on her grandmother's recipes, which if true makes her grandma one hell of a badass cook. I hope the menu changes with some regularity as this is a new favorite spot.
author: Scott M.

description:
I invited my wife to Crenn for her xxx birthday. We liked the food, the ambience, the service and the acceptable noise level. What we liked most was that they only serve fix price ($79) , fix time (6 or 8:30)  and fix menu dinners including the tip. 

The main attraction became a tile fish caught the same day in the Atlantic and served with a generous number of side dishes. Before served the fish was shown at every table - nice gesture we know from Europe.
author: Uwe W.

description:
Gorgeous plate-wares. I mean, its a selection of white bowls and plates that I would dream of having at home. Ahem, but aside from that, the food and service is great! 

Heres what to expect when you come in, the tabletop are at max 36 seatings(I tried counting) not including chef's table? There is no menu so its very simple because everyone is given a family style tasting menu. The whole entire food is 72 bucks (thats including service) but not tax and wine. I thought it was worth it because of the food itself. Their wine selection is pretty nice too, ranging mostly in France but an affordable price. 

The food itself is pretty simple. 
1. Oysters(depending on the catch of the day) I had the miyagi, but it seems that its always filled with the smoked Tomato Gelee. 
2. Chanterelle broth - very savory, Its simple, but the flavor profile is very good. 
3. Cauliflower Gratin with Smoked breadcrumb- I liked it. I thought the dish itself is very simplistic because its just a gratin, but i understood why they chose this dish, simply cause of the concept. 
4. Grilled Cabbage! Yum I love cabbages so this is what I like most. 
5. Whole Trout. Cooked at medium rare so everything is so soft and melts in your mouth. 
6. Citrus Mousse - Simple, a little bit acidic but refreshing. 
7. Mignardise - Butter cookies, truffles and Caramels, simple to make but they are drops of heaven! 

Everything was really good here, but the only thing i would comment is the spacing. Its very small, so I understand if you want to get a intimate dinner here, im afraid its hard to do, unless you go during the weekday, which is slow for the restaurant?  (Thats what i did). Because literally, I can hear the conversation of people who is next to you.
author: Cavin T.

description:
Why do some people at my company insist on meeting up at these "too cool for their own good" places? I swear, they just like saying that they went there to impress people. 
 Lets start on a semi positive. The food was good, not great just good. To be fair, I'm comparing it to Le Balafon in Dinard, so kind of hard to impress me after spending time in Brittany. Its almost as good as the everyday bistro food there. Of course there its just regular food not some example of a nearly impossible code to crack. Strange that normal french food done in the US is put on such a pedestal. But, I admit, it was good. Like, 23 euro in St Malo good. 
 The ambiance however is ridiculous. Its like the guys from A Clockwork Orange were told to make a sterile set for a 80s sci fi movie. The room is cacophonous and the service frazzled and confusing. The staff was not impolite at all. It just felt like many things were hindering our ability to relax and converse. The super bright lights and white...well almost everything didn't help.
 Hip, slick and or trendy will never impress me. The money wasted on design should have gone to the fundamentals of service. I ran into this kind of thing all the time time back east. The same food in my hometown was ten times more expensive across the river because of Manhattan rents and a fortune in art work that had to be paid for in every dish.  
 Still, after tuning out all the distracting elements, the food was good.
author: Steve M.

description:
We enjoyed most of our dishes. Will probably go back.

The service was good, but the Italian host is pretty bad. His poor English skills are annoying. He gave us a long lecture on how to book a table online. We said "We have a reservation" not "Do you have a table?"

The space is nice, but they really need to dim the lights.
author: Lola P.

description:
Highly recommended -- very elegant with great service and food.

Came with a group of six, the table by the window was perfect for a large party. We had the prix fixe menu and added the wine pairing which was spot on. We got seven courses, mainly seafood including Oysters, Mussels and a full size (whole!) Octopus. You can tell they use very good, fresh seafood and produce.
author: Meron A.

description: They seated everyone at 8:30 so the service was fairly seamless with everyone in the restaurant basically on the same course at the same time. The food was portioned perfectly, served family style for the table to share. I really enjoyed the flavors of everything we got, baked cauliflower, roasted potatoes, cheese puff bites, salad at the end as the French do, and several small desserts to try. Oh and they first brought out this bread, huge slices of the best rustic bread ever with butter baked in. Yum.
author: Marisa L.

description:
The review is not about the wine. I came in for a glass of wine and the wine list is good. The menu looks great! I didn't get to eat but the food looked amazing. I'm writing a bad review because the host/server was very standoffish and rude. I've been to way nicer restaurants than this and I just asked her who I had to order from politely and she stayed in my face and said - seems like I'm the right person! Then I asked her about how the menu worked and the first thing she said is WE ARE NOT SERVING ANYMORE! Then I asked again, but how does the menu work here? She : at the bar is a la carte. me: and at the tables? She: 75 dollars per person!! Like it was a big deal. 
The blond host/server ruined my impression of the place. Owner: if you hire people make sure they have face to client skills. I've never felt treated like this before in SF. I'm well presented, educated and traveller.  Double check your marketing strategy to retain costumers. Your people is not getting it.
author: Joa B.

description:
This place has the perfect balance of casual lack of pretense and sophistication.  The small and simple clean white room with an open kitchen creates that warm, (really nice) home-like feeling.

I believe the menu changes daily (or pretty often), but everything we had was great, served at a nice pace.  Though the additions looked awesome, I am glad I took the advice of someone else on Yelp and skipped them.  It was more than enough food for us just with the regular menu!
author: Nicole D H.

description:
Yes, def a fan! We went for the chef's tasting menu, which, being seasonal, is very similar to the other dishes described in these reviews.  The oysters with smoked tomato gelee were outstanding, as were many of the amuse bouche.  I hate brussel sprouts, though I try them periodically when someplace thinks they have the new best way to make them... I think Petit Crenn has finally converted me... I went back for seconds. My absolute favorite was the dessert, though I'm not usually a sweet fan.  My weakness is citrus, and the orange mousse was lick the bowl (orange rind in this case) good. 

So why 4 rather than 5 stars? The wine pairings (two of which were not wines but ciders).  Two of the pairings were just way off (one red wine and the first cider), and the others were just OK, nothing that made you think, "wow, that was an amazing combo", and as mentioned, two of them we left unfinished.  Given the caliber of this chef-owner's reputation and how delicious the food offerings are, she really should rethink whoever is doing the pairings. My recommendation is go for the food, avoid the wine pairings and select a bottle on your own.
author: Kathryn E.

description:
YES. ITS FINALLY OPEN. 

Warning: I may be slightly biased because I absolutely love Dominique Crenn and have followed her everywhere. 

For those of you who just haven't been able to try Atelier Crenn due to its extreme price (I feel you all..), I think this is a great alternative to try Crenn's cooking. The atmosphere and the purpose behind this restaurant is still different from Atelier Crenn (Petit Crenn is much more casual, vibrant, and open), but you can definitely find similarities in the quality and seasonality of the local ingredients she loves to use in all her cooking. 

This place is still pretty expensive for an average dinner ($72/person), but it's a great glimpse into what Crenn offers and it's honestly a very filling dinner. I won't go into all the dishes that were offered (menu changes seasonally anyways), but I have to say that the trout was probably my favorite dish of the night, and even though the menu says it's a 5-course menu, there quite a bit of amuse bouche-like plates that come out as well. The environment is lively and everything is meant to be family-style, so don't come here looking for a quiet, intimate space to have a formal dinner at (that's what Atelier Crenn is for). I came with a friend, and we shared a 4-person table with another couple, where we had to share certain dishes/sides that came out as part of the courses. Given that, if you don't feel comfortable sharing tables and dishes with other people, you should plan on coming here in a group of 3+ people. 

I absolutely love the interior, the open space, and positive family-like attitude that everyone, including the staff, has once inside the restaurant. The service was also great but again, it could easily be my biased opinion (I came on opening day, so Dominique Crenn was present and helping to serve tables - first of all, fangirling really hard; second of all, of course service is going to be amazing if she's there watching everything; and third of all, the fact that she served customers herself as a 2-michelin star chef shows how down-to-earth, caring, and overall awesome she is, which deserves a star on its own)

I could keep going on about this place, but I'm just going to end this review with the fact that I WILL be back again ... if I can get a reservation because reservations are pretty filled up for the next 30 days already. Crenn, you did it again. *applause*
author: Judy B.

description: Loved the wine pairing option with our meal, each dish was beautiful and thoughtfully created. We sat at the chefs counter and it was so fun to have a front row seat to the kitchen. Staff was super friendly, we ended up being the last ones to leave because the chefs were so fun to talk to. Really feels like these guys love what they do. Definitely make a reservation, it's a fairly small space so it can fill up fast. There are two seatings each night at 6 and 8:30...and apparently they do lunch 11a-2p a la cart!
author: Amber R.

description: Fantastic food, and definitely on the pricier side, but we had a good time. I like the french ambiance. Reservations are definitely needed for the tastings, because the restaurant seats ~40 people at a time.
author: Temi A.

description: We have been there twice.  The first time as a party of two.  The meal was flawless.  The second time as a party of three.  This time the timing was off so two of our courses came out lukewarm.  We also noted that with a couple of exceptions, an extra oyster,an extra mussel, and two additional courgettes, we were served the same amount of food as the couple next to us (which included one very small filet of turbot for three people as the main course).  So, if you plan to go and want to get your money's worth, go as either a couple or a foursome.  A threesome get shorted on the food despite paying the full amount for the menu.  We won't do that again.
author: Beth B.

description:
food... meh.
service... meh.
seating policy... ridiculously rigid. if you don't believe me, try changing your table.
corkage... a ridiculous $45.
place on the over-hyped spectrum... way to the right.
place on the "desire to go back" spectrum... way to the left.
author: Sanil S.

description: Great experience! Friendly and knowledgeable staff....love all the little details they put into each dish
author: JoAnna L.

description:
I visited this week for dinner at the bar. 

The layout is gorgeous. Very light and chic and the overall presentation is very nice, especially the dishes. We opted for the bar because there are certain things in the tasting menu that are dietary restrictions. Service was a tad spotty. We never were clear on who our server was and always had to request water refills. Also there was some confusion on our order and what we had received and were still due. Perhaps out of order, but it doesn't matter.  The food was quite good but the portion size honestly left me wanting for more.  I don't think that all of the dishes are meant to be shared with the exception of the trout and cauliflower.  Everything was artfully presented but slight in portion as are the wine servings.  Quite pricy as I expected, but it was a nice surprise to see that the gratuity is included.
author: Amy Z.

description:
The food here is divine.  Came here for lunch on the weekend, which seems to be an abridged a la carte version of the dinner prix fixe.  No complaints here.

Perfectly dressed little gems, the most tender gnocchi I've had in recent memory, and the surprise hit of the table - the fire roasted trout.  Not something you see often on Bay Area menus, so we went for it, and so glad we did - the fish was served whole, and a very delicious gribiche-type sauce that brought out the flavor of the trouty flesh.  We also saw a few omelettes go by, so added that to our conquering front - a perfectly executed classical French omelet, creamy and ever so slightly sweet.  Finished up with the only dessert option - a nicely done (if microscopic) panna cotta.

Service was serviceable - one FOH staffer deboned our trout quite expertly - but otherwise slightly disinterested.  I'm willing to forgive that for the incredible quality of the food.

Setting is lovely - crisp whites and shades thereof.  Throw pillows on the banquette side look cool, but end up being somewhat awkward for dining in real life.

Would be very interested in returning to experience the prix fixe dinner.  Fingers crossed.
author: Audrey L.

description:
I'm a big fan of Dominique Crenn, and dinner at Petit Crenn last night was a solid 4 Yelp stars. Really, really excellent meal, although I'm not sure I'll be dreaming of one dish in particular a month from now.

Our menu last night:
Amuse bouche of a gruyere puff and oyster
Gnocchi and sweet corn
Market fish, tomatoes, potatoes
Salad
Corn cake with blueberries, nuts

Service was great, and I loved that everyone sat down together.
author: K. D.

description: Terrible service. Incredibly rude. Half empty restaurant and it took 45 minutes to get our drinks. Don't waste your time to be treated so rudely.
author: C K.

description: As we take a trip to San Francisco and we take my son and his girlfriend out to different restaurants as both work in restaurants.. Their words are this place is "Bad all around...Rude service salty food. This comes from professionals opinion in the industry. Think if you go to a restaurant and your paying all this money $$ and you have rude staff and food is over salty... No one wants to waste hard earn money like that
author: Queta Q.

description: I was very disappointed :( I looove the crenn may be it was my mistake expecting something similar but.. Ordered onion soup. It was supposed to be with caramelized onion but it was actually burnt. Did mentioned that to the waitress at the end of the meal but nothing!! No good customer survive either. Don't think I'll go back Again
author: Taztouchy T.

description: We ate there on Oct 8, my husband's birthday.  We were given the best seat in the house - the front corner seat with pillows.  We came in, were seated, and the waiter started bringing the food.  Didn't have to order except the wine.  They are very accommodating when one of the items is not to your liking.  I didn't want to eat the raw oyster so I was brought something else that I was able to eat.  It was very nice.  The only negative - in my opinion - is that the restaurant had a smoky smell from the flames in the kitchen.  I had to get over it since I find it off-putting to smell smoke.  It immediately makes me feel a little nauseous.  After about 10 or 15 minutes I got used to it.  But, I felt like my hair and clothes smelled like smoke when I left.  Overall it was a really nice intimate dinner.  I would go back.
author: Ann S.

description:
Being that I didn't pay for this meal, I won't have the opinion I got ripped off, or I invested in something I had to like.  So I think this is a review purely based on food, regardless of the price.  In summary, I'd describe this is a place where the prep is complex, but the flavors are simple.  So lets get into it while I try to remember the onslaught of dishes that came out: the starter pastry puff with cheese was amazing.  The oyster...the orange zest actually stuck in my mind so it was ok.  The toasted bread...you'd think huh...but amazing bread.  The main was a halibut with a side of beans and roasted carrots...absolutely amazing sides.  The fish looked overcooked, but once it hit the palate it was delicious.  We were pretty much stuffed at this point.  Now the lowpoint: the salad with some dill dressing.  This taste was in my mouth all night, and pretty much what was most remembered in the meal because it was such a miss.  A tasteless bland salad that neither of us finished.  The desert was a light cream custard or something...it was ok, a bit light and refreshing, not a bam in your face decadent desert.  

So all in all the dinner was nice.  Not knowing the price, I'd go back and glad I experienced it. 

The atmosphere.  Ugh, the all white interior felt like I was in some hoity toity store that thought they were better than they are.  It felt very pretentious, and not welcoming whatsoever.  It was my first observation when walking in the door.  Most of the staff was nice, but one had a perma bitch face as if she just hated her job. I'm sure if she lived in NYC or LA, she would be re-calibrated.  People (not me) are paying a lot for a dinner, wear a friggin smile.
author: A A.

description: The food is good, the fish was excellent... But a big part of a restaurant experience is also the ambiance and the service : both not very good. The service is professional but very cold, the minimum explanation about the dishes, no smile at all. So you are in cold ambiance restaurant with good food.
author: Arnaud M.

description: We walked in without a res and walked out 20 minutes later, having had a very bad experience.  They seated us and never told us the prix fixe menu was not available because we didn't have a reservation.  Then when we complained, someone came over to defend the first person.  A few minutes later, when we were about to leave, a third person came over and arrogantly and arbitrarily announced that we could have the prix fixe meal, with no apologies whatsoever.    The waiter we had for 20 minutes had no idea what he was doing, knew nothing about the menu or wine list, despite the fact that we were now being charged $87 pp for a supposedly elegant meal.  There was a layer of dust all over the table and cutlery which no one in the restaurant noticed or rectified.  Completely disorganized staff, arrogant manager, simply awful experience.  So glad we left and went to Rich Table and had a wonderful meal!
author: Jake F.

description: Love this place. I wish we had more casual tasting menus with nice byo policies in Chicago. Lovely & chic space; great service. Charming in the best of ways. Romantic. And the food is unforgettable.
author: Leah H.

description:
Just OK. Not worth the hype.... We were totally underwhelmed.  Nothing was bad, but there was a general lack of precision and I felt more like the kitchen was still working things out. 

First course we're oysters. Fresh. Tasty. But almost ruined with a sweet mignonette. I thought it was ok, but wished I'd had some lemon juice to add an acid note. My date actively disliked it. 

Next were mussels that were really quite boring. Not enough flavor and although not bad, I could have done much better at home. 

The laughable dish was a large portion of mashed sunchokes.  Tasty yes, but not very digestible.  They also served roasted Brussels sprouts that were roasted on the stem for dramatic effect. More style than substance if you ask me. They were good. But paired with the sunchokes I wondered why they would double up on two gassy vegetables. 

The next course was a whole grilled fish. I thought it was odd that the larger tables got an entirely different fish than the tables of two. Our neighbors had a flounder. We had a cod of some kind, which was a little over cooked and too salty for my taste. 

Sadly, my favorite thing was the green salad that followed with thinly sliced persimmon. The greens were super fresh and it had a very light vinaigrette. 

The dessert was a dense and pasty mess. Supposedly a Normandy apple tart.   Not sure if the traditional Normandy tart is as dense and tasteless as this, but I sure hope not!  

The dessert was a dense pasty disaster. A "Normandy style" apple tart. Dense. 

I left feeling very full. But not in a satisfied way. I won't be rushing back here soon.
author: Priscilla C.

description:
I was so looking forward to loving this restaurant but it fell flat. The plating, The attempt at coursing was laughable. Staff tries but are not trained enough in service. There understanding of your Wine list was not good. When someone asks which wine you recommend and what region, you should not say all of them are good.  

This was supposed to be a celebration for a special persons birthday.  Instead we got salty food. An atmosphere that was more of the $$ not $$$$.  The noise level was not average, it was loud.  This was a steep drop from Alterier Crenn.  

Hopefully as the restaurant matures it will get better but from what I experienced that is highly doubtful.
author: Andrew M.

description: Came for the 8:30 seating on a Wednesday night. I tried to book the reservation only a week and half before and of course it was full but they use a great reservation system that alerts u when a table becomes available! I ended up getting the reservation I requested a few days before our dinner. Initially the host ignored us upon seating almost everyone around us, until another host came and gladly sat the 3 of us. The food was everything. The showmanship of the fish throughout the restaurant including the sourcing explanation was unforgettable. The amount of food was way more than enough and above my expectations. Along with the dessert and candies to end the meal. Dominque Crenn  herself came to our table to greet us and see if everything was good while making small talk. Even tho she was just there to enjoy her own dinner, you could tell she takes pride in her restaurant. Also, the French Pinot Noir by the glass is superb (we got a bottle). One of the best light fresh Pinot's I've had!
author: Andrea O.

description:
This place is totally fantastic and one of my favorites in the city.  I am shocked at the low ratings from other Yelpers!  

The cuisine is from Brittany (Bretagne) in France, so seafood centric, because that's what they eat in Brittany.  The menu is set for the day -- which might not appeal to the person who wants to 'customize' every single item they order.  However, if you let them know about food intolerances/sensitivities when booking, they will accommodate gladly.  (We let them know about the gluten-free thing and they were able to modify seamlessly).  (if you have a seafood allergy, you may wish to choose another place).  Do let them know ahead though.  The woman next to me had about a million rules about gluten this and dairy that -- she hadn't notified them in advance and she also had 'just a little taste' of everything her date had, including the beer and a bite of bread.  (Please don't do that.  It's gotta be so discouraging to the chefs who take careful measures to ensure they don't sicken people with real food intolerances).  

Since the menu IS set for the day -- what you're going to get is the best of the market, the best of the season, in a focused, delicious preparation.  It's not exactly a cheap night out but it's really a great value at this price point.  I totally recommend it.
author: Jaina S.

description:
I had dinner here a couple of nights ago and the experience was beautiful.  I was excited to dine at this restaurant having seen the episode of Chef's Table that features Dominique Crenn.

Each course was full of interesting, light, summer flavor and the presentation was gorgeous.  I had no idea that a simple piece of bread with butter could taste so good.  The oyster was delicious and my favorite course was the Parisian gnocchi. My friend and I both agreed, however, that the fish entrée was good without being great, in part because it was slightly overcooked. Honestly, that didn't bother me so much because the experience of the meal was so enjoyable - a culinary story well narrated and timed perfectly.  It was a charming touch that the kitchen staff brought the fish (from Boston) out to the dining room to show everyone what (or whom) we'd be eating later on.

The staff were welcoming and attentive, and the text message updates were appreciated.  I got a reminder about my reservation and even a follow-up message asking about any dietary restrictions.

I would certainly go back and I'd love to visit Atelier Crenn... but that's a different tax bracket altogether!  I don't normally spend this much on dinner but I think it was definitely worth it.  The ambience was lovely - a light dining room that wasn't too noisy.  Good music and I could have a conversation without shouting (what seems to be a rarity these days).
author: James B.

description: Beyond lovely . Wonderful people, wonderful space and ambiance and outrageously delicious food, so unusual and innovative and generous
author: Barbara M.

description:
I hate to provide the first bad review, but here we go.

I absolutely loved the food at Atelier Crenn so I was really excited to dine at Petit Crenn. The price tag isn't low, but Atelier is so excellent I assumed it would be worth it.

The big problem began right as we arrived. When they say the food is served family style, they mean it -- there were only two of us hoping for a romantic dinner, but they forced us to sit at a table for four, with another couple, and split the food with them.

Before sitting down, we asked to be sat at our own table: we pointed out that there were open seats at the bar and open seats at other 2-top tables. The host said we couldn't sit at the bar because it was reserved for walk-ins nor at the 2-top because it was reserved for the 8 pm seating, even though we were there for the prior seating. Neither of these really made sense -- I'm forced to sit at a table because I made a reservation, so they are basically holding my cancellation fee hostage so they can force me to sit at a worse table? And the table that we would vacate before the next seating began we couldn't sit at because then they'd have to bother to reset it? We asked the host to just have our own table, as would happen at any other restaurant, but the host assured us there was simply no other option than to share a table even though there clearly was. And the host was totally unapologetic about it, even condescending to us that we needed to open our mind to try out this different way of doing things. Apparently this is part of the experience.

As expected, sitting right next to another couple and sharing food with them was supremely awkward and made it difficult to hold a conversation at all. I kept bumping elbows with the stranger next to me and couldn't focus on a conversation with the person I was having dinner with because a stranger was talking (at a totally normal volume) 6 inches from my left ear. It gets extra hard to hold a conversation because the restaurant is just loud enough that there's background noise, but quiet enough that it didn't drown out the stranger sitting right next to me, so all I could think about was the words he was saying.

In summary, it would have been easier to hold a conversation at a Burger King than it was at this restaurant.

Then there were all the little things that added up to be extra annoying: they don't serve tea; they charged us for the wrong wine; the wait staff kept bumping into me; the serving utensils didn't match the food so dinner was difficult to serve out of their family style serving containers; they served the four of us in joint vessels instead of splitting eminently splittable food like salads into two dishes for the two parties at the table.

Not at any point did the staff give any indication that they genuinely wanted us to have a good experience; the vibe consistently before, during, and after the meal was that it was a privilege for us to spend our money and time there and we should appreciate the uniqueness of the uniquely bizarre and uncomfortable reality they had created for us.

The food was fine. I would rate it average quality for a restaurant with $15 entrees, not a $72 tasting menu. Unremarkable. Nothing that interesting or that great-tasting or presented that well; just fine food that we could have cooked at home for a lot cheaper.

Walking out, my dinner companion and I exchanged glances and let out a sigh of relief because we could finally release the stress we were feeling throughout the dinner because of all the awkwardness and strangeness of the meal.

The ice cream was good. But not so good that I'd endure that experience again. I certainly wouldn't pay $72 to do so; you'd have to pay me that.
author: David B.

description:
This review is for the a la carte bar menu, for which we lucked out and got a last minute seat without a reservation.  The wood grill and the small space give it a cozy feel, but the overall vibe is elegant. The grill made it a tiny bit smoky to which I'm normally sensitive but it didn't bother me. Staff was tight- all trained professionals, but we particularly loved watching the prep chef behind the bar (young Asian guy) who was incredibly precise but so calm and focused on his work.  

I am not a salad person- save it for the bunnies.  But the buttermilk dill dressing was something I'd return for specifically.  The gnocci with peas was delicate but had layers of flavor- the chef explained how they used the pea shells to make stock etc.  And the deconstructed cheesecake, while not the most innovative, could not be argued with.  

The wine list was surprisingly reasonable for a place like this and we had a bottle of Sauv Blanc for under $60.  My ever discerning French boyfriend loved the whole experience as much as I did.  I'd go back and try the prix fixe at a table.
author: Jennifer B.

description: I don't get these three star reviews at all. Food was great - gnocchi were perfect. Service was lovely. Petit Crenn is exactly what I wanted it to be.
author: L T.

description: We ordered about half the menu today at brunch. We were pleased with every dish, but the trout and croque madame were standouts. The whole trout was fresh, moist, deboned, and had a crispy skin. The wait staff was pleasant and attentive. We plan to try the dinner menu next time.
author: C C.

description:
Prefixed meal that changes each night and there are only 2 seatings a night. I got a text message asking about any food allergies or dislikes the day of our reservation. The location and venue are really nice we loved this place when it was Bar Jules the venue is small enough that it doesn't get loud. The food is vegetarian and fish which is my food preference anyways. Not all of the dishes blew me away but every course had a great standout. The main course was yellowfin tuna which they brought around to show everyone before filleting and claimed it was caught in Baja the day before and shipped next day air to SF. The oysters, fish and a vegetarian gnocchi dishes were my personal favorites. Dessert was disappointing the night we were there. Portions were generous you will leave full and satisfied. 

Because its prefix the only items to order are drinks. We didn't get the drink pairing there were 5 courses and I cannot handle 5 rounds of drinks on a Tuesday anymore. Their beer selection was terrible. There was an expensive french beer and the other option on the menu was verbatim "the champagne of beers from Milwaukee" which I assumed was Miller High Life. I was disappointed there were no beer options and found it pretentious that they clearly just don't want people ordering beer and how they went about it. That said we weren't going there to drink beer and heavy fare I just found it strange.

Summary: Really interesting meal that takes advantage of everything you get making a prefixed only restaurant and is a great experience.
author: David M.

description: Food has been excellent and expertly prepared the few times we have been here.   If you are particular about what you get to order, this isn't the place for you.  Service is very good.  Overall experience is very Euro if you like that sort of thing (and I do).
author: Neal M.

description: We absolutely loved our meal at Petit Crenn. The food? Fantastic. The staff? Incredibly personable. We loved how seasonal and authentic the courses were and will most definitely be back as soon as we can snag another reservation.
author: Andrew V.

description:
We got to go during the soft opening thanks to a friend :). The ambience is super cute, and I love the white and wood decor, which was very clean and simple yet warm and comfortable.

Since it was a soft opening, the front of the house was still ironing out a few service things such as explaining certain dishes and telling the stories behind them.  Each dish is supposed to have special meaning from chef Crenn's childhood, which gives the menu more meaning.  However, having chef Crenn drop by our table made up for everything right away.

We started out with some items that were communal with the table adjacent to us (well our tables were basically put together into a 4 top). I was a little caught off guard since I knew it was family style, but family style usually implies you share with your own group?  I think it would have been nice if they had set the expectations for the meal in the beginning, such as which dishes would be communal, etc. 

Amuses: shared with the table next to us
1. Radishes: to be eaten with butter and sea salt. This was not clear to us when the radishes and butter were set down separately, so I'm glad someone asked about the butter.
2. Gougeres: mini, filled with a tangy creamy cheese
3. French omelette: kind of like an herbed version of tamago - super smooth and silky and wonderful in texture. I wish we had more of this!

Food: 
1. Sweet water oysters: Each part of 2 got 6 sweet water oysters. The oysters were fresh and served on a bed of kelp, topped with tomato gelee. The tomato gelee was definitely the highlight 
2. Escargot: I usually don't like snails due to the sliminess, but theirs were cooked quite well and tasted more like clams in texture. I loved the mushroom broth and wish there were more. There was also a mushroom galette, which had good flavor, but it was a bit soft yet dry in texture and was a bit awkward. These came in individual bowls.
3. Cabbage: shared with the table. The cabbage was cooked down nicely and had a refreshing vinaigrette 
4. Broccoli gratin: shared with the table.  The cheesy creamy broccoli with a butter and breadcrumb crust was totally comfort food and tasted amazing.  This is best eaten hot.
5. Fire roasted trout: perfectly cooked with an amazing wood fired flavor, personally deboned table side by chef Crenn (!!). We got lucky since most other tables had other servers deboning it. The trout was pretty big for the 2 of us.  It came with a cider sabayon, and I wish there were more of it!
6. Little gems: a nicely dressed light salad in the end, shared with the table. It also came with some bread, which was good in flavor but not as crusty in texture as i had hoped.  It also came with a small wedge of cows milk cheese from Brittany made by monks 
7. Valencia orange granita over a mousse: this was beautiful and served in the orange. The granita was light and refreshing, while the mousse was richer. I personally loved the granita and wished there were more of it
8. Mignardaises: the butter cookie was really good, and I wished there were more. There was also a chocolate truffle and a house made caramel.

It's $72 including tip (but not tax).  They have a very French focused wine list, as well, with quite a few real champagnes.   We ended up getting various wines by the glass. I wonder if they could have done a wine pairing at request?

Atelier Crenn is one of my favorite places, so I was excited to have a less formal and more seafood focused menu.  Portions were good, and we were pretty full, but since the food was relatively light, I didn't leave feeling gross.  Meeting chef Crenn was a pretty awesome surprise - she was so charming and personable.  Overall, everyone was pleasant, and the back of the house did well with timing considering this was a soft opening.
author: Marilyn H.

description: Oyster, gougere, gnocchi, salad and dessert were great. Fish a little bit overcooked. Service ok. Lovely wine list and ambience.
author: Marco K.

description: This is a small, modern space serving very good food with excellent service.  My group of four did the seven-course menu and were very pleased with all of it.  The dishes that were prepared for food issues (one gluten-free person, one shrimp allergy person) were just as good, if not better, than the regular menu items.  We had a lovely sauvignon blanc to accompany the fish-centric meal, and were very pleased with it.  Looking forward to coming again!
author: Laura H.

description: We had a perfect meal here, with a trout that was so perfectly cooked, I asked what the secret was (perfect fish, timing and a grill).
author: Kal R.

description: So good.  The Petit Crenn omelette is the best omelette in the world, and anyone who disagrees should not be trusted.  My favorite restaurant in San Francisco, fo' sho'.
author: Mister M.

description:
We met another couple for a 5:30pm seating on Friday night.
Everything on the tasting menu was delicious and well prepared.
(Although we substituted shrimp for oysters).
Each couple split a wine pairing as well.
The place was full, but service was prompt and attentive.
author: Peter N.

description: Beautiful decor and attention to detail. The silverware is heavy and intricate. The music is refined. The staff is professional and friendly. And obviously the food is amazing. Every course is incredible. My only complaint was that it was very warm inside due to the oven. Wear layers you can remove.
author: Renee R.

description: Oh man, the simple toasts they make during lunch are divine.  I keep dreaming of them!!
author: Monica P.

description: Such a disappointment after watching season 2 of "Chefs Table".  And I guess you can say it was all due to first impressions.   As This was advertised as a neighborhood place that is like "coming home" at least to paraphrase, I felt so Unwelcomed at the start.  My impression was this was the neighborhood joint to pop into.  Suffice to say, we had a reservation and showed up 40 minutes early.  And we found out the friendly neighborhood joint did seating and made it none their problem to let us stand in the corner without much ado.  Then more folks started coming in while 7 tables were cleared and empty.  And then folks got sat at the bar all while we had checked in...waiting.  The staff was so interested in making the tables neat we were just passed over until we were asked if we would like to sit at the bar for a drink. By then I was so disenchanted with the friendly little bistro the meal was ruined for me.  Here is the deal.  The meal was fine.  Had I felt welcomed, it was still fine.  We had the striped bass aka rockfish.  Guess what, it was flown out from Massachusetts.  I can catch this in Maryland where I live.  Why is a 2 star Michelin chef flying rockfish to California?  And why are we also eating oysters from New Brunswick?  The lack of local protein befuddled me.  And the "charred potatoes" we're boiled and under seasoned.  Such a disappointment of a meal from such a high end chef.  Let's also mention that the place is so packed tight my wife kept getting bumped by the waitstaff.  So...the chef who goes to the dock locally and samples local prawns is shipping in rockfish from Massachusetts and the friendly place is so stuffy that you can't buy a seat because the staff is so worried about the next seating.  And there is a fee for reservation cancelation of 85 dollars.  So...though I wanted to leave immediately I had to sit there at a meal about as enjoyable as hanging out with your in laws after you have broken up with their daughter.  Thankfully my wife is super cool and at least her company made it better
author: Matty J.

description: I had one of the most underwhelming restaurant experience in San Francisco. Nothing on the prix fixe menu was exciting. Although the presentation was great, (the chefs bringing the whole fish over to the table before cooking, pretty plating, etc.) the fish was overcooked with a bland sauce and garlic chips that didn't add much to the plate, little gem salad and the potato dish was bland, and the gnocchi a la parisienne was mediocre. I'd much more prefer AL's place's vegetable dishes to here, Bouchon's gnocchi to here, and pretty much any other good fish dish to what's served here. I wouldn't recommend this place to anybody.
author: Aiden E.

description: Horrible experience.  The pacing of the tasting menu was too slow.  I have never been more bored or uncomfortable sitting on a chair in my life.  The wood grill filled the restaurant with smoke, my eyes were watery/itchy my entire time there.  My clothes still smell of smoke.  The food was ok, not great.  Very poor service; it took a long time to get my drink order.  I found the wait staff fairly brusque and dismissive.  I guess that is what happens when gratuity is included!
author: Adam B.

description: I slammed this place a few months ago and for good reason (see my previous review). Full disclosure--the manager called my husband and comped us for a meal, which we had tonight. I am very happy to say it was a very different and positive experience. I think they took my feedback--and that of others--and made some big improvements. The food was always delicious so that was not the issue. The big issue was lack of communication as to what to expect (since it was really a 3-hour dining experience) as well as a lack of flexibility (Me: "You are in the middle of the performing arts district and we did not know this was a 3-hour meal. What can you do for us so we can get to our show on time?" Them: Nothing.) Tonight was lovely and the service was so much better paced than last time. In fact, we got through 7 courses between 6 and 8. Last time we had only 2 small courses between 6 and 7:50. Also we observed that different tables were at different stages of the menu, so they were not being so rigid about everyone having to be on the same course at the same time, which shows much more flexibility. It is so nice when someone listens and makes adjustments to suit customer needs and Petit Crenn has done it. The service now lives up to the promise of the food and I can recommend it highly. I really appreciated the opportunity to try the restaurant again on their dime and I will definitely go back. But I would still not plan to go before a show--it is just too tight for multi-course meal. Take your time and make a night of it.
author: Sharon G.

description: Just had breakfast at Petit Crenn. This is a great place to start the day. I had the omelet and French press coffee. Delicious. Casual and friendly vibes. I was tempted to have the fresh croissant but last time I did I couldn't stop eating them and I didn't have hours just for breakfast (lol). Good to have a local breakfast spot.
author: Linda H.

description: Super good.  Recently sat at the bar and sampled several dishes, which I think is the way to go.  They do not course dishes when seated at the bar, you just do it yourself and order until you're full, or in my case, super stuffed !  lol  The food really is excellent !!!
author: Brent V.

description: There were some bright spots to the dinner, but we had terrible service. I'm pretty patient about these things, but to say our server inattentive would be a gross understatement. On the menu side, it was a very unusual format. The courses were HUGE and poorly planned, the whole service just didn't seem to work together. And then after you're served 4 lbs of average food, they bring you a salad before dessert. A salad. Before dessert. We didn't finish any of the dishes and still had no room for a green salad before desert. We skipped that course entirely. Dessert, however, was pretty darn tasty. Overall, we thought the menu was poorly thought out and the service was terribly mismanaged, not what we expected from Madame Crenn.
author: Tom A.

description:
I was nervous that Id walk in and find myself missing Bar Jules and the truth is that the space is so refreshing, clean and welcoming that I was actually met with the realization that Bar Jules had been in need of a face lift and PC has done just that. In a time in SF when everyone is making their restaurants to hyper cool one gets to just relax at PC. You can take in the very modern clean design and get into the perfect art, tile, etc or bc its so stylistically subtle one can just settle into it without even noticing much of anything but the feel of the place and of course, the food.  
When you walk in someone welcomes you. Ive been twice, takes me two times to get a sense of places, and once it was Chef Crenn. I was taken aback but suddenly realized that she was so casual, inviting and normal!  It was sorta sweet and I could feel what she meant when she said in some press thingie a few months ago that she wanted it to be like her home. She is there as though she has had you over to hang out. She deboned our trout at some point and engaged with us as though wed known each other for years...You can see she is enjoying the personal element of the space...which was fun to watch.
The food is deceptively simple. Youll eat it as though its simple cafe food and then it creeps up on you, and as we found, and you start talking to your dinner guests about what is actually going on. I had the omelette both times and on first taste its easy to think its just an omelette however after a few bites you realize no its not just an omelette rather its Chef Crenns omelette and its excellent!
The other standouts are the oysters, the cheeses(that arrive during the meal which is very fun), the salad which comes in a tall bowl, the tomato salad...which is perhaps the best tomato salad Ive ever eaten and it makes sense as as Ive followed Chef Crenn for years now its no secret that she can make a tomato dance!  We also enjoyed the escargot, the mussels and though the brussel sprouts were slightly undercooked the seasoning was perfect. Then there is the trout-truly fabulous. Chef Crenn clearly trusts the trout and in doing so lets it be. Its cooked over a wood fire and it appears she simply adds lemon. I feared it would be too simple when it arrived at the table and it is what made me come back within two weeks of my first visit. I awoke the next morning thinking about the trout. 
And though I am not Gluten Free they are serving a GF free bread option that may be the best bread Ive ever eaten. Super!
The wines are worth a trip all on their own. We had a beautiful burgundy that was a delight. 
The service is causual. The servers seem to take the approach that you will let them know what you need however it isnt as though we felt forgotten but rather not intruding upon. They seem to be clear that this is not a showplace for service but rather food and atmosphere. On both trips we met those sitting near by and enjoyed conversation.
Very little pomp, great food and wine, an approachable very talented chef and a warm space to settle in and enjoy!
Bravo!!!
author: Kate S.

description:
Simply put--this place is awesome. Six of us had dinner here last week. It was one of the best meals I've had in years. If you like seafood and adventurous cuisine, I would highly recommend Petit Crenn. 

Quick rundown of my favorites. Four different types of incredibly fresh oysters. A fantastic assortment of mushrooms that I have never encountered, but were so flavorful. A delicious brussel sprouts dish served on the stalk. The mussels were delightful and were served with some exquisite bread. A five pound Octopus served whole--this was unlike anything I had ever seen! The portion sizes on the mussels and octopus were extremely generous. The wine pairings were also phenomenal! Be prepared to set aside 2 hours to feast. 

I'm already looking forward to my next visit.
author: Andrew T.

description: So sad that this was a real disappointment. I looked forward to a good experience here... I loved the aesthetics and hoped for a nice new addition to the neighborhood. Sadly... My friend and I waited two hours for food we ordered, completely ignored... Felt like we had to really go out of our way to get water and wine in our glasses. Almost like a hostage situation? ;b The server who sadly shares my name said she was sorry in a 'fake-friendly way' said she would take off a couple dishes for the fact that the order was misplaced by the kitchen... Working in service, I know it is in very bad taste to blame the kitchen. Finally had to ask for the bill after another 30 min of waiting, never got food boxed  and was over charged $100 on check. They claimed it was a printer issue they have been experiencing. But why would they not double check the receipts they were printing if that were an issue? We would have over paid if not for looking at check... I would have been happy if they seemed to care about our patronage, but rather the sever was very defensive and rude, when I told her she had over charged us and we had been waiting for over two hours. She then gave us a $5 off discount... Wow. My time and future patronage is only worth $5? Cool. I think this place needs more servers, or perhaps should let patrons tip vs. including tips in their check? More incentive for servers to at least seem happy to serve you? That would help the Yelp reviews that clearly are not the most amazing for an over priced, not so amazing eating experience. What a waste of time and terrible way to spend a Saturday evening. Don't go.
author: Courtney H.

description: I've been obsessed with Dominique ever since I saw her on Netflix. So, my husband took me to Petit Crenn last night for our anniversary. I was beyond thrilled but was a little disappointed when we were escorted to seat in the corner of the bar area. My husband had made reservations and had said it was a very special occasion for us. The host was very nice but placed us to the side, and we were to wait for a Good Samaritan who would be willing to exchange his table for our two seats at the end of the bar. It was awkward for us but worth the wait. We had a cramped table close to the bathroom but we didn't care. We are in love and we were eating at Petit Crenn! The food was all I expected and more! For sure, our next anniversary will be at Atelier Crenn but we did joke about making reservations now. Maybe then, we won't have to beg for a nice table! But, in all seriousness, Dominique Crenn is a ROCK STAR
author: amanda l.

description: The prefix menu experience was too ochestrated for a restaurant intended to have a casual atmosphere. Although each course was delightful, it was a bit safe and you might be finding yourself eating the same little gem salad else where. The ocean/beach/sea atmosphere it desperately tries to create somehow was lost in translation through multiple vegetable courses.
author: Co K.

description: The team at Petit Crenn were awesome. We wanted to have a team dinner for over 20 people and they were so accommodating. From the first email they were flexible and courteous and made it happen seamlessly. The night was lovely too. They were flexible with our team coming in in waves and moving seats around. They had great starters and wine and nothing was too hard for them. The decor and service was amazing. The food was great. The oysters were amazing and the fish was perfect! Love to go back again....thanks team.
author: Suha P.

description: This is specifically for the service, and not the food, on a Saturday for lunch. I write this because poor service kills a restaurant, and there is no other way to make that clear to management. We were greeted coldly, by both the waitress and another woman who seemed to be hostess/manager. Both were grim, unsmiling, and put out by serving us. I have no idea why, other than I expressed dismay at their no longer serving breakfast despite having it written on a huge chalk board. A simple smile and a "sorry" would have smoothed it all over. Sad, as the food was lovely and the man who brought our food over and must have prepared it was friendly and smiling. Maybe train your employees who seem to have PBF?
author: Mary M.

description:
An excellent and creative restaurant new to Hayes Valley.  Petit Crenn is a very European-style restaurant where service is included, and all employees are dedicated to ensuring a positive experience for the diners.  I sat with a friend at the counter where we enjoyed the delicious oysters on half shell, Rainbow Trout, and a great French cider to accompany the meal.

Highly recommended!
author: Mike W.

description: Absolutely delicious meal, attentive wait staff,  it's place. Try the salmon, it's phenomenal.
author: Benjamin S.

description: Truly, as good as it gets. We were running late for this hard-to-get reservation, and the hostess was as accommodating as she could possibly be. We ended up having to sit at the bar (missing the fixed menu) and eating a la carte, and I am so happy we decided to do so. The oysters, the little gem salad, soft shell crab, the dessert. Everything we ordered was fast, and perfectly satisfying (not too heavy). The chef('s) came over to personally check on us, and we were blown away by the obvious personal touch in food, and in service. We have eaten at a few of the "big names" in the Bay (Manresa, Plumed Horse, Chez Panisse, etc), but this is a new favorite hideaway, a delicious treat. Bonus, prices are much less frightening than you might expect. We cannot wait to try the full dining experience. Thank you!!
author: B F.

description: I completely enjoyed my dinner at Petit Crenn just days after opening. The warm, friendly vibe of the communal service and homey, simple, yet perfectly executed food made me feel like I was in a Breton kitchen, assuming all the cooks there are spectacular, with an unerring attention to detail. I'd love to stop back sometime at the bar, and can't wait until their breakfast and lunch service starts.
author: Taco T.

description: I just had breakfast here this morning and sadly the perfectly soft boiled egg can not make up for the unacceptably poor service from the woman up front. I'm pretty sure Dominique would not have been pleased to see the way I was treated.
author: Brenda A.

description: What an amazing meal. Each dish was so well balanced, delicious to the last bite. We did the wine pairing as well which was a perfect compliment and a solid half glass per course. And the service and the staff was impeccable. One of the better meals we've had in a very long time. Great job!
author: Alex H.

description: Some of the dishes excellent, all at least good.  The problem was the service.  I eat out quite frequently in SF and the higher end restaurants seem to carefully choose their wait staff.  The service, at least with Courtney our server, was amateurish and unprofessional.  My wine glass removed before I was finished with it, not knowing ingredients of dishes, loud voice, overcharge error of $60 on check, very rote and rushed feeling when describing dishes.  Quick movements..knocked me twice while serving.  Please choose your staff wisely...it makes a difference to your customers.
author: RENEE a.

description: Had lunch. Service was terrible. It took nearly 30 min to order and only two other people were in the restaurant. One couple got disgusted and walked out. Lunch was nice but the service was so slow and bad I would not go again or attempt to try dinner.
author: Thomas K.

description: Had a fantastic meal last night at Petit Crenn!  The space was lovely and the food, and family style concept and overall ambience was perfect for a great meal!  I can't wait to go back!
author: Colleen C.

description: Absolutely delicious.  There are so many great restaurant options in SF that it's rare for me to return to one no matter how good (local take-out spots notwithstanding). This is one place I've been to multiple times. I enjoy this place far more than her Atelier Crenn spot; the food is more straightforward. Just fresh, beautiful ingredients cooked with a simple perfection. There are some menu items imported from Brittany: little pleasures that in themselves are nothing amazing but are things I had never had before and are fun and unique to try.
author: Eric F.

description: I was under impressed-was really looking forward to amazing dinner. Don't get me wrong - food was good but when I dine out I want exceptional. The only truly outstanding item was the fish. They nailed it.
author: Tore V.

description: The food was incredibly salty and frankly just did not taste good! The highlights were the fish, the carrots, and the blood orange mousse which were tasty. Everything else - not great and had something seriously off. This place was a definite miss, there are plenty of other much better places in SF for dinner, especially at this price point. Even the bread was not tasty, it was gummy and hard to eat.
author: Ang G.

description: We all had high expectations and walked away disappointed.  The food was not served at the right temperature.   Everything was served family style.  The prix fixe menu seems in line with others but we felt it was over priced for what was presented.  Courses included oysters, mussels, carrots, potatoes, trout, salad, apple tart..  The oysters were served warm.  The mussels were disappointing not being cleaned properly and served cold.  The carrots were very nice served with yogurt and sumac.  The potato gratin was heavy and bland.  The trout was deboned table side lacked flavor.  The salad was the best part of the dinner.  The apple tart with spiced cream was very lacking.
author: MY C.

description:
We have been wanting to try Petit Crenn for some time, especially because it was "inspired by Chef Dominique Crenn's mother, grandmother and her home in Brittany, France". Brittany is one of our favorite places we have visited in France.
We came for lunch. Street parking was easy to find, even though the restaurant sits just beyond the busy section of Hayes at Octavia.
Overall, the experience was very good. Service was pleasant and efficient. The portions were easy to share (and large enough to, as well). Here's what we had:
Gougères with gruyere cream and pickled shallot: The flavors were great. The shallot gelée made a nice contrast to the richness of the cheese. If the choux pastry had been a little more crisp, it would have provided an even better contrast to the filling.
Salad: I don't recognize the salad that we had from their online menu, but it was delicious with a citrus vinaigrette.
Parisienne Gnocchi: Ours came with hen of the woods mushrooms and baby kale. The sauce made from the mushrooms was great. I felt the gnocchi were a bit heavy (perhaps this was on purpose? I'm not familiar with Parisian gnocchi). Unfortunately, as the dish sat at the table, the sauce started to break; it remained tasty, though.
Petit Crenn Omelette: This was also delicious. The eggs were cooked into a roll that reminded me of a cross between Jacques Pepin and tamago.
I wouldn't have minded a few more choices of cider on the menu.
I'm not sure how well the dishes connected to the Bretagne heritage, but the food was well done in a French manner, good flavors and reasonable portions. Prices were reasonable given that no tipping is necessary.
author: Bob G.

description: Petit Crenn is awesome. The tasting menu is light, tasty and interesting. I love the use of fresh, simple ingredients. Usually tasting menus leave you feeling too full but at Peitit Crenn we left feeling satisfied and delighted. The ambiance is cute - all white Scandinavian interior. Chic neighborhood gem.
author: Britney R.

description: There are too many amazing restaurants in SF that actually care about their patrons.  Find another place!  We were so excited to eat there.  We made a 1:30pm lunch reservation for two on Saturday (8/6).  We arrived at 1:31pm. We walked in and stood there for 5 minutes.  There were four chairs open at the bar and a cleaned off (not set) four top by the window.  After five minutes, a woman (no idea if she was a server, host, owner, cook) says to us.  It will be a few minutes.  Absolutely nothing more.  TWENTY  minutes later, yes 20 minutes, a gentleman comes out and offers to seat us at the table that has been empty for 20 minutes.  After I sat, I called him over to very gently say that we want through an experience that could and would ruin an otherwise nice experience.  How can any service or business improve if they never receive feedback?  He seriously interrupted me a few times saying they planned to take care of us?  What does that mean? Honestly, NOTHING.  Double checked the receipt when I got home and they charged us $9 for an appetizer that we NEVER even ordered!!  What a horrible experience.  I'll say it again, find another restaurant.
author: Pamela G.

description: My husband and I had a great meal last night.  Service and food are both very important to us, and the restaurant delivered on both categories.  Expect prompt and courteous service.  They paid close attention to our dietary restrictions which scores high on our list.  If a restaurant is going to ask about your restrictions, you'd expect such restrictions to be heard. Our favorite course was the gnocchi substitute (we didn't want dairy/cream)--an amazing potato with fantastic kale creation.  Only Dominique can make vegetables shine so brightly!  The carrots tasted farm fresh, the butternut casserole tasted elegant and homey at the same time, and the fish was perfectly prepared and very flavorful.  Overall, a fantastic experience.  Highly recommend.
author: lily f.

description: Really enjoyed the preview dinner last saturday, so much so that I'm going back this Saturday. Great, simple flavors and I love that they served radishes with butter as a throwback to Chef Crenn's childhood. Delicious!
author: Olivia T.

description:
I was really excited to try the food at Petit Crenn, given that I haven't been able to swing by Atelier Crenn yet (and I've heard so many rave reviews about that place), but overall, I wasn't that impressed with what I received.

Ambience: clean, modern, lots of white and wood, vintage, mismatched silverware (so adorable!). The place is TINY, with the kitchen open so you can watch the chefs prepping the food and muse about the different equipment and the next dish. However, the size of the place makes it so that it gets quite loud quite easily -- I was in a group of six people, and it was near impossible to hear the jazzy French music playing in the background, let alone the person at the other end of the table. Dinner conversation with the whole table was a no go.

Food:
Appetizers: I really enjoyed both of these -- absolutely delicious
Gougeres: tiny lil cream puffs, with a salty, savory filling
French omelette: warm and filled with herbs and smooth and delicious! amazing amazing amazing
Sardines: surprisingly mild flavor, with a delicious spice topping

Courses:
1) Church Point oysters with a smoked tomato gelee -- 2 per person, the plating was beautiful and the tomato gelee complimented the brininess. A highlight of the night!
2) Escargot and chanterelle mushroom in a broth -- individual bowls, the escargot had a similar texture to the mushroom, which was interesting to me. I would have preferred more variance in texture, but wasn't bad per say. 
3) Cauliflower gratin with smoked breadcrumbs -- came in a large bowl for the entire table. it tasted pretty standard; I wasn't particularly impressed. 
4) Grilled cabbage and crispy shallots in a charred leeks vinaigrette -- one plate for the entire table. the vinaigrette made this cabbage shine, but it was overly charred and difficult to eat
5) Whole rainbow trout with a cider sabayon -- 1 per two people -- without a doubt, the star of the night! Cooked with lemon and herbs inside the trout, deboned by the sous chef, the perfect tenderness, especially the bits next to the lemon. The cider sabayon was AMAZING! 
6) Salade of little gems with an anchovy caper vinaigrette and heirloom tomato-fromage -- it came in a large bowl for the entire table. Overall quite delicious -- the dressing was surprisingly delicious and the textures from the tomatoes and savory (fishy) tuile were lovely! Also came with a wedge of cow's milk cheese, made by monks, who would wash the rind in an almond liquor. Pleasantly surprised by the mild, nutty flavor!
7) Citrus mousse -- the mousse was served in the orange and was slightly salty, but was complimented nicely by the cap of the orange, which had bits of frozen orange left inside. I prefer my mousse to be lighter and creamier, so I was left feeling a bit unsatisfied
8) Mignardaises: mmmm the butter cookie and the caramel were delicious, but the truffle was too dark and overpowering.

Service: Impeccable! The sommelier and servers were all lovely and attentive, filling up wine and water and checking to make sure everything was taken care of.

Overall, I was only fully pleased with half the dishes I'd received, and given the price tag ($72/person), that's pretty disappointing. I've had better at lower costs.
author: Courtney N.

description: It was good. A bit overpriced and lacking in service. Atelier Crenn is something else.
author: A P.

description: Lunch was a sublime experience. The staff was warm and friendly, especially Courtney whose professionalism and presence puts her in rarefied company. I had the smoked trout tartine of which I was dubious but wildly exceeded my expectations.  Accompanied by a small salad and a glass of rose I could not have been happier. A dinner experience will soon be in the offing.
author: David T.

description: Petit crenn is a lot of hype, food tasting was fine, but nothing was 'amazing', interesting project, you are seated intimately next to strangers on the next table, its good and bad depending on your style. Staffs are on point, friendly. Stylistic wise, its as hayes valley as it gets, cool but not unique.
author: Alvin D.

description: I've eaten here twice, once at the bar and once for the prix-fixe, and have absolutely loved both experiences! The staff is super friendly and took the time to engage us in conversations about the foods, ingredients and how they made their delicious tomato jam! Enjoy!
author: Yasmin F.

description: My husband and I went to Petit Crenn on Friday to celebrate our one year anniversary and had booked the reservation one month in advance.  They asked a week prior and note it on their website to let them know if you have any allergies.  I let them know a week ahead of time of mine and then the day of they told me multiple dishes were prepared with that ingredient and that I would be unable to enjoy them.  I called back and left a message asking what the dishes were and if they would provide an alternative.  For a top restaurant I was baffled that no alternative was provided and when I asked the manager said no.  I had to pay the same amount for the pre fixe menu and for half the amount of food.  While other tables were presented little cakes with a candle to celebrate a birthday, we did not receive anything.  When the check was presented to other tables they received sweet little bites and we received nothing.  Our server was wonderful and the idea of the restaurant is great but the manager was so rude and unaccommodating that I would not recommend this restaurant.  If you are not going to make accommodations don't ask people what they are allergic too and post your menus in advance so we could have canceled our reservation.
author: Katie H.

description: $79 for the prix fix dinner plus $58 for five small to moderate glasses of wine.  Prices include service.  There was a lot food, and we left feeling very full.  The meal is rich, with significant amounts of cream and butter used in the preparation.  Still, this is an experience to be enjoyed.  You are in the hands of a master chef, and the experience is great enjoyment.
author: Hank H.
